PT J
AN ZOOR14807052726
DT Article
TI A review of the amphidromous species of the Glossogobius celebius
   complex, with description of three new species.
AU Hoese, Douglass F. (doug.hoese@austmus.gov.au) 
   Allen, Gerald R.
SO Cybium
VL 35
IS 4
PS 269-284
PD 31 decembre 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Amphidromous species of the Glossogobius celebius complex found in lower
   reaches rivers of the eastern Indian Ocean and the western Pacific Ocean
   are reviewed. Glossogobius celebius is not as widely distributed as
   previously thought and is confined to the eastern Indian Ocean to
   eastern Indonesia. Three species are described as new species from
   Australia, New Guinea and various localities in the western Pacific. The
   species are distinguished on the basis of coloration, anal fin-ray and
   predorsal scale counts, head pores and papilla patterns.
C1 Hoese, Douglass F.; Australian Museum, 6 College Street, NSW 2010,
   Australia, Australia.
EM doug.hoese@austmus.gov.au
SC Marine &Freshwater Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0399-0974

   region; Eurasia; Asia; Australasia; Australia; Oceanic islands; Pacific
   Ocean islands

   islands /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14807052727
DT Article
TI A new species of amphidromous goby, Stiphodon alcedo, from the Ryukyu
   Archipelago (Gobiidae: Sicydiinae).
AU Maeda, Ken (goby@live.jp) 
   Mukai, Takahiko
   Tachihara, Katsunori
SO Cybium
VL 35
IS 4
PS 285-298
PD 31 decembre 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB A new goby species, Stiphodon alcedo, is described from 27 specimens
   collected in Okinawa and Iriomote Islands of the Ryukyu Archipelago,
   Japan. This species can be distinguished from its congeners by having a
   pointed, but not filamentous, first dorsal fin in males, nine soft-rays
   in the second dorsal fin, 15-17 rays in the pectoral fin, the number of
   teeth, and unique sexually dimorphic colouration. The new species is
   considered to have recently colonised the islands where it has
   established small populations, and is considered to have originated from
   regions to the south of the archipelago, with larvae occasionally being
   transported northward by the Kuroshio Current.
C1 Maeda, Ken; Marine Genomics Unit, Okinawa Institute of Science and
   Technology (OIST), 1919-1 Tancha, Onna-son, Kunigami-gun, Okinawa
   904-0412, Japan, Japan.
EM goby@live.jp
RI Maeda, Ken/G-4189-2015
OI Maeda, Ken/0000-0003-3631-811X
SC Zoology
SN 0399-0974
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Stiphodon alcedo [Japan /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates

DT Article
TI Five new species of Sicyopterus (Gobioidei: Sicydiinae) from Papua New
   Guinea and Papua.
AU Keith, Philippe (keith@mnhn.fr) 
   Allen, Gerald
   Lord, Clara
   Hadiaty, Renny
SO Cybium
VL 35
IS 4
PS 299-318
PD 31 decembre 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Five new species of Sicyopterus, freshwater gobies, are described from
   streams of Papua New Guinea and Papua Province, Indonesia. They differ
   from other species belonging to the genus by a combination of characters
   including the upper lip morphology, the number of soft rays in the
   second dorsal fin, the scales in the lateral, predorsal, transverse
   back, transverse forward and zigzag series, sexual dimorphism, and live
   colours.
C1 Keith, Philippe; Museum national d&apos;Histoire naturelle, DMPA, CP
   026, 43 rue Cuvier, 75231 Paris cedex 05, France, France.
EM keith@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0399-0974
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; Australasia
DE Sicyopterus calliochromus; Sicyopterus erythropterus; Sicyopterus
   lengguru; Sicyopterus stiphodonoides [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
   Sicyopterus ocellaris [Papua New Guinea /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Gobiidae
OR Sicyopterus calliochromus - Keith, Allen & Lord 2011 (Gobiidae): [Sp
   nov, Indonesia, P. 314]. 
   Sicyopterus erythropterus - Keith, Allen & Lord 2011 (Gobiidae): [Sp
   nov, Indonesia, P. 311]. 
   Sicyopterus lengguru - Keith, Lord & Hadiaty 2011 (Gobiidae): [Sp nov,
   Indonesia, P. 309]. 
   Sicyopterus ocellaris - Keith, Allen & Lord 2011 (Gobiidae): [Sp nov,
   Papua New Guinea, P. 304]. 
   Sicyopterus stiphodonoides - Keith, Allen & Lord 2011 (Gobiidae): [Sp
   nov, Indonesia, P. 301].

PT J
AN ZOOR14807052738
DT Article
TI A review of distribution, field observations and precautionary
   conservation requirements for sicydiine gobies in Australia.
AU Ebner, Brendan C. (Brendan.Ebner@csiro.au) 
   Thuesen, Paul A.
   Larson, Helen K.
   Keith, Philippe
SO Cybium
VL 35
IS 4
PS 397-414
PD 31 decembre 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB The tropical Indo-Pacific is considered the centre of sicydiine goby
   diversity. Nevertheless, these amphidromous gobies have only
   occasionally been recorded in Australia, and this probably relates to
   the existence of limited suitable habitat (perennial streams that drain
   steep coastal mountain ranges and enter the sea via poorly developed
   estuaries). We provide new records of the distribution of sicydiine
   gobies within Australia, and review the Australian biogeography of the
   group to confirm at least seven species from four genera (Sicyopterus,
   Sicyopus, Smilosicyopus, Stiphodon) occur in north-eastern Australia
   (North Queensland). We provide the first Australian records of three
   species: Sicyopus discordipinnis, Smilosicyopus sp. and Stiphodon
   birdsong. Current records of sicydiines in Australia are centred on and
   are almost exclusive to the Wet Tropics region, spanning just a few
   hundred kilometres of coastline. Longitudinal within-stream
   distributions of the fauna are species-specific (and to a large extent,
   genus-specific) corresponding with altitude and migration ability in
   relation to instream barriers (e.g., waterfalls). Sicydiines are
   colourful, and attractive to aquarists. This in combination with the
   apparently low densities and restricted ranges of sicydiines in
   Australia, suggests that collecting should be limited, at least until
   the population structure and ecology of these assemblages is better
   understood.
C1 Ebner, Brendan C.; Tropical Landscapes Joint Venture, CSIRO Ecosystem
   Sciences & Australian Centre for Tropical Freshwater Research, 47 Maunds
   Road, Atherton, Queensland, 4883, Australia, Australia.
EM Brendan.Ebner@csiro.au
RI Ebner, Brendan/J-3759-2014
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Biodiversity &Conservation
SN 0399-0974
BD Conservation; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
DE Sicydiinae [Conservation measures / Precautionary conservation
   requirements / New record; field observations; review] [Queensland / Wet
   Tropics / distribution; faunal list]. 
   Sicyopterus discordipinnis; Stiphodon birdsong [Australia /  / New
   record] [Queensland /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Gobiidae
OR Sicydiinae (Gobiidae): [New record]. 
   Sicyopterus discordipinnis (Gobiidae): [New record]. 
   Stiphodon birdsong (Gobiidae): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807052738

DT Article
TI Two new syntopic species of Typhloreicheia from South-Eastern Sardinia
   (Coleoptera, Carabidae).
FT DUE NUOVE SPECIE SINTOPICHE DI TYPHLOREICHEIA DELLA SARDEGNA
   SUD-ORIENTALE (Coleoptera, Carabidae).
AU Magrini, Paolo
   Marcia, Paolo
   Casale, Achille
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 43
IS 2
PS 117-134
PD 31 dicembre 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new syntopic Typhloreicheia species from South-Eastern Sardinia are
   described and illustrated in this contribution: T carlonnisi n. sp.,
   sampled at the base of the entrance pit of Su Pittiolu de Gospuru cave
   (near Armungia, Cagliari province), and T. paladinii n. sp., sampled
   shilling soil under big stones near the entrance of the same cave, and
   recently also on Lora Mt. near San Vito (Muravera). Owing to several
   morphological features, the first species apparently belongs to the
   angelae species group (sensu Magrini 2003), but is markedly distinct
   from all other Typhloreicheia species of Sardinia for the peculiar
   combination of the following features: small size; genae almost flat;
   elytra with discal setiferous pores on intervals 2-3-5-7 and lateral
   margins with series of numerous, small teeth reaching the elytral apex;
   aedeagus short, with median lobe narrow and bent on the ventral side in
   lateral aspect, asymmetrical in ventral aspect. Copulatory piece
   represented by an elongate lamina, rounded distally and with dorsal side
   markedly sclerotized and hooked. T. paladinii belongs to the occulta
   species group (sensu Magrini&Bulirsch 2002), and is distinct from the
   closer T. viti Magrini&Bulirsch, 2002 for the more elongate and less
   convex elitra, for the aedeagus larger in size, with median lobe less
   narrowed and slightly bent to the left side in ventral aspect, shorter
   and wider at apex in lateral aspect; the copulatory piece is more
   rounded distally. In a key for identification, evident diagnostic
   characters from the other species of the occulta species group known so
   far are stressed. The spectacular adaptive radiation of the genus
   Typhloreicheia in Sardinia, recently proposed and debated by one of the
   authors (A.C.) of this contribution, and the hypotheses concerning the
   origin of this lineage of Reicheiina in the island, are stressed in
   light of new data.
C1 Magrini, Paolo; Univ Florence, Museo Storia Nat, Via Romana 17,
   Florence, I-50125, Italy, Italy.
SC Zoology
SN 0429-288X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Italy
DE Typhloreicheia carlonnisi; Typhloreicheia paladinii [Sardinia /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Typhloreicheia carlonnisi (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Sardinia, P. 118]. 
   Typhloreicheia occulta group (Carabidae): [Key to species, Extended to
   include new species, p. 129]. 
   Typhloreicheia paladinii (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Sardinia, P. 123]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807049644
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14807049645
DT Article
TI A new Typhloreicheia species from Central-Eastern Sardinia (Coleoptera,
   Carabidae).
FT UNA NUOVA TYPHLOREICHEIA DELLA SARDEGNA CENTRO-ORIENTALE (Coleoptera,
   Carabidae).
AU Magrini, Paolo
   Marcia, Paolo
   Onnis, Carlo
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 43
IS 2
PS 135-146
PD 31 dicembre 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 2
AB Typhloreicheia casalei n. sp. is described from the "Buco sotto la punta
   Zippiri" No 2649 Sa/NU, a cave located in the "Supramonte" of Urzulei
   (Ogliastra, Nuoro, Central-Eastern Sardinia), markedly distinct from all
   Typhloreicheia species of Sardinia known so far mainly by morphological
   features of both male and female genitalia. The median lobe of aedeagus
   is large-sized, markedly curved, with apex abruptly and peculiarly bent
   at right angle on the ventral side. The endophallus has a developed,
   sub-triangular, snake-head shaped copulatory piece. The parameres are of
   peculiar shape: large-sized, widened at apex, each with three very
   developed apical setae. Ovipositor relatively small-sized; gonocoxites
   thin and curved outwards, each with two very elongate spiniform setae on
   the outer side. Owing to morphological features of aedeagus, the new
   taxon appears related to Typhloreicheia sardoa Baudi, 1891, known from
   the Gennargentu massif Both species are also similar in having elytra
   bearing a series of short, erected setae on intervals 2, 3, 5, 7 only.
   The evident diagnostic features distinctive for these two species are
   stressed and illustrated in text and figures.
C1 Magrini, Paolo; Univ Florence, Museo Storia Nat, Via Romana 17,
   Florence, I-50125, Italy, Italy.
SC Zoology
SN 0429-288X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Italy
DE Typhloreicheia casalei [Sardinia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Typhloreicheia casalei (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Sardinia, P. 136]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807049645
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14807049648
DT Article
TI A new genus and a new species of Melambiina from Oman (Coleoptera,
   Tenebrionidae).
FT UN NUOVO GENERE E UNA NUOVA SPECIE DI MELAMBIINA DELL'OMAN (Coleoptera,
   Tenebrionidae).
AU Leo, Piero (piero.leo@tiscali.it) 
   Liberto, Andrea
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 43
IS 2
PS 157-166
PD 31 dicembre 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Orarabion dominici n. gen. n. sp. of the subtribe Melambiina, from
   Northern Oman (Arabian peninsula), is herein described and illustrated.
   The new genus is easily recognizable by the following set of characters:
   size comparatively large, body apterous, stout, very convex, about two
   times longer than wide; antennae rather elongate, with the third joint
   three times longer than wide; elytra bluntly rounded at apex, glabrous
   even along margins; humeri rounded, bearing no calli; striae faint, made
   of very small and shallow punctures, elytral interstices flattened.
   Ventrites 1-4 with outer sides strongly margined, ventrite 5 with margin
   apically obsolete. Foretibiae slightly bent inwards, moderately expanded
   and flattened apically, with outer apical margins very widely rounded,
   not distally produced. Middle and hind tibiae oval in cross section with
   the upper surface neither flattened nor depressed. Male genitalia with
   distal part of parameres ventrally concave, inner margins of parameres
   distally bearing a fringe of long, projecting setae. The geographic
   distribution of the new genus is striking and no close relationships
   were found with any other genus of Melambiina, even if the new genus
   appears to be related with the cluster of Palaearctic genera of the
   subtribe. The type series of Orarabion dominici n. gen. n. sp. was
   collected under stones on arid soil, in an open forest of Juniperus
   excelsa ssp. polycarpos.
C1 Leo, Piero; Via P Tola 21, Cagliari, I-09128, Italy, Italy.
EM piero.leo@tiscali.it
SC Zoology
SN 0429-288X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Orarabion dominica [Oman /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Orarabion (Tenebrionidae): [Gen nov, Of subtribe Melambiina, Type
   species Orarabion dominica, p. 157]. 
   Orarabion dominica (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Oman, P. 159]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807049648

DT Article
TI A new Otiorhynchus (Lixorrhynchus) Reitter, 1914 from Sicily and brief
   notes on the genus Ioniorhynchus Magrini, Meoli & Abbazzi, 2005
   (Coleoptera, Curculionoidea).
FT UN NUOVO OTIORHYNCHUS (LIXORRHYNCHUS) REITTER, 1914 DELLA SICILIA E
   BREVI NOTE SUL GENERE IONIORHYNCHUS MAGRINI, MEOLI & ABBAZZI, 2005
   (Coleoptera, Curculionoidea).
AU Magrini, Paolo (duvalius@paolomagrini.it) 
   Petrioli, Andrea
   Daino, Giorgia
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 43
IS 2
PS 167-177
PD 31 dicembre 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species, Otiorhynchus (Lixorrhynchus) milazzoi n. sp., from
   western Sicily is described. The specimens were collected died and are
   missing of the genitals. It is the first finding of this subgenus in
   Sicily and greatly extends its distribution southward. The genus rank of
   Ioniorhynchus Magrini, Meoli&Abbazzi, 2005, wrongly considered a
   subgenus of Otiorhynchus Germar, 1822 (Osella, 2008a) is re-instated on
   the basis of the clearly different male genitals of the two genera.
C1 Magrini, Paolo; Via Gianfilippo Braccini 7, Firenze, I-50141, Italy,
   Italy.
EM duvalius@paolomagrini.it
SC Zoology
SN 0429-288X

   position; Status; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Italy

TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Curculionidae

   from, Otiorhynchus (Ioniorhynchus), p. 174]. 
   Ioniorhynchus loebli - Osella 1974 (Curculionidae): [Combination
   revalidated, Transferred back from Otiorhynchus (Ioniorhynchus), p.
   174]. 
   Ioniorhynchus vailatianus - (Osella 2008) (Curculionidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Otiorhynchus (Ioniorhynchus), p. 174].

   (Curculionidae): [Raised to, Ioniorhynchus, p. 174].

   [Referred to, Ioniorhynchus, p. 174].

DT Article
TI TWO NEW ITALIAN CEUTORHYNCHUS (Coleoptera, Curculionidae).
AU Colonnelli, Enzo (ecolonnelli@yahoo.it) 
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 43
IS 2
PS 179-186
PD 31 dicembre 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Are described and illustrated two new Italian species of Ceutorhynchus.
   The first of them, C. apenninus n. sp. from central Italy, collected on
   the montane crucifer Isatis allionii P. W. Ball., is close to C.
   peyerimhoffi Hustache from Spain, Italy and Algeria, also living on
   Isatis. The second, C. magnunoi n. sp. from southern Italy is very close
   to the French C. matthiolae Hoffmann, and was collected of Matthiola
   like the species from southern France.

   parasite species] [Italy /  / New species from plant host].

DT Article
TI Hymenopterological investigation in the island of Lampedusa, with
   description of a new species of Mutillidae (Hymenoptera).
FT RICERCHE IMENOTTEROLOGICHE NELL'ISOLA DI LAMPEDUSA CON DESCRIZIONE DI
   UNA NUOVA SPECIE DI MUTILLIDE (Hymenoptera, Mutillidae).
AU Pagliano, Gudio (guido.pagliano@tin.it) 
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 43
IS 2
PS 215-224
PD 31 dicembre 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 1
AB Physetopoda silviae n. sp. of Mutillidae from the island of Lampedusa is
   described. The species is compared with P. lampedusia and P. halensis.
   New records of Hymenoptera from the island are also presented.
C1 Pagliano, Gudio; Univ Turin, Via Leonardo da Vinci 44, Turin, I-10095,

PT J
AN ZOOR14807048742
DT Article
TI Radiolarian Faunas and Stratigraphy of the Pattenau-Formation (Campanian
   to Maastrichtian) in the Helveticum of Bad Toelz (Upper Bavaria).
FT Radiolarien-Faunen und Stratigraphie der Pattenau-Formation (Campanium
   bis Maastrichtium) im Helvetikum von Bad Toelz (Oberbayern).
AU Ohmert, Wolf (Wolf.Ohmert@web.de) 
SO Zitteliana Reihe A Mitteilungen der Bayerischen Staatssammlung fuer
   Palaeontologie und Geologie
VL 51
PS 37-98
PD 31 Dezember 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 2
AB The lithostratigraphy and biostratigraphy of the Pattenau-Formation is
   studied by means of cephalopods, foraminifera and radiolarians almost
   complete sections in the Helvetikum near Bad Tolz. Beginning with an
   unconformity the limy marls of the Pinswang-Member resent the basal unit
   of the Pattenau-Formation. The age of this member in the Helvetikum of
   Bad Tolz is the Early Campanian zone Globotruncanita e/evata in terms of
   the pelagic foraminiferal stratigraphy. This unit encompasses the type
   level of Pachydiscus sub- ustus stallauensis Imkeller and ranges up to
   the ammonite zone of Hoplitoplacenticeras van. It terminates with a
   layer of common emnitella hoeferi. The superjacent manly clays of the
   typical Pattenau facies are ranging from the foraminiferal zone of
   Globotruncana ntricosa up to the zone of Globotruncanella havanensis in
   the Middle and Late Campanian (respectively from Planoglobulina carseyae
   P manuelensis according to the Heterohelicids). The uppermost layers of
   the clays yielded Belemnitella minor and B. cf. langei. In the per
   foraminiferal ventricosa zone a rich radiolarian fauna comes in
   corresponding to the uppermost Crucella espartoensis radiolarian ne. A
   regional subzone of Caly-ptocoryphe cranaa Foreman can be recognized
   atop the espartoensis-Zone. Therein boreal species are xed with tethyal
   and pacific ones. The clays are superimposed by nodular marly limestones
   labeled here, as the new Schellenbach- mber which ranges frorr the
   havanensis up to the foraminiferal zone of Gansserina gansseri. The
   uppermost beds of this member are ly Maastrichtian in age ;according to
   the Heterohelicids Planoglobulina brazoensis and P acervulinoides. These
   layers include again poor radiolarian fauna of polysegmented
   nassellarians assigned to the regional subzone of Spongocapsula buticula
   n.sp.. Alltogether new radiolarian species are described. The top of the
   Pattenau-Formation corresponds to the foraminiferal zone of
   Abathomphalus yaroensis (respectively FIacemiguembelina fructicosa)
   without any faunal change to the dark sandy Gerhardsreit-Formation.

   Germany.

AN ZOOR14807048743
DT Article
TI The Gastropods of the upper Aalenian of Geisingen (Southern Germany).
FT Die Gastropoden aus dem oberen Aalenium von Geisingen (Sueddeutschland)'
AU Gruendel, Joachim (joachim.gruendel@lingua-pura.de) 
   Ebert, Martin
   Furze, Roger
SO Zitteliana Reihe A Mitteilungen der Bayerischen Staatssammlung fuer
   Palaeontologie und Geologie
VL 51
PS 99-114
PD 31 Dezember 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper 23 gastropod species are described from the Upper Aalenian
   of the clay pit Geisingen (southern Germany), mostly under open
   nomenclature. New is Parvulactaeon inusitata n. sp. From the Upper
   Aalenian of southern Germany gastropods were nearly un- known until
   today. Therefore this fauna close the gap between the well known
   gastropod faunas from the Upper Toarcian/Lower Aalenian on the one side
   and the Bajocian on the other side.
C1 Gruendel, Joachim; Free Univ Berlin, Inst Geol Wissensch, Malteserstr
   74-100, Berlin, D-12249, Germany, Germany.
EM joachim.gruendel@lingua-pura.de

   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Gastropoda [Fossil assemblages /  / New record; systematics] [Germany /
   South, Geisingen / ] [Jurassic / Upper Aalenian / ]. 
   Parvulactaeon inusitata [Germany /  / new species] [Jurassic /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Opisthobranchia
OR Gastropoda (Mollusca): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Parvulactaeon inusitata (Opisthobranchia): [Sp nov, Germany, Jurassic,
   P. 111; Fossil].

PT J

DT Article
TI Contributions on the Ostracode- and Foraminifera-Fauna of the Lower
   Freshwater Molasses in Switzerland and in Savoyen (France). 3. The
   Findreuse-Profile (Departement Haute-Savoie, France).
FT Beitraege zur Ostracoden- und Foraminiferen- Fauna der Unteren
   Suesswassermolasse in der Schweiz und in Savoyen (Frankreich). 3. Das
   Findreuse-Profil (Departement Haute-Savoie, Frankreich).
AU Schaefer, Peter (peter.schaefer@lgb-rlp.de) 
SO Zitteliana Reihe A Mitteilungen der Bayerischen Staatssammlung fuer
   Palaeontologie und Geologie
VL 51
PS 255-283
PD 31 Dezember 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 1
AB Ostracods and foraminifers of the Findreuse section (Lower Freshwater
   Molasse, Departement Haute-Savoie, France) are descri- d and
   illustrated. Ilyocypris molassica n. sp. (Ostracoda) is introduced as a
   new taxon. By means of ostracods the palaeoecological nditions can be
   reconstructed as temporarily but strongly affected by fluctuations of
   salinity, and the deposition area was probably bdivided into different
   salinity-controlled aquatic biotopes. Occurrences of the ostracods
   Hemicyprideis dacica (Hejjas, 1894) and He- cyprideis rhenana
   (Lieneriklaus, 1905) within the Findreuse section permit a correlation
   with sediments of the Upper Rhinegraben area. palaeogeographic
   connection probably existed between the Molasse Basin and the Upper
   Rhinegraben area during deposition of the tere Cerithienschichten
   [=Weisenau-Formation in the Mainz Basin].
C1 Schaefer, Peter; Landesamt Geol & Bergbau Rheinland Pfalz, Emy Roeder
   Str 5, Mainz, D-55129, Germany, Germany.
EM peter.schaefer@lgb-rlp.de
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1612-412X

   factors; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe;
   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene; Palaeogene
DE Foraminiferida; Ostracoda [Fossil assemblages /  / systematics]
   [Environmental indicators / Palaeoenvironmental indicators / ] [Salinity
   /  / ] [Zoogeography /  / ] [France / Haute-Savoie, Findreuse / ]
   [Miocene /  / ] [Oligocene /  / ]. 
   Ilyocypris molassica [France /  / Miocene & Oligocene; new species] [ / 
   / ] [Tertiary /  / ] [Miocene /  / ] [Oligocene /  / ].

   Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Granuloreticulosea

DT Article
TI Four species of the genus Leptoglypus [Leptoglyphus] from Japan
   (Coleoptera, Bothrideridae).
AU Aoki, Jun-ichi
SO Elytra
VL 1
IS 2
PS 263-271
PD Dec 31 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In addition to two known species of the genus Leptoglyphus, two more new
   species were found from Japan. One of them is described here under the
   name of Leptoglyphus tanakai sp. nov., which was formerly identified as
   L. orientalis SHARP. A large number of specimens of true L. orientalis
   were collected in the southern part of Japan. The other new species is
   described here as L. kubotai sp. nov.

   Ischaliidae) from the Island of Shikoku, Japan.
AU Saito, Masahiro
SO Elytra
VL 1
IS 2
PS 307-314
PD Dec 31 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Ischalia PASCOE, 1860 (Coleoptera,
   Ischaliidae) are described from the Island of Shikoku, Japan, under the
   names of Ischalia (Ischalia) toshikoae M. SAITO and I. (I.) kitanoi M.
   SAIT6. Both the species belong to the nominotypical subgenus Ischalia.
   Remarkable hind wing polymorphism is reported for I. (I.) patagiata
   LEWIS for the first time.

TI Description of a new Aphthona species from Japan (Coleoptera,
   Chrysomelidae, Alticinae).

PS 321-326
PD Dec 31 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Aphthona hakonensis n. sp. is described from Honshu Is., Japan. Further
   Longitarsus ihai CHUJO is newly synonymized with Aphthona opaca ALLARD.
   Accordingly 12 species of the genus are known to occur in Japan. A key
   to these species together with figures of male aedeagi is provided.

TI Two new species of Ochyromera (Coleoptera, Curculionidae) associated
   with a coniferous tree, Keteleeria evelyniana (Pinaceae) from Laos.
AU Hojima, Horoaki
SO Elytra
VL 1
IS 2
PS 335-341
PD Dec 31 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ochyromera keteleeriae sp. nov. and O. sonepheti sp. nov. are described
   from Laos. The weevils were captured on a coniferous tree, Keteleeria
   evelyniana (Pinaceae). Both species occur sympatrically, but O.
   sonepheti was much rarer than O. keteleeriae, whose male is unknown at
   the moment.

   Agriculture, 1737 Funako, Atsugi, Kanagawa, 243-0034, Japan, Japan.

TI A new species of Charinus Simon 1892 (Amblypygi: Charinidae) from the
   Leeward Islands, Lesser Antilles.
AU Teruel, Rolando (rteruel@bioeco.ciges.inf.cu) 
   Questel, Karl
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 49
PS 15-18
PD 31 diciembre 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Charinus Simon 1892 is herein described on
   the basis of four adult specimens collected in two localities of
   Saint-Barthelemy (Leeward Islands of the Lesser Antilles). This
   represents both the first record of the family Charinidae Quintero 1986
   from the Leeward Islands, and its first species to be described from the
   Lesser Antilles.

AB Hypnoidus ibericus n. sp.(Portugal, Spain), Agriotes simakensis n. sp.
   (south-eastern Turkey) and Anostirus omogoensis n. sp. (Shikoku, Japan)

   (Stierlin), Denticollis linearis (L.), Ampedus rubellus Gurjeva,
   Cardiophorus ruficollis (L.) are given. The genitalia of the male of
   Cardiophorus kasnaki Platia and that of the female of C. acuminatus
   Platia & Gudenzi, two species from Turkey, are figured.

PT J
AN ZOOR14804027313
DT Article
TI A new Mexican species of the genus Andricus with very peculiar
   characters: A. georgei Pujade-Villar n. sp. (Hymenoptera, Cynipidae).
FT Una nueva especie Mexicana del genero Andricus con caracteres muy
   peculiares: A. georgei Pujade-Villar n. sp. (Hymenoptera, Cynipidae).
AU Pujade-Villar, Juli (jpujade@ub.edu) 
   Equihua-Martinez, Armando
   Estrada-Venegas, Edith G.
   Serrano-Munoz, Miriam
   Lomeli-Flores, J. Refugio
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 49
PS 27-32
PD 31 diciembre 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Andricus, A. georgei Pujade-Villar n. sp.,
   from woolly yellow galls collected from the leaves of Quercus mexicana
   in Mexico's Distrito Federal (D.F.) is described. The most important
   diagnostic characters of the new species are illustrated and the
   differences with closely related species are mentioned. Andricus
   nievesaldreyi Pujade-Villar is proposed as a new name for Andricus
   mexicanus Kinsey, 1920. Andricus mexicanus Bassett, 1890 and Cynips
   guatemalensis Cameron, 1883 are considered as incertae sedis' The
   possibility that, because of its characteristic morphological
   peculiarities, A. georgei Pujade-Villar n. sp. might constitute a
   distinct genus together with A. nievesaldreyi Pujade-Villar nom. nov. is
   commented upon.
C1 Pujade-Villar, Juli; Universitat de Barcelona, Facultad de Biologia,
   Departament de Biologia Animal, Avda Diagonal 645, 08028-Barcelona,
   Spain, Spain.
EM jpujade@ub.edu
RI Pujade-Villar, Juli/K-9838-2014
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1134-6094
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Available name; Taxonomy; Parasites
   diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America
DE Andricus georgei [Plant hosts / Quercus mexicana / New parasite species]
   [Mexico /  / New species from plant host]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Cynipoidea, Cynipidae
OR Andricus georgei - Pujade-Villar 2011 (Cynipidae): [Sp nov, Mexico,
   Parasite of Quercus mexicana (Plant), p. 28; Parasite]. 
   Andricus georgei nievesaldreyi - Pujade-Villar 2011 (Cynipidae): [Nom
   nov, For Andricus mexicanus Kinsey 1920, p. 32]. 
   Andricus mexicanus - Bassett 1890 (Cynipidae): [Taxonomic position, P.
   32]. 
   Andricus mexicanus - Kinsey 1920 (Cynipidae): [Preoccupied name replaced
   by, Andricus georgei nievesaldreyi Pujade-Villar 2011, p. 32]. 
   Cynips guatemalensis - Cameron 1883 (Cynipidae): [Taxonomic position, P.
   32].

DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Notes on some African Pterophoridae, with description of new species
   (Lepidoptera).
AU Gielis, Cees (Pterophoridae@gmail.com) 
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 49
PS 33-63
PD 31 diciembre 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Recently collected Pterophoridae from African countries have been
   examined. In this study, new species have been recognised: Agdistis
   gambiaensis sp. n., A. rumurutia sp. n., A. Luria sp. n., Ochyrotica
   juratea sp. n., 0. willyi sp. n., Crocydoscelus castaneum sp. n.,
   Walsinghamiella leifi sp. n., W. niniella sp. n., W. peterseni sp. n.,
   Platyptilia albilobata sp. n., P. gatamaiyua sp. n., P. kaijadoensis sp.
   n., P. kasulua sp. n., P. nyumgwea sp. n., P. rufamaculata sp. n., P.
   rwandae sp. n., Stenoptilia amharae sp. n., S. uwinkae sp. n., S.
   wieringal sp. n., Exelastis hulstaerti sp. n., Capperia morogoroa sp.
   n., Prichotilus tanzanicus sp. n., Apoxyptilus steineri sp. n.,
   Megalorhipida umbra sp. n., Pselnophorus busoroensis sp. n., Hellinsia
   ruhuruinia sp. n., Adaina kihonda sp. n., Merrifieldia lonnvei sp. n.,
   and Cosmoclostis bivalva sp. n. The imagines and male and female genital
   structures are illustrated. New synonyms are recognised: Agdistis
   augrabiesi Kovtunovich & Ustjuzhanin, 2010 (partim) = A. criocephala
   Meyrick, 1909 syn. n.: Deuterocopus henrioti Bigot & Boireau, 2006 = D.
   deltoptilus Meyrick, 1930 syn. n.; Platyptilia pentheres Bigot, 1969 =
   Inferuncus toxochorda (Meyrick, 1934) syn. n.; Exelastis bergeri Bigot,
   1969 = Exelastis tenax (Meyrick, 1913) syn. n.; Pselnophorus ducis
   Gibeaux, 1994 = Pselnophorus laudatus Bigot, 1964 syn. n.. New
   combinations are listed: Inferuncus Gibeaux, 1994 for Platyptilia
   infesta Meyrick, 1934; Platyptilia interpres Meyrick, 1922: Platyptilia
   strictiformis Meyrick, 1932; and Platyptilia toxochorda Meyrick, 1934.
   Bigotilia Gibeaux, 1994 for Platyptilia melitroctis Meyrick, 1924.
   Antarches Gibeaux, 1994 for Oxyptilus tessmanni Strand, 1912.
   Trichoptilus Walsingham, 1880 for Oxyptilus erebites Meyrick, 1937.
   Megalorhipida Amsel, 1935 for Trichoptilus festus Meyrick, 1920;
   Trichoptilus varius Meyrick, 1909; and Trichoptilus viduus Meyrick,
   1917. Gypsochares Meyrick, 1890 for Pselnophorus pachyceros Meyrick,
   1921. Crassuncus Gibeaux, 1994 for Aciptilus tripunctatus Walsingham,
   1881. Picardia Gibeaux, 1994 for Pterophorus ecstaticus Meyrick, 1932;
   Pterophorus eparches Meyrick,1931; Pterophorus orchatias Meyrick, 1908;
   and Oidaematophorus ruwenzoricus Gielis, 1991. Vietteilus borbonica
   (Viette. 1957) is recognized as a bona species. Notable distribution
   data are mentioned.
C1 Gielis, Cees; National Centrum voor Biodiversiteit Naturalis, P.O. Box
   9517, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM Pterophoridae@gmail.com

PT J
AN ZOOR14804027315
DT Article
TI New species of Chactidae (Scorpiones) from the Upper Rio Negro in
   Brazilian Amazonia.
AU Lourenco, Wilson R. (arachne@mnhn.fr) 
   de Leao Giupponi, Alessandro Ponce
   Pedroso, Denis Rafael
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 49
PS 65-73
PD 31 diciembre 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four new species of chactid scorpions belonging to the genera
   Broteochactas Pocock, 1893, Brotheas C. L. Koch, 1837, Teuthraustes
   Simon, 1878 and Chactopsis Kraepelin, 1912 are described from a single
   location in the upper Rio Negro region, Brazilian Amazonia. These
   descriptions provide further confirmation of the high biodiversity and
   the important level of endemicity found in the upper Rio Negro and in
   the Imeri endemic centre.
C1 Lourenco, Wilson R.; Museum national d'Histoire naturelle, Departement
   Systematique et Evolution, UMR7205 CP 053, 57 rue Cuvier 75005 Paris,
   France, France.
EM arachne@mnhn.fr
RI Giupponi, Alessandro PL/M-5692-2013
SC Zoology
SN 1134-6094

   South America

   yanomami; Teuthraustes newaribe [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Scorpiones
OR Broteochactas caramaschii (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 66]. 
   Broteochactas neimeyerae (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 66]. 
   Chactopsis yanomami (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 67].

PT J
AN ZOOR14804027317
DT Article
TI Contribution to the knowledge of the genus Phylan Dejean, 1821 and
   description of a new species of Heliopates Dejean, 1834.
FT Contribucion al coonocimiento del genero Phylan Dejean, 1821, y
   descripcion de una especie nueva del genero Heliopates Dejean, 1834
   (Coleoptera, Tenebrionidae, Pedinini).
AU Ferrer, Julio
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 49
PS 75-82
PD 31 diciembre 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The study of the respective types and historical material compared to
   specimens determined recently by the late specialist Francisco Espanol
   (in lift.) indicates that Olocrates subheliopathes Reitter, 1904 is
   another Iberian species erroneously interpreted in recent works. Phylan
   subheliopathes (Reitter 1904) is clearly different from Phylan
   subheliopathes sensu Espanol, 1945 et auct., a new species here named
   Heliopates (Heliocrates) murriai n. sp., from Valencia, Zaragoza and
   Huesca. The type and historical specimens belonging to Phylan
   abbreviatus (Fabricus, 1775) compared with material determined as Phylan
   abbreviatus ssp. intermedius Dajoz, 1965, clearly indicate that it is a
   valid sympatric species worthy of elevation to specific rang: Phylan
   intermedius Dajoz, 1965, stat. nov. Illustrations and photographs are
   provided to separate all these species.
C1 Ferrer, Julio; Departamento de Entomologia, The Swedish Museum of
   Natural History, S-10405 Stockholm, Sweden, Sweden.
SC Zoology
SN 1134-6094
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Status; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Heliopates (Heliocrates) murriai [Spain /  / New species]. 
   Phylan subheliopathes [Spain / Valencia / Distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Heliopates (Heliocrates) murriai (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Spain, P.
   79]. 
   Phylan abbreviatus intermedius - Dajoz 1965 (Tenebrionidae): [Raised to,
   Phylan intermedius, p. 78]. 
   Phylan intermedius - Dajoz 1965 (Tenebrionidae): [Raised from, Phylan
   abbreviatus intermedius, p. 78]. 
   Phylan subheliopathes - (Reitter 1904) (Tenebrionidae): [Redescription,
   P. 79].

PT J
AN ZOOR14804027318
DT Article
TI A new species of Ammotrechella Roewer 1934 (Solifugae: Ammotrechidae)
   from Saint-Barthelemy, Lesser Antilles.
AU Teruel, Rolando (rteruel@bioeco.ciges.inf.cu) 
   Questel, Karl
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 49
PS 83-86
PD 31 diciembre 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ammotrechella beatriceae n.sp. is herein described on the basis of three
   specimens from the small island of Saint-Barthelemy, in the Lesser
   Antilles. This species clearly differs from all of its congeners by the
   peculiar dentition pattern of the of fixed the finger body of and the
   chelicerae (including the presence of a diastema between the median and
   the anterior teeth) and the coloration of the body and appendages, among
   other characters.
C1 Teruel, Rolando; Centro Oriental de Ecosistemas y Biodiversidad
   (BIOECO), Museo de Historia Natural "Tomas Romay", Jose A Saco #601,
   esquina a Barnada, Santiago deCuba 90100, Cuba.
EM rteruel@bioeco.ciges.inf.cu

SN 1134-6094

OR Ammotrechella beatriceae (Solpugida): [Sp nov, Saint Barthelemy, P. 83].

AN ZOOR14804027323
DT Article
TI Catops cavicis n. sp. from the Krubera-Voronya cave (Abkhazia,
   Caucasus), an interesting species of the C. alpinus group (Sensu
   Perreau, 2000) (Coleoptera, Cholevidae).
AU Giachino, Pier Mauro (PierMauro.Giachio@regione.piemonte.it) 
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 49
PS 87-89
PD 31 diciembre 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Catops cavicis n. sp. from the Krubera-Voronya cave (Orto Balagan,
   Arabika Mts, Abkhazia Rep., Caucasus) is described. This new species,
   belonging to the group of C. alpinus (sensu Perreau, 2000), is closely
   related to C. cavazzutii Giachino, 1988, of the eastern Pontic Alps, and
   constitutes its northern vicariant. The author provides ecological and
   chorological data on the new species and discusses the zoogeographic
   hypotheses on the origin of the phenomena of differentiation in the
   south-western species of this group.
C1 Giachino, Pier Mauro; Settore Fitosanitario Regionale, Environment Park
   Palazzina A2, Via Livorno 60, 10144 Turin, Italy, Italy.
EM PierMauro.Giachio@regione.piemonte.it

SN 1134-6094

   Leiodidae

TI A new species of the genus Nemadiopsis Jeannel, 1936 from Chile, with
   distribution data for the species of this genus (Coleoptera, Leiodidae,
   Cholevinae, Anemadini).
FT Una e4specie nueva del genero Nemadiopsis Jeannel, 1936 de Chile datos
   de distribucion de las especies de este genero (Coleoptera, Leiodidae,
   Cholevinae, Anemadini).
AU Salgado Costas, Jose Maria (jmsalgadocostas@uvigo.es) 
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 49
PS 91-102
PD 31 diciembre 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Nemadiopsis Jeannel, 1936, N. (Nemadiopsis)
   magallanesianus n. sp., is described and illustrated. The synonymy of
   Nemadiopsis (Nemadiopsis) franki Perreau, 2002 n. syn. with Nemadiopsis
   (Nemadiopsis) grossicomis Salgado, 2002 is established. Numerous records
   for all species of this genus are provided, with an update of their
   biogeographical information and a key to the species of the subgenus
   Nemadiopsis.
C1 Salgado Costas, Jose Maria; Departamento de Ecologia y Biologia Animal,
   Univesidad de Vigo, 36310 Vigo (Pontevedra), Spain, Spain.

AN ZOOR14804027327
DT Article
TI [A new species of Tityus from Bolivia, belonging to the subgenus Tityus
   and to the species group 'Tityus bolivianus' (Scorpiones, Buthidae).]
FT Une nouvelle espece de Tityus de Bolivie, appartenant aus sous-genre
   Tityus et au groupe d'especes 'Tityus bolivianus' (Scorpiones,
   Buthidae).
AU Lourenco, Wilson R. (arachne@mnhn.fr) 
   Leguin, Elise-Anne
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 49
PS 103-107
PD 31 diciembre 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Tityus Koch (subgenus Tityus) is described from the
   region of the San Mateo river in the province of Cochabamba, Bolivia. It
   is the latest member of the 'Tityus bolivianus' group of species to be
   found in this country. The new species seems to be endemic to the region
   where it was collected. The scorpion fauna of Bolivia remains, however,
   one of the least studied in South America, and no geographical patterns
   of distribution have yet been defined.
C1 Lourenco, Wilson R.; Museum National Histoire Naturelle, Departement de
   Systematique et Evolution, UMR7205, CP 053, 57 Rue Cuvier, 75005 Paris,
   France, France.
EM arachne@mnhn.fr

SN 1134-6094

   South America

OR Tityus (Tityus) horacioi (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Bolivia, P. 103].

PT J

DT Article
TI A new species of Diplocentrus Peters, 1861 (Scorpionidae:
   Diplocentrinae) from northwestern Alta Verapaz, Guatemala.
FT Nueva especie de Diplocentrus Peters, 1861 (Scorpionidae:
   Diplocentrinae) del noroeste de Alta Verapaz, Guatemala.
AU de Armas, Luis F. (dearmas@ecologia.cu) 
   Trujillo, Rony E.
   Agreda, Emmanuel O.
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 49
PS 113-117
PD 31 diciembre 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the scorpion genus Diplocentrus Peters, 1861 is
   described from the ecological region of Lachua, Alta Verapaz department,
   Guatemala. It resembles D. maya Francke, 1977, but differs from it by
   having a darker pattern of coloration, chelicerae with dark
   reticulation, a sharper subaculear tubercle, trichobothrium Dt on the
   fixed finger, and other morphological differences.

AN ZOOR14804027334
DT Article
TI On some species of Neuroptera of the Iberian Peninsula and the Canary
   islands with a problematic taxonomic position, or with dubious or
   questionable records (Insecta, Neuropteera: Megaloptera, Planipennia).
FT Sobre algunas especies de neuropteros de la Peninsula Iberica y de las
   Islas Canarias de posicion taxonomica problematica o con citas dudosas o
   cuestionables (Insecta, Neuroptera: Megaloptera, Planipenia).
AU Monserrat, V.J. (artmad@bio.ucm.es) 
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 49
PS 153-178
PD 31 diciembre 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A revision is presented of those Iberian lacewing species which up till
   now had a dubious or problematic taxonomic or systematic status.
   Designation of neotypes for the following species is proposed:
   Sympherobius gratiosus Navas, 1908, Sympherobius bellus Navas, 1911,
   Helicoconis interna (Navas, 1911) (= Aleuropteryx intema Navas, 1911),
   Sialis fumosa Navas, 1915, Sialis didyma Navas, 1917, Hemerobius canadai
   Navas, 1924 (= Hemerobius canadai Navas, 1924) and Sialis atra Navas,
   1927. Designation of lectotypes is proposed for Sialis nigripes Pictet,
   1865, Neuroleon canariensis (Navas, 1906) (= Myrmeleon canariensis
   Navas, 1906), Helicoconis laufferina Navas, 1913, Sialis excelsior
   Navas, 1917, Chrysopa montana Navas, 1917 (= Chrysopa palpalis Navas,
   1917) and Aleuropteryx aequalis Navas, 1918. On this basis, the
   following synonymies are proposed: Sialis fuliginosa Pictet, 1836 =
   (Sialis fumosa Navas, 1915 n. syn. = Sialis didyma Navas, 1917 n. syn. =
   Sialis gonzalezi Vshivkova, 1985 n. syn.), Siat/s lutaria (Linnaeus,
   1758) = (Sialis atra Navas, 1927 n. syn.), Neuroleon nemausiensis
   (Borkhausen, 1791) = (Myrmeleon buffer/ Navas, 1909 n. sin.),
   Helicoconis intema (Navas, 1911) (= Aleuropteryx interna Navas, 1911) =
   (Helicoconis laufferina Navas, 1913 n. syn. = Helicoconis pseudolutea
   Ohm, 1965 n. syn.), Chrysopa vindana Schneider, 1845 (= Chrysopa
   viridana Schneider, 1845 var. montana Navas,1915) = (Chrysopa montana
   Navas, 1917 n. syn. = Chrysopa palpalis Navas, 1917 n. syn.) and
   Hemerobius stigma Stephens, 1836 = (Hemerobius canadai Navas, 1924 =
   Hemerobius canadai Navas, 1924 n. syn.), and the following synonymies
   are confirmed: Sympherobius pygmaeus (Rambur, 1842) = (Sympherobius
   gratiosus Navas, 1908 = Sympherobius bellus Navas, 1911), Aleuropteryx
   loewii Klapalek, 1894 (=Aleuropteryx Lowii Klapalek, 1894) =
   (Aleuropteryx codinai Navas, 1910) and Nineta guadarramensis (Pictet,
   1865) = (Nineta alvesi Navas, 1917). Revision and discussion are carried
   out of some records of Neuroptera species having been recorded as
   belonging to the Iberian fauna and which are here dismissed as
   collecting data errors and / or misidentifications, with assignation of
   these records to other non Iberian species. Comments are also provided
   on some records of Iberian species that are dubious or questionable in
   terms of the localities from where they have been recorded and their
   known Iberian distribution, with assignation of these records to other
   Iberian species. New unpublished data of all these 14 valid species that
   support and corroborate the data and conclusions here provided.
C1 Monserrat, V.J.; Departamento de Zoologia y Antropologia Fisica,
   Facultad de Biologia, Universidad Complutense, E-28040 Madrid, Spain,
   Spain.

   174].

   P. 173].

AB Five new species of genus Leptomeson Jeannel, 1924 are described here,
   four from Croatia and one from Bosnia and Herzegovina: L. radjai n. sp.
   of from the pit Zvekaa, close to ibenik, L. dalrrratinus n. sp. from the
   pit Maravida jama, on the island of Ciovo, L. bujasi n. sp. from the pit
   lama kod Matesida stana, on the island of Brad, L. biokovensis n. sp.
   from the pit Pretnerova jama, on the Biokovo Mountain and L. raguzi n.
   sp. from the cave Majida ponor, near Crude. Moreover, some new
   chorological data are given on L. dombrowskii dombrowskii (Apfelbeck,
   1907), found in the cave Baba pilja, on Biokovo Mountain (Dalmatia).

TI Investigation of the endophallic structure of the subgenus Carabus
   (Neoplectes) Reitter, 1885 (Coleoptera: Carabidae).
AU Retezar, I. (retezar@t-online.hu) 
SO Folia Entomologica Hungarica
VL 72
PS 47-58
PD Dec 30 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The endophallic structures of the species of the subgenus Carabus
   (Neoplectes) REITTER, 1885 were investigated and substantial differences
   were found between the individuals from different populations. Carabus
   (Neoplectes) szekelyi sp. n. and Carabus (Neoplectes) imereticus sp. n.
   are described. New classification for the subgenus is proposed and an
   identification key to the species is given. With 39 figures.

PT J
AN ZOOR14810072919
DT Article
TI Nomenclatural notes and identification of small-eared shrews (Mammalia:
   genus Cryptotis) from Coban, Guatemala, in The Natural History Museum,
   London.
AU Woodman, Neal (woodmann@si.edu) 
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 124
IS 4
PS 249-258
PD 30 December 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A small series of shrews collected in Guatemala and registered in the
   British Museum between 1843 and 1907 includes parts of type series for
   three species: Corsira tropicalis Gray (1843), Sorex micrurus Tomes
   (1862), and Blarina tropicalis Merriam (1895). These three names are now
   considered equivalent, but my recent review of the specimens comprising
   the series indicates that they include three distinct species: Cryptotis
   merriami Choate (1970), Cryptotis oreoryctes Woodman (2011), and
   Cryptotis tropicalis (Merriam 1895). I review the taxonomic history of
   these specimens, provide current identifications tied directly to museum
   register numbers, describe how to distinguish the three species, and
   provide revised synonymies for these species.
C1 Woodman, Neal; USGS Patuxent Wildlife Research Center, National Museum
   of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C.
   20013-7012, USA, USA.
EM woodmann@si.edu
OI Woodman, Neal/0000-0003-2689-7373
SC Education &Educational Research; Zoology
SN 0006-324X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Synonymy; Animals and man;
   Education and entertainment
DE Cryptotis [Museums collections and exhibitions / Natural History Museum,
   London / Guatemalan specimens identification & nomenclature]. 
TN Chordates; Insectivores; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Insectivora, Soricidae
OR Blarina tropicalis - Merriam 1895 (Soricidae): [Nomenclature,
   Nomenclatural history & significance of NHM specimen, p. 252]. 
   Corsira tropicalis - Gray 1843 (Soricidae): [Nomenclature, Nomenclatural
   history & significance of NHM specimen, p. 250]. 
   Cryptotis (Soricidae). 
   Cryptotis merriami - Choate 1970 (Soricidae): [Diagnostic characters, P.
   255; Syn nov, Corsira tropicalis Gray 1843, p. 255]. 
   Cryptotis oreoryctes - Woodman 2011 (Soricidae): [Diagnostic characters,
   P. 255]. 
   Cryptotis tropicalis - (Merriam 1895) (Soricidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 255]. 
   Sorex micrurus - Tomes 1862 (Soricidae): [Nomenclature, Nomenclatural
   history & significance of NHM specimen, p. 251]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14810072919
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14810072923
DT Article
TI A new genus and species of unusual tern (Aves: Laridae: Anoinae) from
   the Middle Miocene Calvert Formation of Virginia.
AU Olson, Storrs L. (olsons@si.edu) 
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 124
IS 4
PS 270-279
PD 30 December 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Feducciavis loftini, new genus and species, is described from a single
   partial associated skeleton from the Middle Miocene Calvert Formation of
   Virginia. This bird was evidently most closely related to the noddy
   terns (Anoinae, Anous, Procelsterna). Compared with those genera, the
   tibiotarsus was much shorter and the ulna much longer in relation to the
   size of the humerus. The absolute size of the wing was considerably
   larger than in Anous stolidus, but the sternum was smaller. Aspects of
   the configuration of the quadrate and mandibular articulation are very
   distinct from any genus of modern gulls or terns, so that Feducciavis
   must have had singular feeding habits.
C1 Olson, Storrs L.; Department of Vertebrate Zoology, National Museum of
   Natural History, P.O. Box 30712, Division of Birds NHB MRC 116,
   Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C. 20013-7012, USA, USA.
EM olsons@si.edu
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0006-324X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Feducciavis [Miocene /  / New genus]. 
   Feducciavis loftini [Virginia /  / new species] [Miocene /  / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates

PT J
AN ZOOR14810072929
DT Article
TI Cambarus (Tubericambarus) stockeri (Decapoda: Cambaridae) a new species
   of plesiomorphic Cambarus from Georgia and Tennessee with zoogeographic
   affinity to Cambarus (Depressicambatus) cymatilis.
AU Thomas, Roger F.
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 124
IS 4
PS 318-325
PD 30 December 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species of crayfish, Cambarus (Tubericambarus) stockeri, is
   described from northern Georgia and southern Tennessee within the Ridge
   and Valley Physiographic Province of North America. Of the recognized
   members of the subgenus, it is the most physically divergent form
   discovered to date. It is easily distinguished from other recognized
   members of the subgenus, and all other members of the genus Cambarus
   Erichson 1846, by the extensive tuberculation of the chelae. Cambarus
   (T.) stockeri has tubercles over most of the dorsal and ventral chelae
   surface, a character state common in members of Procambarus Ortmann,
   1905b. This new species was frequently found in association with
   Cambarus (T.) acanthura, Hobbs, 1981 and Cambarus (Depressicambarus)
   cymatilis, Hobbs, 1970 and shares a close zoogeographic association with
   the latter species.
C1 Thomas, Roger F.; Department of Evolution, Ecology, and Organismal
   Biology, Museum of Biological Diversity, 1315 Kinnear Road, Columbus,
   Ohio 43212-1192, USA, USA.
SC Zoology
SN 0006-324X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA
DE Cambarus (Tubericambarus) stockeri [Georgia-USA /  / New species]
   [Tennessee /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Astacura
OR Cambarus (Tubericambarus) stockeri (Astacura): [Sp nov, Tennessee, P.
   319].

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Heterolaophonte Lang, 1948 (Copepoda:
   Harpacticoida: Laophontidae) from Maxwell Bay, King George Island,
   Antarctica.
AU Hyun Woo Bang
   Lee, Yoon (yoonlee@nfrdi.go.kr) 
   Lee, Woncheol
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 124
IS 4
PS 326-340
PD 30 December 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Heterolaophonte is described from tidal pools
   near the King Sejong Station at King George Island, Antarctica. This
   species is described and named as Heterolaophonte heejinae, new species.
   The new species is closely related to H. pauciseta from the South
   Georgia Islands and H. livingstoni from Livingston Island, Antarctica.
   Both species share several characters with the new species, including
   the seven-segmented antennule, segmentations of swimming legs and setal
   numbers on P5. However, the new species is distinguishable from its
   congeners with the combined characters of spinules on the terminal claw
   of the P1 endopod, the antennary exopod with only two setae, and the
   seta numbers on the second exopod segment of the P4 and the distal
   segment of the P2 endopod. A key to species of the genus Heterolaophonte
   is also provided.
C1 Lee, Yoon; West Sea Fisheries Research Institute, NFRDI, 707,
   Eulwang-dong, Jung-gu, Incheon 400-420, South Korea, South Korea.
EM yoonlee@nfrdi.go.kr
SC Zoology
SN 0006-324X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones
DE Heterolaophonte heejinae [Antarctic Ocean / South Shetland Islands / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Harpacticoida
OR Heterolaophonte - Lang 1948 (Harpacticoida): [Key to species, P. 338]. 
   Heterolaophonte heejinae (Harpacticoida): [Sp nov, South Shetland
   Islands (marine), P. 327].

PT J
AN ZOOR14810072940
DT Article
TI Two new species of Branchiosyllis (Polychaeta: Syllidae) from Western
   Mexico.
AU Gongora-Garza, G.
   Garcia-Garza, M.E.
   de Leon-Gonzalez, J.A. (jesus.deleongn@uanl.edu.mx) 
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 124
IS 4
PS 378-385
PD 30 December 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Branchiosyllis differs from other syllid genera by possessing
   claw-shaped falcigers. There are 18 valid species in the genus, but only
   five have been reported from Mexico: B. diazi Rioja, 1958, B. exilis
   (Gravier 1900), B. oculata Ehlers, 1887, B. pacifica Rioja, 1941, and B.
   salazari Ruiz-Ramirez&Harris, 2008. During diverse sampling campaigns
   along Western Mexico, specimens of two undescribed species were found.
   Branchiosyllis sanmartini, new species, was collected in La Paz Bay, in
   rocky bottoms. Its body is subcylindrical anteriorly, depressed in
   median and posterior regions, and with segments that are strongly
   pigmented black on the dorsal side. The palps are divided by a dorsal
   groove appearing bilobed; without branchiae; anterior parapodia with
   bidentate falcigers in dorsal position, ventral ones unidentate, in
   median parapodia all falcigers unidentate, posterior parapodia with
   claw-shaped falcigers. This species differs from all others in the genus
   due to its color pattern, the shape and distribution of falcigers along
   the body, the subcylindrical shape of the anterior end, and the
   dorsoventrally flattened shape of the middle and posterior region.
   Branchiosyllis riojai, new species, was collected in Phragmatopoma sp.
   beds in Manzanillo, Colima, and Maria Madre Island, Nayarit, among algae
   and sponges. This species has a cylindrical body, without color pattern;
   branchiae absent; bidentate dorsal falcigers on anterior and median
   parapodia; claw-shaped falcigers from median chaetigers. Branchiosyllis
   riojai has been reported for the Mexican Pacific as B. exilis (Gravier
   1900), described from the Red Sea, but it differs from the nominal
   species in falciger distribution along the body, shape of antennae,
   tentacular cirri and dorsal cirri, as well as in the number and shape of
   aciculae. A key to all species of Branchiosyllis from Mexican waters is
   included.
C1 de Leon-Gonzalez, J.A.; Universidad Autonoma de Nuevo Leon, Facultad de
   Ciencias Biologicas, Laboratorio de Biosistematica, Ap. Postal 5
   &quot;F&quot;, San Nicolas de los Garza, Nuevo Leon, 66451, Mexico,
   Mexico.
EM jesus.deleongn@uanl.edu.mx
RI Garza, Ma Elena Garcia/A-2441-2009; Garcia-Garza, Maria
   Elena/F-3465-2019
OI Garza, Ma Elena Garcia/0000-0002-9022-2728; de Leon-Gonzalez, Jesus
   Angel/0000-0003-2314-240X
SC Zoology
SN 0006-324X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones;
   Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic; Pacific Ocean
DE Branchiosyllis [Gulf of Mexico / Mexico / Key to species] [North Pacific
   /  / ]. 
   Branchiosyllis riojai; Branchiosyllis sanmartini [North Pacific / Mexico
   / New species]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Polychaeta

   Mexico, Mexico & North Pacific, Mexico, P. 384]. 
   Branchiosyllis riojai (Polychaeta): [Sp nov, Mexico (marine), P. 382].

   380].

DT Article
TI Two new Neotropical species of Drosophila peruensis species group
   (Diptera, Drosophilidae).
AU Doege, Jonas S. (jsdoge@gmail.com) 
   Gottschalk, Marco S.
   Valente, Vera Lucia S.
SO Iheringia Serie Zoologia
VL 101
IS 4
PS 310-316
PD Dec 30 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Drosophila peruensis species group was recently proposed and
   includes four taxa: D. atalaia Vilela&Sene, 1982, D. boraceia
   Vilela&Val, 2004, D. pauliceia Ratcov&Vilela, 2007, and D. peruensis
   Wheeler, 1959. All these species have most of setae or setulae of
   mesonotum arinsing from dark spots, wings with crossveins darker (except
   in D. atalaia) and hypandrium squared-shaped mostly fused to gonopods.
   Here, we describe two new species, Drosophila itacorubi sp. nov. and
   Drosophila paraitacorubi sp. nov., belonging to this species group. The
   male genitalia of these species are figured. An identification key to
   the D. peruensis species group is provided.
C1 Doege, Jonas S.; Univ Brasilia UnB, Programa Posgrad Ecol, Campus Darcy
   Ribeiro, Brasilia, DF, BR-70910900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM jsdoge@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0073-4721

   Neotropical region; South America

   species].

   Drosophilidae

   Drosophila paraitacorubi (Drosophilidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 312]. 
   Drosophila peruensis species group (Drosophilidae): [Key to species, P.
   315].

PT J
AN ZOOR14805038595
DT Article
TI Two new species of the Drosophila onychophora species group (Diptera,
   Drosophilidae) in the Polylepis forest of Papallacta, Pichincha,
   Ecuador.
FT Dos nuevas especies del grupo Drosophila onychophora (Diptera,
   Drosophilidae) en los bosques de Polylepis de Papallacta, Pichincha,
   Ecuador.
AU Luna Figuero, Maria (lunaf3@hotmail.com) 
   Rafael, Violeta
SO Iheringia Serie Zoologia
VL 101
IS 4
PS 343-349
PD Dec 30 2011
PY 2011
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species of the Drosophila Onychophora species group (Diptera,
   Drosophilidae) in the Polylepis forest of Papallacta, Pichincha,
   Ecuador. Despite being a relatively small country, Ecuador has a variety
   of ecosystems that has favored high speciation levels. One of these
   ecosystems is the high-altitude Polylepis forests. In these forests,
   there is great plant diversity including Asteraceae, which host a
   plethora of insects in their flowers, among which one can find species
   from the Drosophila Onychophora species group. In this study, we
   describe two new species of Drosophila collected in a remnant of
   Polylepis pauta in the Paramo of Papallacta at 4000 m. Both species
   belong to the D. Onychophora group: Drosophila yurag sp. nov. and
   Drosophila yuragshina sp. nov. The two species have elongated aedeagus
   that are typical of the group. Morphologically both species are very
   similar; the easiest way to distinguish them is by observing their
   wings.
C1 Luna Figuero, Maria; Pontificia Univ Catolica Ecuador, Lab Genet Evolut,
   Quito, 17012184, Ecuador, Ecuador.
EM lunaf3@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0073-4721
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Drosophila (Drosophila) yurag; Drosophila (Drosophila) yuragshina
   [Ecuador /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Drosophilidae
OR Drosophila (Drosophila) yurag (Drosophilidae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P.
   344].

   345].

TI Revision of the Neotropical spider genus Berlandiella (Araneae,
   Philodromidae).
AU Lise, Arno Antonio (lisearno@pucrs.br) 
   Cruz da Silva, Estevam L.
SO Iheringia Serie Zoologia
VL 101
IS 4
PS 350-371
PD Dec 30 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The spider genus Berlandiella Mello-Leitao, 1929 is revised and the
   three known species, Berlandiella insignis Mello-Leitao, 1929 (Rio de
   Janeiro), B. magna Mello-Leitao, 1929 (Pernambuco, Minas Gerais, Rio
   Grande do Sul), and B. polyacantha Mello-Leitao, 1929 (Rio de Janeiro,
   Sao Paulo), are redescribed and illustrated. Lectotypes for Berlandiella
   insignis, B. magna and B. polyacantha are designated. Descriptions and
   illustrations of three new species are presented: B. robertae sp. nov.
   (Brazil and Argentina), B. meridionalis sp. nov. (Brazil) and B.
   querencia sp. nov. (Brazil). The geographical distribution of the
   representatives of the genus is presented.

DT Article
TI New neotropical genus of Spintharinae (Araneae, Theridiidae).
FT Novo genero neotropical de Spintharinae (Araneae, Theridiidae).
AU Marques, Maria Aparecida L. (maria-marques@fzb.rs.gov.br) 
   Buckup, Erica Helena
   Lopes Rodrigues, Everton Nei
SO Iheringia Serie Zoologia
VL 101
IS 4
PS 372-381
PD Dec 30 2011
PY 2011
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 0
AB New neotropical genus of Spintharinae (Araneae, Theridiidae). Neopisinus
   gen. nov. is proposed on the type species Neopisinus fiapo sp. nov.,
   based on male and female specimens from Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil.
   Neopisinus differs from all Spintharinae by having the male palp with an
   enormous trifid conductor with two pointed structures and the third one
   apically bifurcated and by the characteristic shape of the theridioid
   tegular apophyses with a terminal and a dorsal lobes. The female
   genitalia has the inconspicuous opening anteriorly on a transversal
   sclerotized slit and internally a tubular longitudinal median
   thickening, where the copulatory ducts run in their initial trajectory.
   From northern Brazil, Neopisinus urucu sp. nov. is described based on
   both sexes. Seven species are transferred from Episinus to Neopisinus:
   N. bigibbosus (O. P.-Cambridge, 1896), N. bruneoviridis (Mello-Leitao,
   1948), N. cognatus (O. P.-Cambridge, 1893), N. gratiosus (Bryant, 1940),
   N. longipes (Keyserling, 1884), N. putus (O. P.-Cambridge, 1894) and N.
   recifensis (Levi, 1964). The male of N. longipes and the female of N.
   recifensis are described for the first time. New records and
   illustrations of N. bruneoviridis are provided.

AB Two new species of scale insects collected in Sardinia (Italy) are
   de-scribed and illustrated: Spinococcus giuliae sp. n. (Pseudococcidae)
   off the roots of Umbilicus rupestris (Crassulaceae) and Micrococcus
   sardous sp. n. (Micrococcidae) off the root of an undetermined grass
   (Poaceae) growing near the sea. An identification key to Micrococcus
   species and a revised list of the scales presently known in the island
   are also provided.

DT Article
TI Revision of the West-Palaearctic species of Pipizella Rondani, 1856
   (Diptera, Syrphidae).
AU van Steenis, Jeroen
   Lucas, Jan A.W.
SO Dipterists Digest Second Series
VL 18
IS 2
PS 127-180
PD 30 December 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The West-Palaearctic species of Pipizella are revised. Five new species,
   Pipixella ochreobasalis, P. vandergooti, P. orientalis, P. kuznetzori
   and P. obscura are described from the West-Palaearctic region. The new
   species are compared with related species. Pipizella certa Violositsh.
   scat. rev. is reinstated as valid taxon. Lectotypes arc designated for
   P. various (Rondani) and P. virens var. sacculata Becker. All known
   synonyms are given and the following new synonymies are established: P.
   campestris (Fallen) = P. viduata (Linnaeus), P. varians (Rondani) = P.
   maculipennis (Meigen), P. macrobasalis Lucas = P. calabra (Goeldlin de
   Tiefenau), and P. microupicalis Lucas = P. pennina (Goeldlin de
   Tiefenau). A key to the males, descriptions and drawings are provided
   for all species.
C1 van Steenis, Jeroen; Hof de Toekomst 48, NL-3823 HX Amersfoort,
   Netherlands, Netherlands.

   156]. 
   Pipizella - Rondani 1856 (Syrphidae): [Key to species, Palaearctic
   region, West, Males, p. 173]. 
   Pipizella brevis - Lucas 1976 (Syrphidae): [Removal from synonymy,
   Pipizella certa Violovitsch 1981, p. 149]. 
   Pipizella calabra - Goeldlin de Tiefenau 1974 (Syrphidae): [Syn nov,
   Pipizella macrobasalis Lucas 1976, p. 144]. 
   Pipizella certa - Violovitsch 1981 (Syrphidae): [Removal from synonymy,
   With Pipizella brevis Lucas 1976, p. 149].

PT J
AN ZOOR14802017303
DT Article
TI Contribution to the biology of the endangered Mexican fish, Zoogoneticus
   tequila, and suggestions for its indoor management.
AU Arbuatti, Alessio
   Trentini, Roberto
   Bernabo, Nicola
   Lucidi, Pia (plucidi@unite.it) 
SO AACL Bioflux
VL 4
IS 5
PS 670-683
PD December 30 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.bioflux.com.ro/
AW http://www.bioflux.com.ro/docs/2011.4.670-683.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The endangered Mexican fish, Zoogoneticus tequila Webb & Miller, 1998,
   represents a new challenge for scientists: its biology, quite unknown,
   could perhaps explain the reason for its extremely low consistency in
   natural environments. An experimental setting was prepared where four
   pairs of young Z. tequila from the only Italian colony were bred in two
   different (biotope and enriched) tanks. Breeding results showed that the
   animals have grown and presented a positive reproductive performance, in
   both the environmental conditions confirming that the choice of
   substrata, of the vegetable layout, of food administration and of
   breeding of fry, resulted optimal for the indoor breeding. Aggressive
   behavior was extremely low and, although inter-male interactions were
   unstable, no injuries were observed among the animals, apart from a few
   episode of cannibalism towards the young. The behavior of animals in
   stressful situation were also recorded, namely the encounter with a male
   displaying enhanced sexual characters or with a predator. The behavioral
   responses toward the male were mainly noticed in the enriched tank,
   where flicks of tail and display of fins were recorded compared to the
   biotope. On the other hand, the predator snake Thamnophis sp. elicited
   an innate flight response in both the experimental conditions and in
   both genders. All together those results seem to encourage the breeding
   of Z. tequila in captive condition, although more studies on the
   cognitive skills of the species are needed before its reintroduction in
   natural environment.
C1 Lucidi, Pia; Dep. Comparative Biomedical Science, School of Veterinary
   Medicine, Teramo, Italy, Italy.
EM plucidi@unite.it
SC Zoology; Biodiversity &Conservation; Environmental Sciences &Ecology;
   Behavioral Sciences
SN 1844-8143; 1844-9166
BD Conservation; Techniques; Behaviour
DE Zoogoneticus tequila [Conservation measures / Conservation biology &
   requirements / ] [Endangered status /  / ] [Care in captivity /  / ]
   [Behaviour /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cyprinodontiformes, Goodeidae
OR Zoogoneticus tequila (Goodeidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14802017303
DA 2020-09-17
ER

TI Physa mezzalirai, a new cretaceous basommatophoran from Adamantina
   formation, Brazil.
AU Ghilardi, Renato P. (ghilardi@fc.unesp.br) 
   Carbonaro, Fabio A.
   Simone, Luiz Ricardo L.
SO Strombus
VL 18
IS 1-2
PS 7-9
PD December 29 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper deals with a formal description of Physa mezzalirai
   (Basommatophora, Physidae), a new species of freshwater gastropod that
   lived in upper Cretaceous deposits, in sand-silty beds of Adamantina
   formation, Bauru basin, from Marlia, Sao Paulo state, Brazil. This
   formal description legitimates the availability of the name previously
   described in 2010 by same authors; being this paper the correct citation
   for the species name.

DT Article
TI New taxa in the genus Dirphiopsis Bouvier, 1928 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
FT Neue Arten der Gattung Dirphiopsis Bouvier, 1928 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (R.Brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 4
IS 5
PS 72-80
PD 29 Dezember 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Five new species in the genus Dirphiopsis Bouv1ER, 1928 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) are described and figured: four from Peru, D. amamartiniana
   n. sp. (San Martin and Amazonas departments), D. cuscoensis n. sp
   (Cusco), D. unicarpishiana n. sp. (Huanuco) and D. unipascoensis n. sp.
   (Pasco), and D. rotenbergi n. sp. from Venezuela (Barinas, Merida). All
   holotypes (ex coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP) or Frank MEISTER,
   Prenzlau (CFMP)) are in CRBP in coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany),
   which later, together with this collection, will be included in
   Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen, Munich, Germany. The preimaginal
   instars of the new species are unknown. In addition, D. orientalis
   LEMAIRE, 1976 stat nov., originally described as a subspecies of D.
   flora (SCHAUS, 1911) and following synonymized with this taxon by
   LEMAIRE (2002) is now released from D. flora and treated in full species
   rank.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.

AN ZOOR14803021123
PM 21764218
DT Article
TI Occurrence of blood-borne tick-transmitted parasites in common tsessebe
   (Damaliscus lunatus) antelope in Northern Cape Province, South Africa.
AU Brothers, P.S.
   Collins, N.E.
   Oosthuizen, M.C.
   Bhoora, R.
   Troskie, M.
   Penzhorn, B.L. (banie.penzhorn@up.ac.za) 
SO Veterinary Parasitology
VL 183
IS 1-2
PS 160-165
PD December 29 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 1
U2 15
AB Blood samples were collected from 71 tsessebes relocated from the
   deproclaimed Vaalbos National Park to Mokala National Park, South
   Africa. DNA was extracted from the samples and the reverse line blot
   (RLB) hybridization technique was used to detect and identify any
   haemoparasites present. Six samples hybridized to the Theileria/Babesia
   genus-specific probe, the Theileria genus-specific probe and the
   Theileria sp. (sable) probe, while 3/6 also hybridized to the Theileria
   separata probe. Full-length 18S rRNA genes of the Theileria spp.
   detected were amplified, cloned and sequenced. Two novel Theileria 18S
   rRNA gene sequences were identified which are phylogenetically very
   closely related to both Theileria sp. (sable) and T. separata. All
   animals appeared to be in good health. It seems likely, therefore, that
   these Theileria spp. do not cause disease under normal circumstances.
   Nevertheless, care should be taken when translocating wild animals, as
   introduction of novel piroplasm parasites into new areas could cause
   clinical disease and losses in naive wildlife and domestic animals, and
   new parasite species could become established in areas in which they
   previously did not occur. [copyright] 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights
   reserved.
C1 Penzhorn, B.L.; Department of Veterinary Tropical Diseases, Faculty of
   Veterinary Science, University of Pretoria, Private Bag X04,
   Onderstepoort 0110, South Africa, South Africa.
EM banie.penzhorn@up.ac.za
RI Collins, Nicola/O-6342-2014; Oosthuizen, Marinda C/N-8706-2014;
   Penzhorn, Banie L/J-7222-2013
OI Collins, Nicola/0000-0001-7296-3912; Bhoora, Raksha/0000-0003-2377-2735;
   Penzhorn, Barend (Banie)/0000-0001-6935-5545; Troskie,
   Milana/0000-0002-0762-0371; Oosthuizen, Marinda/0000-0002-1893-0818
SC Biodiversity &Conservation; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology;
   Parasitology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 0304-4017
BD Conservation; Conservation measures; Genetics; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Damaliscus lunatus [Release and relocation programmes / Parasite
   translocation with host / ] [Protozoan parasites / Theileria / ] [South
   Africa / Northern Cape, Mokala National Park / ]. 
   Theileria [Molecular genetics / 18S rRNA gene sequences / parasite
   translocation with host] [Mammalian hosts / Damaliscus lunatus / ]
   [South Africa / Northern Cape, Mokala National Park / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Protozoans; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Artiodactyla, Bovidae,
   Protozoa, Apicomplexa, Sporozoea, Piroplasmia
OR Damaliscus lunatus (Bovidae): [Host]. 
   Theileria (Piroplasmia): [Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14803021123
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14802017142
DT Article
TI Oxycarenus pallens (H.-S.) in Van Province (East Turkey) (Hemiptera,
   Lygaeidae).
AU Kemal, Muhabbet (muhabbet_kemal@yahoo.com.tr) 
   Bakan, Buket
SO CESA News
VL 71
PS 1-6
PD 29 December 2011
PY 2011
UR http://ia600804.us.archive.org/24/items/CentreForEntomologicalStudiesAnk
   araCesaNewsNr.71/CesaNews71.pdf
AW http://ia600804.us.archive.org/24/items/CentreForEntomologicalStudiesAnk
   araCesaNewsNr.71/CesaNews71.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This short paper deals with the first reliable record of Oxycarenus
   pallens (H.-S.) in Van Province (East Turkey). Hibernated individuals
   were found among the leaves of Verbascum sp. (Scrophulariaceae) in the
   steppe vegetation on 23 January 2011. The species and some predators are
   illustrated in nature. Distributional maps of the species are given.

   amazhorca BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Peru (Amazonas)), D. riojhorca
   BRECIILIrr & MEISTER n. sp. (Peru (San Martin)), D. tolimafurca BRECHLIN
   & MEISTER n. sp. (Colombia (Tolima)), D. apeggyae BRECHLIN, MEISTER &
   KACH n. sp. (Ecuador (Pichincha)), D. pastazana BRECHLIN, MEISTER & KACH
   n. sp. (Ecuador (Pastaza)), D. aculecuatoriana BRECHLIN, MEISTER & KACH
   n. sp. (Ecuador (Pastaza)), D. fabiani BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Peru
   (Junin)), D. schmiti BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Bolivia (Santa Cruz))
   and D. lapaziana BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Bolivia (La Paz)). All
   holotypes (ex coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP) or Frank MEISTER,
   Prenzlau (CFMP)) are in CRBP in coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany),
   which later, together with this collection, will be included in
   Zoologische Staatssammlungen Munchen, Munich, Germany. The preimaginal
   instars of the new species are unknown. In addition, D. nora (DRUCE,
   1897) stat. rev. and D. triangulum WALTZER, 1855 stat rev. are removed
   from synonymy with D. avia (STOLL, 1780) and reinstated to species rank.
   Furthermore, D. confluens Bouv1ER, 1930 stat rev., currently treated as
   a subspecies of D. somniculosa (CRAMER, 1777), is raised to species
   status.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.
