TI New taxa in the genus Pseudodirphia BOUVIER, 1928 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
FT Neue Taxa der Gattung Pseudodirphia BOUVIER, 1928 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (R.Brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 4
IS 5
PS 30-71
PD 29 Dezember 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Thirty-seven new taxa in the genus Pseudodirphia Bouvmt, 1928
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae) are described and figured (names are followed
   by the type locality in the format: country (province/department/state):
   P. nicjunensis BRECHLIN & MEIS'u n n. sp. (Peru (Junin)), P.
   nicamazonica BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Peru (Amazonas)), P.
   birejunensis BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Peru (Junin)), P. birepascoensis
   BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Peru (Pasco)), P. obeuanucensis BRECHLIN &
   MEISTER n. sp. (Peru (Huanuco)), P. obmartiana BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp.
   (Peru (San Martin)), P. obecuatoriana BRECHLIN, MEISTER & KACH n. sp.
   (Ecuador (Zamora Chinchipe)), P. obguayana BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp.
   (French Guyana (Cayenne)), P. obbeniana BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp.
   (Bolivia (Beni)), P. bolivaria BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Venezuela
   (Bolivar)), P. draudtioides BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Peru (Cusco)), P.
   benicola BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Bolivia (Beni)), P. andicoloides
   BRECHLIN, MEISTER & KACH n. sp. (Ecuador (Sucumbios)), P. parfuscata
   BRECHLIN, MEISTER & KACH n. sp. (Ecuador (Napo)), P. napola BRECHLIN,
   MEISTER & KACH n. sp. (Ecuador (Napo)), P. zamorcola BRECHLIN, MEISTER &
   KACH n. sp. (Ecuador (Zamora Chinchipe)), P. pascola BRECHLIN & MEISTER
   n. Sp. (Peru (Pasco)), P. dioscola BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Peru
   (Madre de Dios)), P. uniseptentrionalis BRECHLIN, MEISTER & KACH n. sp.
   (Ecuador (Zamora Chinchipe)), P. eupanamensis BRECHLIN & MEISTER Sp.
   (Panama (Panama)), P. beckei BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Venezuela
   (Bolivar)), P. lampei BRECHLIN, MEISTER & VAN SCHAYCK n. sp. (Paraguay
   (Concepcion)), P. svetlanae BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Bolivia (La
   Paz)), P. ecoridides BnncHu r, MEISTER & KACH n. sp. (Ecuador
   [Pastaza]), P. ecoccidides BRECHLIN, MEISTER & KACH n. sp. (Ecuador
   (Pichincha)), P. andides BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Peru (Cusco)), P.
   punodides Bnscm N & MEISTER n. sp. (Peru (Puno)), P. pascodides BRECHLIN
   & MEISTER n. sp. (Peru (Pasco)), P. septentrides BRECHLIN, MEISTER &
   KACH n. sp. (Ecuador (Sucumbios)), P. weberorum BRECHLIN, MEISTER & KACH
   n. sp. (Ecuador (Pichincha)), P. regia madriziana BRECHLIN & MEISTER n.
   ssp. (Nicaragua (Madriz)), P. reguayana BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp.
   (French Guyana (Cayenne)), P. purpurata BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp.
   (Bolivia (La Paz)), P. agandensis BRECHLIN, MEISTER & KACH n. sp.
   (Ecuador (Sucumbios)), P. agidiosiana BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Peru
   (Madre de Dios)), P. agiyungana BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Bolivia (La
   Paz)) and P. mexaustralica BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. (Mexico (Chiapas)).
   All holotypes (ex coll. Ronald Brechlin, Pasewalk (CRBP), Frank Meister,
   Prenzlau (CFMP) or Eric van Schayck (CEVS)) are in CRBP in coll. Museum
   WITT, Munich (Germany), which later, together with this collection, will
   be included in Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen, Munich, Germany.
   The preimaginal instars of the new species are unknown. In addition, P.
   draudti BOUVIER, 1935 stat. rev., P. convexa BOUVIER, 1929 stale rev.
   and P. angulata BOUVIER, 1929 stat. rev. are removed from synonymy with
   P. varia (WALKER, 1855), P. eumedide (STOLL, 1782) and P. agis (CRAMER,
   1775) respectively and reinstated to species rank. Following Article
   24.1. of the ICZN (1999), and thus in contrast to LEMAIRE (2002: 892),
   P. convexa stat. rev. is recognized and instated as having priority over
   P. peruviana var. concava BOUVIER, 1929 and with which (here following
   LEMAIRE 2002: 892) P. griseoalba BOUVIER, 1929 is a junior synonym.

DT Article
TI Revision of the Afrotropical species of the Philonthus circumcinctus
   species group (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Philonthina).
AU Hromadka, Lubomir (hrodmadkal@seznam.cz) 
SO Klapalekiana
VL 47
IS 3-4
PS 173-200
PD December 28 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Philonthus circumcinctus species group, containing 16 species of the
   genus Philonthus Stephens, 1829 is redefined and revised. Two species
   are described as new: Philonthus mehelya sp. nov. (Democratic Republic
   of the Congo) and P. zosterops sp. nov. (Kenya). Fourteen species are
   redescribed: P. bonus Tottenham, 1962, ;P. cailleuxi Levasseur, 1980, P.
   circumcinctus Eppelsheim, 1895, P. clementi Levasseur, 1962, P
   complicatus Tottenham, 1961, P. densecaudatus Bernhauer, 1928, P.
   densicauda Bernhauer, 1943, P. facialis Tottenham, 1962, P. fraxinatus
   Tottenham, 1949, P. mlogosiensis Bernhauer, 1934, P. rollei Bernhauer,
   1943, P. rubricatus Tottenham, 1962, P. staudingeri, Bernhauer, 1928. P.
   marginellus Schubert 1902, stat. restit. is removed from synonymy with
   P. xanthoraphis Eppelsheim, 1895. An identification key to all species
   of the species group is provided; the aedeagi of most species and
   relevant morphological characters are figured.
C1 Hromadka, Lubomir; Anny Letenske 7, CZ-120 00 Praha 2, Czech Republic,
   Czech Republic.
EM hrodmadkal@seznam.cz

DT Article
TI A recent record of the jewel beetle Cylindromorphus bohemicus
   (Coleoptera: Buprestidae) in the Central Bohemian region, and comments
   on its conservation.
FT Recentni nalez krasce Cylindrornorpluts bohemicus (Coleoptera:
   Buprestidae) na uzemi Stredoeeskeho kraje a poznamky k jeho ochrane.
AU Trnka, Filip (filip.trnka88@gmail.com) 
SO Klapalekiana
VL 47
IS 3-4
PS 259-260
PD December 28 2011
PY 2011
LA Czech
U1 0
U2 2
AB Cylindromorphus bohemicus Obenberger, 1933 is an endemic jewel beetle to
   the Czech Republic, listed on the Czech Red List of endangered
   invertebrates as critically endangered. Recently, it has been found only
   in north-eastern Bohemia (Zatec district), although until the 1970s it
   was also collected in two localities in central Bohemia [long dash]
   Praha-Troja (type locality) and Sedlecke skaly Nature Monument. In this
   paper, the recent occurrence of this species in central Bohemia is
   confirmed by a new record from Rortocky hdj [long dash] Tiche udoli
   Nature Reserve (Rortoky u Prahy). This new locality is a former pasture
   with sparse grassland dominated by fescue grasses (Festuca sp.), and
   seriously threatened by shrub and tree encroachment.
C1 Trnka, Filip; Katedra ekologie a zivotniho prostiedi, Piirodovedecka
   fakulta, Univerzita Palackeho v Olomouci, Tr-. Svobody 26, 771 46
   Olomouc, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM filip.trnka88@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Biodiversity &Conservation; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1210-6100
BD Conservation; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Europe
DE Cylindromorphus bohemicus [Endangered status / Critically endangered
   status / new record] [Zoogeography / Endemism / ] [Czech Republic /
   Central Bohemia / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Buprestoidea,
   Buprestidae
OR Cylindromorphus bohemicus (Buprestidae): [New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR14805037433
DT Article
TI The Malagasy Goblin Spiders of the New Genus Molotra (Araneae:
   Oonopidae).
AU Ubick, Barrell
   Griswold, Charles E.
SO American Museum Novitates
VL 3729
PS 1-69
PD December 28 2011
PY 2011
NT Unpaginated.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new oonopid genus endemic to Madagascar, Molotra, is proposed and its
   six included species are newly described and illustrated: M. molotra,
   the type species, M. ninae, M. katarinae, M. suzannae, M. tsingy, and M.
   milloti. Molotra is deined on the basis of its unusual genitalia. he
   male has the palpal bulb terminating in broad, liplike lobes, unlike any
   previously described in Oonopidae. he female is equally unusual in
   lacking an apparent receptaculum, although the genitalia otherwise
   resemble those of silhouettelloid genera. he species of Molotra form
   three distinct groups based on somatic and genitalic characters. he M.
   molotra group includes four large, strongly spined species. he remaining
   two are morphologically distinct and known only from males. M. tsingy is
   a small species with unusual palpi that are complex, contorted, and with
   a resting position along the sternocoxal boundary, instead of an
   anterior sternal cavity. M. milloti is a very bristly species that
   difers somatically from other Molotra but has genitalia similar to the
   M. molotra group. Molotra is known only from Madagascar where the three
   spe- cies groups are strongly disjunct. The M. molotra group occurs in
   higher elevation forests (1000[long dash]1300 m) in northeastern
   Madagascar, M. tsingy is from low elevation karst (150 m) of the
   southwest, whereas M. milloti is from a coastal locality in the
   northwest.
C1 Ubick, Barrell; Department of Entomology, California Academy of
   Sciences, San Francisco, California 94118, USA, USA.
SC Zoology
SN 0003-0082; 1937-352X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Molotra katarinae; Molotra milloti; Molotra molotra; Molotra ninae;
   Molotra suzannae; Molotra tsingy [Madagascar /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI Two Chloranthaceae leafminers of the genus Phyllocnistis (Lepidoptera:
   Gracillariidae: Phyllocnistinae) from Japan, with descriptions of new
   species and pupal morphology.
AU Kobayashi, Shigeki
   Hirowatari, Toshiya
SO Lepidoptera Science
VL 62
IS 4
PS 156-165
PD December 27 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new Chloranthaceae leafminer, Phyllocnistis shizukagozen sp. nov.
   (host plants: Chloranthus serratus, Sarcandra glabra) is described and
   P. chlorantica Seksjaeva, 1992 is newly recorded from Japan. Adult
   morphologies and life histories of the two Chloranthaceae mining species
   are described with photographs and illustrations. The pupal morphologies
   of the two species are described with the use of a scanning electron
   microscope. The two species have a type of mine which is new in the
   genus involving a change in the position of the mines, initially
   utilizing the lower (abaxial) epidermis, and, transferring via leaf
   tissue, later utilizing the upper (adaxial) epidermis; cocoons of the
   two species are spun on the lower epidermis.
C1 Kobayashi, Shigeki; Entomological laboratory, Graduate School of life &
   Environmental Sciences, Osaka Prefecture University, Sakai, Osaka,
   599-8531, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   leaf mining characteristics; new record; systematics] [Japan /  /
   biology].

TI A New Genus of African Loach Catfish (Siluriformes: Amphiliidae) from
   the Congo River Basin, the Sister-Group to All Other Genera of the
   Doumeinae, with the Description of Two New Species.
AU Ferraris, Carl J., Jr
   Vari, Richard P. (varir@si.edu) 
   Skelton, Paul H.
SO Copeia
VL 2011
IS 4
PS 477-489
PD Dec 27 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Congo River basin catfishes previously identified as Doumea alula
   (Amphillidae, Doumeinae) were found to include three species that belong
   not to the genus Doumea but are, instead, the sister-group to a clade
   formed by all remaining Doumeinae. The species are assigned to a new
   genus, Congoglanis. Characters delimiting the Doumeinae and the clade
   consisting of all members of the subfamily except Congoglank are
   detailed. Congoglanis alula is distributed throughout much of the Congo,
   River basin; C. Inga, new species, is known only from the lower Congo
   River in the vicinity of Inga Rapids; and C. sagitta, new species,
   occurs in the Lualaba River basin of Zambia in the southeastern portion
   of the Congo River system.
C1 Vari, Richard P.; Smithsonian Inst, Natl Museum Nat Hist, POB

TI A New Species of Deep-sea Ceratioid Anglerfish, Genus Himantolophus
   (Lophiiformes: Himantolophidae), from Southern Waters of All Three Major
   Oceans of the World.
AU Pietsch, Theodore W. (twp@uw.edu) 
   Kenaley, Christopher P.
SO Copeia
VL 2011
IS 4
PS 490-496
PD Dec 27 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB A new species of the deep-sea ceratioid anglerfish genus Himantolophus,
   long hidden within material identified as H. appelii Clarke, 1878, is
   described based on 43 female specimens collected in southern waters of
   all three major oceans of the world. A member of the H. appal group, it
   differs from its sister-species, H. appelli, the only other member of
   the group, in details of escal morphology. The two species are
   geographically sympatric over much of their range.

DT Article
TI A New Basal Ancistrini Genus and Species from the Andes of Northern Peru
   (Siluriformes: Loricariidae).
AU Lujan, Nathan K. (nklujan@gmail.com) 
   Armbruster, Jonathan W.
   Rengifo, Blanca
SO Copeia
VL 2011
IS 4
PS 497-502
PD Dec 27 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Etsaputu relictum, a new genus and species sister to all other
   Ancistrini, is described from the upper Maranon River in Northern Peru.
   Etsaputu relictum can be diagnosed from all other Hypostominae by having
   a coracoid with a serrated posterior margin of the posterior process, an
   opercle with a process extending ventrolaterally from the ventral
   margin, and branchiostegals one and two fused. Etsaputu rectum is
   further distinguished by having cheek plates evertible to less than 45
   from the sagittal plane, by having fewer than ten (typically zero or
   six) enlarged cheek-plate odontodes, by having enlarged cheek-plate
   odontodes straight and no longer than 15 times length of odontodes on
   lateral body plates, by having large eyes (mean 24.0% of head length,
   range 21.7-27.6% HL), and by having uniformly gold-brown to bronze base
   color with golden sheen when alive.
C1 Lujan, Nathan K.; Texas A&M Univ, Sect Ecol Evolut & Systemat Biol, 215
   Old Heep Hall,2258 TAMU, College Stn, TX, 77843, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI New Species of Steindachnerina (Characiformes: Curimatidae) from the Rio
   Tapajos, Brazil, and Review of the Genus in the Rio Tapajos and Rio
   Xingu Basins.
AU Netto-Ferreira, Andre L.
   Vari, Richard P. (varir@si.edu) 
SO Copeia
VL 2011
IS 4
PS 523-529
PD Dec 27 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB A new species of Steindachnerina, family Curimatidae, is described from
   the headwaters of the Rio Jamanxim in the central portion of the Rio
   Tapajos basin of the Brazilian Amazon. The species is distinguished from
   its congeners on the basis of pigmentation and various meristic and
   morphometric features. The phylogenetic placement of the new species
   within Steindachnerina is investigated, and notwithstanding the
   similarities in pigmentation patterns between that species and S.
   fasciata, those forms were not found to be closely related. The new
   species represents the first reported occurrence of a species of
   Steindachnerina within the Rio Tapajos, the fifth largest component of
   the Amazon. The occurrence of a second species of the genus, S.
   fasciata, in the Rio Teles Pires, another tributary of the Rio Tapajos
   basin is also documented. Steindachnerina brevipinna, a species
   widespread through major portions of the Rio de La Plata system, is
   confirmed to occur in the Rio Xingu of the Amazon basin.
C1 Vari, Richard P.; Smithsonian Inst, Natl Museum Nat Hist, MRC-159,POB
   37012, Washington, DC, 20013, USA, USA.
EM varir@si.edu
RI Netto-Ferreira, Andre/F-7018-2015
OI Netto-Ferreira, Andre/0000-0002-3096-0411

SN 0045-8511

   South America

   record]. 
   Steindachnerina seriata [Brazil /  / New species].

PM 22123974
DT Article
TI High-efficiency homologous recombination in the oil-producing alga
   Nannochloropsis sp.
AU Kilian, Oliver
   Benemann, Christina S.E.
   Niyogi, Krishna K. (niyogi@berkeley.edu) 
   Vick, Bertrand
SO Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of
   America
VL 108
IS 52
PS 21265-21269
PD Dec 27 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 2
U2 125
AB Algae have reemerged as potential next-generation feedstocks for
   biofuels, but strain improvement and progress in algal biology research
   have been limited by the lack of advanced molecular tools for most
   eukaryotic microalgae. Here we describe the development of an efficient
   transformation method for Nannochloropsis sp., a fast-growing,
   unicellular alga capable of accumulating large amounts of oil. Moreover,
   we provide additional evidence that Nannochloropsis is haploid, and we
   demonstrate that insertion of transformation constructs into the nuclear
   genome can occur by high-efficiency homologous recombination. As
   examples, we generated knockouts of the genes encoding nitrate reductase
   and nitrite reductase, resulting in strains that were unable to grow on
   nitrate and nitrate/nitrite, respectively. The application of homologous
   recombination in this industrially relevant alga has the potential to
   rapidly advance algal functional genomics and biotechnology.
C1 Niyogi, Krishna K.; Univ Calif Berkeley, Dept Plant & Microbial Biol,
   Berkeley, CA 94720, USA, USA.
EM niyogi@berkeley.edu
SC Zoology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 0027-8424
BD Animals and man; Genetics; Cytogenetics; Chromosomes
DE Nannochloropsis [Animals as tools / Potential new model species / ]
   [Recombination / Homologous recombination / ] [Karyotype / Haploidy / ].
   
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa
OR Nannochloropsis (Protozoa). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14803022579
OA Green Published, Bronze

DT Article
TI Description of a New Genus and New Species of Diaspididae (Hemiptera:
   Coccoidea) from Anhui Province, China.
AU Wu, Shi-jun
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 33
IS 4
PS 241-244
PD Dec 25 2011
PY 2011
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB One new genus and species are described based upon the materials
   collected from Anhui Province, China. All type specimens are deposited
   in the Anhui University of Technology, Ma'anshan. Mammilla, gen. nov.
   Type species: Mammilla jinzhaiensis, sp. nov. The new genus is close to
   Megacanthaspis Takagi, 1961 and Poliaspoides MacGillivray, 1921, but can
   be distinguished by lacking a perivulvar pore and having 4 microtubular
   duct groups in venter. It also differs from the other genus in this
   family by presence of the marginal mammilla spine. Mammilla
   jinzhaiensis, sp. nov. (Figs 1-16) Scales of females elongate 1.6-2.0 mm
   long, 0.6-0.7 mm wide. White in color, one exuviae apical, elliptical,
   pale yellow-brown. Body of the adult female elongate, pale yellow, about
   1.3-1.8 mm long, 0.4-0.5 mm wide, the apex of head somewhat sclerotized;
   margin and submargin of pygidium heavily sclerotized with radialized
   carinae mammary-like spine present along body margin. Dorsal surface:
   The dorsal ducts of one type, two-barred, arranged in rows in abdominal
   segments, irregular in the cephalo-thoracic region. Simple pores and
   minute setae sparse. Ventral surface: Antennae tubercular, with two long
   setaes and one short seta. Ventral ducts of two types: small ducts and
   minute ducts. Small ducts distributed in submargin, microducts numerous,
   forming 4 groups around anterior and posterior spiracular, and with
   irregular distribution on venter. Anterion and posterior the spiracular
   of near with quinquelocular pores 4-5, the dens of spiracular with
   quinquelocular pores 10-12. Apex of abdomen: The pygidial end
   subcircular, with a marked "[LAMBDA]"-like notch, each side of the notch
   with I pointed spine, 2 spines with round apex. Anal ring little and
   circular. With 2 minute setae located on the dorsum of the notch
   centered. Vulvar on the ventral surface of notch, without perivulvar
   pores. Holotype: [female], Jinzhai County, Anhui Province, China,
   18-VIII-2005, WU Shi-jun; Paratypes: 8[female], same data as the
   holotype.
C1 Wu, Shi-jun; Anhui Univ Technol, Maanshan, Anhui, 243000, China, China.
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7482
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Mammilla jinzhaiensis [Anhui /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha,
   Coccoidea
OR Mammilla (Coccoidea): [Gen nov, Of family Diaspididae, Type species
   Mammilla jinzhaiensis, p. 241]. 
   Mammilla jinzhaiensis (Coccoidea): [Sp nov, Anhui, P. 241].

TI A New Species of Emphytus Klug (Hymenoptera: Tenthredinidae) from
   Mountain Helanshan of Inner Mongolia.
AU Li, Ze-jian (weimc@126.com) 
   Xiao, Wei
   Wei, Mei-cai
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 33
IS 4
PS 312-316
PD Dec 25 2011
PY 2011
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Emphytus Klug of Allantinae is described from Mt.
   Helanshan of Inner Mongolia. A key to known species of Emphytus Klug
   from China is provided. The types are deposited in the Insect Collection
   of Central South University of Forestry and Technology. Emphytus
   helanshanicus Wei, Li&Xiao, sp. nov. (Figs. 1-9) Body length 8 mm. This
   species is similar to Emphytus nigrotibialis Rohwer, 1911 but differs
   from the latter in hind coxa entirely, the first trochanter of hind leg,
   tegula entirely black; the upper half of mesepisternum densely and
   coarsely punctured and rugose; malar space 0.80 times diameter of
   lateral ocellus; hind tibia longer than hind tarsus, sheath much longer
   than hind basitarsus; apical sheath distinctly longer than basal sheath;
   inner tooth of claw much shorter than outer tooth and distinctly
   divergent; penis valve; serrulae strongly protruding; annular spines
   bands broadly meeting at middle; apical corner of harpe round; valviceps
   of penis valve short and broad (In Emphytus nigrotibialis, the apical
   third of hind coxa and hind trochanter entirely white; the anterior
   third to half of tegula white; the lateral parts of the fifth abdominal
   tergite white; malar space 0.40 times diameter of lateral ocellus; the
   upper part of mesepisternum weakly punctured or entirely shiny; hind
   tibia as long as hind tarsus; sheath about as long as hind basitarsus,
   apical sheath almost as long as basal sheath; annular spine bands
   broadly separated; serrulae very small and short, hardly protruding;
   apical corner of harpe acute; valviceps of penis valve longer and
   narrower). Holotype: [female], Ganshuwan, Gulaben, Mt. Helanshan, Inner
   Mongolia, 38[degree]59.165[minute]N, 106[degree]02.255[minute]E, 2 300
   m, 28-VII-2010, LI Ze-jian, XUE Jun-zhe; paratype: 1[male], Xuelingzi,
   Yaoba, Mt. Helanshan, Inner Mongolia, 38[degree]40.311[minute]N,
   105[degree]50.582[minute]E, 2 260 m, 28-VII-2010, LI Ze-jian, XUE
   Jun-zhe.

DT Article
TI Morphological and morphometric characterization of a new digenetic
   trematode, Proenenterum sp.n., infecting the common sea bream Pagrus
   pagrus from the Red Sea in Egypt.
AU Morsy, Kareem (Kareemsaid156@yahoo.com) 
   El-Monem, Sayed Abd
   Bashtar, Abdel-Rahman
SO Journal of American Science
VL 7
IS 12
PS 262-267
PD December 25 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB In the present study, the morphology and morphometric characterization
   of Proenenterum sp. (family: Lepocreadiidae), a new digenetic trematode
   infecting the pyloric portion of the stomach and the middle part of the
   intestine of the common sea bream Pagrus pagrus fish, were described by
   light and scanning electron microscopy for the first time from the
   coasts of Gulf of Suez and Hurghada city of the Red Sea in Egypt.
   Numerous specimens were collected during the year of 2010. Out of 140,
   examined fish, only 46 (32.8%) were found to be naturally infected. The
   adult worms exhibited an elongated body with anterior pointed and
   posterior broad ends. The adult worm measured 2.30- 3.84 (mean 3.25[plus
   or minus]0.20) mm in length and 0.42- 0.54 (mean 0.48[plus or
   minus]0.02) mm in width. The present Proenenterum species is
   characterized by its smaller dimensions and the presence of a large
   ventral sucker, two lobed testes. The recorded parasite herein has the
   same general morphology of its family but with different characteristics
   than their members. The genus Proenenterum was included firstly within
   family Enenteridae but after that, it is separated from this genus as a
   separate family Lepocreadiidae due to the presence of distinct
   morphological criteria that specify organisms to be enenterids, these
   are presence of anal aperture, processes on oral suckers and an external
   seminal vesicle which are not present in the current study.
C1 Morsy, Kareem; Zoology Department, Faculty of Science, Cairo University,
   Cairo, Egypt, Egypt.
EM Kareemsaid156@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Anatomy &Morphology

   disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Marine zones; Indian
   Ocean; North Indian Ocean

   parasite systematics] [Red Sea / Egypt / ]. 
   Proenenterum sp. [Biometrics / Morphometrics / new record; systematics]
   [General morphology /  / ] [Piscean hosts / Pagrus pagrus / ] [Red Sea /
   Egypt / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14805032964
DT Article
TI Life cycle of Eimeria rousetti sp. nov. (Alveolata: Apicomplexa:
   Eimeriidae) infecting the frugivorous bat, Rousettus aegyptiacus
   Geoffroy, 1810 (Mammalia: Chiroptera: Pteropodidae) in Egypt.
AU Fayed, Hamed Mohamed (Kareemsaid156@yahoo.com) 
   Shazly, Mohamed Abd-Allah
   El-Monem, Sayed Abd
SO Journal of American Science
VL 7
IS 12
PS 292-305
PD December 25 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Developmental stages of the life cycle of Eimeria rousetti sp. nov. were
   described for the first time from the frugivorous bat, Rousettus
   aegyptiacus in Egypt. The infection rate was 32%. Oocysts were collected
   and identified from naturally infected bats. They were subspherical to
   ovoid in shape; measured 24.43 x 19.33 [mu]m and limited by a smooth
   colourless double-layered wall; no micropyle but a polar granule was
   observed. Events of sporulation were described and sporulation time was
   found to be 85-90 hrs. at 28[plus or minus]3[degree]C. An oocyst
   residuum was also observed. The sporocyst measured 11.34 x 6.62 [mu]m
   with sporocyst residuum; Stieda and substieda bodies were also observed.
   Experimental inoculation of sporulated oocysts was carried out and the
   developmental endogenous stages (merogony and gamogony) were followed up
   and described. The prepatent period was 4 days, while the patent period
   was 12-14 days. Merogony took place in the lamina propria and epithelial
   cells of the middle third of the small intestine of the experimentally
   infected bats at 25-60 hrs. p.i. Only one generation of meronts was
   observed. Early uninuclear meronts were seen 25-30 hrs. p.i. and
   measured 4.40 x 3.69 [mu]m, while the mature meronts measured 9.44 x
   7.10 [mu]m and contained 6-15 fully - differentiated merozoites.
   Gamogony occurred at 60-96 hrs. p.i. and took place at the same site.
   The microgamonts measured 8.60 x 6.62 [mu]m and contained 7-18 small
   nuclei. At the same time, macrogamonts measured 9.12 x 8.22 [mu]m, while
   mature macrogametes measured 10.25 x 9.68 [mu]m and contained 2 types of
   wall-forming bodies (types I&I I). At 90-96 hrs. p.i., newly-formed
   zygotes or young oocysts were observed in the epithelial cells of the
   experimentally infected bats. In the present study, fusion of the
   wall-forming bodies (types I&II) to produce the bilayered wall of the
   oocyst could be observed at the periphery.
C1 Fayed, Hamed Mohamed; Zoology Department, Faculty of Science, Cairo
   University, Egypt, Egypt.
EM Kareemsaid156@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1545-1003
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Africa
DE Eimeria rousetti [Mammalian hosts / Rousettus aegyptiacus / New parasite
   species] [Egypt /  / New species from mammalian host]. 
   Rousettus aegyptiacus [Protozoan parasites / Eimeria rousetti / New
   parasite species] [Egypt /  / New protozoan parasite species]. 
TN Bats; Chordates; Mammals; Protozoans; Vertebrates

DT Article
TI A New Subspecies of Darevskia raddei (Boettger, 1892) (Sauria:
   Lacertidae) from the West Azerbaijan Province, Iran.
AU Nasrullah, Rastegar-Pouyani (nasrullah.r@gmail.com) 
   Rasoul, Karamiani
   Hamzeh, Oraei
   Azar, Khosrawani
   Eskandar, Rastegar-Pouyani
SO Asian Herpetological Research
VL 2
IS 4
PS 216-222
PD Dec 25 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Based on extensive field work in the northern Zagros Mountains, a new
   subspecies of Darevskia raddei (Boettger, 1892) from the west Azerbaijan
   Province, northwestern Iran is described. The new subspecies is
   distinguishable from all the other three subspecies of D. raddei based
   on the combination of several distinguishing characters, such as dorsal
   body with 50-55 oval to round, smooth, or very weakly keeled, scales,
   25-31 scales across the gular region, 18-20 femoral pores on each side
   of body (reaching the knee), 29-31 tuberculate lamellae under the fourth
   toe, 11-12 supraciliaries, 9-11 collars and a specific color pattern.
   The new subspecies meets all the morphological characters described by
   Eiselt et al. (1993) for an undefined and intermediate form between D.
   raddei raddei in the east of and D. r. vanensis in the west of the
   distribution range of the species.
C1 Nasrullah, Rastegar-Pouyani; Razi Univ, Dept Biol, Kermanshah
   6714967346, Iran, Iran.
EM nasrullah.r@gmail.com
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Darevskia raddei chaldoranensis [Iran /  / New subspecies].

   Sauria, Lacertidae

DT Article
TI Two New Species and One New Record of Lonchoptera (Diptera:
   Lonchopteridae) from China.
AU Dong Qi-biao, Jia-hua (dyangcau@126.com) 
   Yang, Ding
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 33
IS 4
PS 267-272
PD Dec 25 2011
PY 2011
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species, Lonchoptera ciliosa, sp. nov. and L. multiseta, sp.
   nov., are described. L. nitidifrons Strobl is recorded from China for
   the first time. The types are deposited in the Entomological Museum of
   China Agricultural University, Beijing. 1. Lonchoptera ciliosa, sp. nov.
   (Figs. 1-7) The new species is somewhat similar to L. orientalis
   (Kertesz), but it can be separated from the latter by the mesonotum
   brown without stripes; pregonite weakly incised medially and hairy
   apically, and postgonite broad and sheet-like with narrower tip.
   Holotype: [male], Shanshuping (33[degree]13[minute]N,
   107[degree]34[minute]E), Changqing nature Reserve, Yangxian County,
   Shaanxi Province, 29-VII-2006, ZHU Ya-jun; Paratypes: 3[female], the
   same data as holotype. Etymology. The specific epithet name refers to
   the hairy apex of the pregonite. 2. Lonchoptera multiseta, sp. nov.
   (Figs. 8-16) The new species is somewhat similar to L. bifurcata
   (Fallen), but it can be separated from the latter by the halter dark
   brown, cercus longer than the epandrium and pregonite with two rows of
   rather long bristles at middle. Holotype: [male], Xinglong Mountain
   (35[degree]79[minute]N, 104[degree]07[minute]E), Yuzhong, Lanzhou City,
   Gansu Province, 21-VIII-2007, HUO Shan; Paratypes: 2[male], same data as
   holotype. Etymology. The new species is named for the pregonite having
   two rows of rather long bristles at middle.
C1 Dong Qi-biao, Jia-hua; Manzhouli Entry Exit Inspect & Quarantine Bur,
   Manzhouli, Inner Mongolia, 021400, China, China.

DT Article
TI PSEUDOATRYPA KESLINGI, A NEW MIDDLE DEVONIAN BRACHIOPOD FROM THE LONG
   LAKE LIMESTONE, ALPENA COUNTY, MICHIGAN, USA.
AU Jensen, Kevin
   Wicander, Reed
SO Contributions from the Museum of Paleontology University of Michigan
VL 32
IS 4
PS 49-58
PD December 23 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species, Pseudoatrypa keslingi, is described from the Middle
   Devonian Genshaw Member of the Long Lake Limestone, in Alpena County,
   Michigan. An abundant species in the Genshaw Member and Ferron Point
   Formation, P keslingi was originally illustrated in Ehlers and Kesling
   (1970) as Atrypa sp., but never formally named. A holotype and three
   paratypes are designated herein, and a complete description of the new
   species is given, based on 273 measured specimens from both the
   taxonomic collection and three stratigraphic collections in the
   University of Michigan Museum of Paleontology.

DT Article
TI An Early Cambrian stem polychaete with pygidial cirri.
AU Vinther, Jakob
   Eibye-Jacobsen, Danny (dejacobsen@snm.ku.dk) 
   Harper, David A.T.
SO Biology Letters
VL 7
IS 6
PS 929-932
PD Dec 23 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB The oldest annelid fossils are polychaetes from the Cambrian Period.
   They are representatives of the annelid stem group and thus vital in any
   discussion of how we polarize the evolution of the crown group. Here, we
   describe a fossil polychaete from the Early Cambrian Sirius Passet
   fauna, Pygocirrus butyricampum gen. et sp. nov., with structures
   identified as pygidial cirri, which are recorded for the first time from
   Cambrian annelids. The body is slender and has biramous parapodia with
   chaetae organized in laterally oriented bundles. The presence of
   pygidial cirri is one of the characters that hitherto has defined the
   annelid crown group, which diversified during the Cambrian-Ordovician
   transition. The newly described fossil shows that this character had
   already developed within the total group by the Early Cambrian.
C1 Eibye-Jacobsen, Danny; Univ Copenhagen, Zool Museum, Copenhagen,
   DK-1168, Denmark, Denmark.
EM dejacobsen@snm.ku.dk
RI Harper, David/AAX-7473-2020; Harper, David A.T./C-6888-2012;
   Eibye-Jacobsen, Danny/A-9223-2013
OI Harper, David/0000-0003-1315-9494; Harper, David
   A.T./0000-0003-1315-9494; Eibye-Jacobsen, Danny/0000-0002-7079-2627;
   Vinther, Jakob/0000-0002-3584-9616
SC Zoology
SN 1744-9561
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

   Pygocirrus butyricampum [Greenland /  / new species] [Cambrian /  / ].

   p. 929, Cambrian; Fossil].

   929; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Sorting out Lalos: description of new species and additional taxonomic
   data on megophryid frogs from northern Indochina (genus Leptolalax,
   Megophryidae, Anura).
AU Ohler, Annemarie
   Wollenberg, Katharina C.
   Grosjean, Stephane
   Hendrix, Ralf
   Vences, Miguel
   Ziegler, Thomas
   Dubois, Alain
SO Zootaxa
VL 3147
PS 1-83
PD 23 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03147p083.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03147p083.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Frogs in the subgenus Lalos of the genus Leptolalax (Megophryidae) are
   highly diversified in continental Asia and consist of about 17 nominal
   species. These frogs are small, inconspicuous, and of high superficial
   morphological similarity. We here formulate a hypothesis of phylogenetic
   relationships and assess the amount of genetic variation among
   genealogical lineages on the basis of 536bp of mitochondrial 16S rDNA
   sequences. Combining molecular data with a study of morphology,
   morphometric divergence and geographical proximity, we tested hypotheses
   of species identity. We (1) used character-based and morphometric
   analyses to assign the onymophoronts (type specimens) of species in
   Lalos available to us to respec- tively one of the main clades, in order
   to propose the best potential correct taxonomic and nomenclatural
   allocation for the individuals included in the molecular study, and (2)
   tried to also assign the historical museum specimens to these molecular
   taxonomic units and to reclassify them whenever necessary. We also used
   the molecular data to match tadpoles with adults and provide tadpole
   descriptions for species the larvae of which were previously unknown.
   Specimens, that could neither be allocated to a molecularly
   characterised species (on the basis of their DNA "barcode") nor to a
   morphologically defined species named on the basis of a type specimen,
   are described here as new species. Based on this integrative set of data
   and analyses we describe two new species, Leptolalax eos n. sp. and
   Leptolalax nyx n. sp., we resurrect Leptolalax minimus, and reassess the
   distribution of the species studied. We propose changes in the Red List
   status of L. pelodytoides and L. ventripunctatus and suggest a
   conservation status for the new species described herein.
C1 Ohler, Annemarie; UMR 7205 OSEB, Department de Systematique et Eolution,
   Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle, 25 rue Cuvier, CP 30, 75005 Paris,
   France, France.
SC Zoology; Biodiversity &Conservation; Environmental Sciences &Ecology;
   Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Key; Conservation; Biometrics; General morphology;
   Genetics; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Leptolalax (Lalos) [Conservation /  / systematics] [Biometrics /

   rDNA sequences / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Zoogeography / Biogeography / ]
   [Asia / Indochina, north / distribution; natural history]. 
   Leptolalax (Lalos) eos [Laos /  / New species].

   Pelobatidae

   Leptobrachium minimum - Taylor 1962 (Pelobatidae): [Referred to,
   Leptolalax (Lalos), p. 63].

PT J
AN ZOOR14802017083
DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Cyrtodactylus Gray, 1827 (Squamata: Gekkonidae) in
   Australia.
AU Shea, Glenn (glenn.shea@sydney.edu.au) 
   Couper, Patrick
   Worthington Wilmer, Jessica
   Amey, Andrew
SO Zootaxa
VL 3146
PS 1-63
PD 23 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt03146p063.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt03146p063.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The gekkonid lizard genus Cyrtodactylus in Australia is revised based on
   a combination of morphology and mitochondrial (ND2) sequence data.
   Previous hypotheses that the Australian populations are assignable to a
   New Guinea species, C. louisiadensis, or to a Cyrtodactylus
   louisiadensis species group defined on shared colour pattern and
   enlarged subcaudal scales, are rejected. Evidence is provided for the
   existence of five endemic species in Australia, allopatrically
   distributed. Cyrtodactylus tuberculatus (Lucas & Frost) is formally
   resurrected for Australian populations in the Cooktown area, from Mt
   Leswell north to Stanley Island. Four new species are described: C.
   mcdonaldi sp. nov. in the south, from the Chillagoe area north to Parrot
   Creek Falls, C. hoskini sp. nov. from the Iron Range area, C. adorus sp.
   nov. from the Pascoe River drainage, and C. pronarus sp. nov. from the
   McIlwraith Range. Concordant genetic and morphological evidence enable
   the hypothesis that C. adorus and C. pronarus represent a species pair
   distinct from the sublineage represented by C. tuberculatus, C.
   mcdonaldi and C. hoskini.
C1 Shea, Glenn; Faculty of Veterinary Science BO1, University of Sydney,
   NSW 2006, Australia, Australia.
EM glenn.shea@sydney.edu.au
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Genetics; Evolution;
   Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
DE Cyrtodactylus [Population genetics / Population genetic variation /
   taxonomic revision] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Australia /  / Key to species] [
   /  / ].

DT Article
TI Revison of the Lower Ordovician (lower Floian; Tulean) pliomerid
   trilobite Protopliomerella, with new species from the Great Basin,
   western USA.
AU McAdams, Neo E.B. (neo-buengermcadams@uiowa.edu) 
   Adrain, Jonathan M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3144
PS 1-113
PD 23 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03144p113.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03144p113.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB New field sampling of classic Ibexian sections in the Great Basin has
   resulted in the discovery of several new species assignable to the
   pliomerid trilobite genus Protopliomerella Harrington, 1957. The genus
   was originally monotypic and based on Protopliomerops contracta Ross,
   1951. Protopliomerella pauca Demeter, 1973, was later added, but it is
   shown herein to be a junior subjective synonym of P. contracta. The
   material originally assigned to Protopliomerella contracta by Ross
   belongs to as many as three distinct, stratigraphically separate
   species. New species include P. stegneri, P. bowlesi, P. kerouaci, P.
   seegeri, and P. okeeffeae. Two additional new species are not well
   enough known to name and are reported in open nomenclature. The
   phylogenetic status of Protopliomerella, as thus conceived, is ambiguous
   and the taxon may be rendered paraphyletic by the genera Pseudocybele
   Ross, 1951, and Lemureops McAdams and Adrain, 2009.
C1 McAdams, Neo E.B.; Department of Geoscience, University of Iowa, 121
   Trowbridge Hall, Iowa City, IA 52242, USA, USA.
EM neo-buengermcadams@uiowa.edu

   [Ordovician /  / ] [ /  / ].

DT Article
TI Parasites of animals in Papua New Guinea recorded at the National
   Veterinary Laboratory: a catalogue, historical review and
   zoogeographical affiliations.
AU Owen, Ifor L. (iowen@datec.net.pg) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3143
PS 1-163
PD 23 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03143p163.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03143p163.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB The catalogue includes more than 700 parasites of domestic and wild
   animals recorded at the National Veterinary Laboratory, Papua New
   Guinea, since data began to be gathered at the end of World War 2. It
   incorporates some information already published and data on parasites,
   particularly of indigenous fauna, not recorded previously in the
   country. Wildlife host species include wild pig, deer, bats, murine
   rodents, marsupials, monotremes, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fishes and
   invertebrates. The range of parasites in domestic and many wild animals
   shows great affinity with that found in Australia. Some notable
   exceptions amongst domestic animal parasites are the endoparasites
   Trichinella papuae, Capillaria papuen- sis and Mammomonogamus laryngeus
   and the economically significant ectoparasites Chrysomya bezziana,
   Tropilaelaps mercedesae and Varroa jacobsoni that are not recorded in
   Australia. Unusual host-parasite associations include the larvae of the
   insects Chrysomya spp. and Lucilia sp., parasites of warm-blooded
   animals, infesting, respectively, cold-blooded crocodiles and cane
   toads, and the mammalian mite, Sarcoptes scabiei, on an avian host,
   cassowaries. No host switching of helminths was seen between domestic
   and wild animals, or between populations of deer, wild pigs and
   wallabies when grazing together. The economic importance of certain
   parasites for domestic animals, the potential threats from introduced or
   newly-discovered parasites, and the relationship between some parasites
   and their wildlife hosts, are discussed. Information is presented in two
   tables: a parasite[long dash]host list that includes the location of a
   parasite in or on a host as well as a list of references of relevance to
   the country, and a host[long dash]parasite list that contains the
   distribution of the parasites ac- cording to province or locality.
C1 Owen, Ifor L.; National Veterinary Laboratory, National Agriculture
   Quarantine and Inspection Authority, PO Box 741, Port Moresby, Papua New
   Guinea, Papua New Guinea.
EM iowen@datec.net.pg
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Animals and man; Documentation; Publications; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Zoogeography; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia
DE Animalia [Organizations / National Veterinary Laboratory / historical
   review; host parasite list] [Catalogues / Catalogue of parasite records
   / ] [Parasites /  / ] [Hosts /  / ] [Zoogeography / Zoogeographical
   affiliations / ] [Papua New Guinea /  / ]. 
ST Animalia
OR Animalia: [Host, Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14802017085

DT Article
TI Sub-brachypterous Ricaniidae (Hemiptera: Fulgoromorpha) of Madagascar
   with morphological notes for these taxa.
AU Stroinski, Adam (adam@miiz.waw.pl) 
   Gnezdilov, Vladimir M.
   Bourgoin, Thierry
SO Zootaxa
VL 3145
PS 1-70
PD 23 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03145p070.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03145p070.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four new genera of sub-brachypterous Ricaniidae are described from
   Madagascar. Globularica gen. nov. is established for a single species,
   Globularica diversicolorata sp. nov. Coniunctivena gen. nov. is
   established for four species: Coni- unctivena antsignyensis sp. nov., C.
   epaulettea sp. nov. (type species), C. montuosa sp. nov., C. synavei sp.
   nov. Nasatus gen. nov. is established for two species: Nasatus sparsus
   sp. nov. (type species) and N. davidouvrardi sp. nov. Cyamosa gen. nov.
   is established for four species: Cyamosa adelinae sp. nov., C. camelouca
   sp. nov. (type species), C. pauliani sp. nov., C. splendens sp. nov.
   Isobium gibbosum Melichar, 1906 is redescribed and transferred from the
   Issidae to the Ricaniidae. Photographs, drawings and maps of
   distribution for all mentioned species are presented. Discussion is
   provided on antennal plate organs, tegminal sub-brachypterism, and
   female bursa copulatrix structure, for these sub-brachypterous
   Ricaniidae.

DT Article
TI Systematic revision of the family Kalliapseudidae (Crustacea:
   Tanaidacea).
AU Drumm, David T. (david.drumm@eagles.usm.edu) 
   Heard, Richard W.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3142
PS 1-172
PD 23 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03142p172.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03142p172.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Kalliapseudidae is a family of shallow burrow[long dash]dwelling and
   fossorial marine and estuarine tanaidaceans. There are currently 39
   known species in 12 genera and three subfamilies. They are distributed
   throughout the world's tropical, subtropical, and temperate coastal
   waters and, with a few known exceptions, are restricted to depths of
   less than 200 m. The phylogeny of Kalliapseudidae is assessed to test
   the monophyly of currently accepted subfamilies and genera, based
   largely on examination of material loaned from various museums and
   institutions. Multiple exemplars from other apseudomorph families were
   also included in the ingroup to test the monophyly of the family.
   Parsimony analyses included 41 terminal taxa and 64 binary and
   multistate morphological characters. Analyses based on successive
   weighting resulted in 20 most parsimonious trees. The strict consensus
   tree of these most parsimonious trees supported Kalliapseudidae,
   Kalliapseudinae, Tanapseudes, Cristapseudes, and Mesokalliapseudes as
   monophyletic. The genus Kalliapseudes could not be resolved, but
   constraining it to be monophyletic resulted in a significantly worse
   tree. The subfamilies Hemikalliapseudinae and Tanapseudinae were
   recovered as polyphyletic and paraphyletic, respectively, but without
   support. Constraining them to be monophyletic did not result in a
   significantly worse tree. Results indicated high levels of homoplasy in
   three morphological characteristics traditionally used to differentiate
   groups. Alokalliapseudes macsweenyi is transferred back to the genus
   Mesokalliapseudes, rendering Alokalliapseudes a junior subjective
   synonym. Nine new taxa, including six species of Kalliapseudes and one
   species of the genus Cristapseudes, and one new genus
   (Phoxokalliapseudes) and species (P. singaporensis) were discovered and
   described. Two species of Kalliapseudes (K. gobinae and K.
   multiarticulus) are transferred to Phoxokalliapseudes n. gen. Neotypes
   are designated for K. magnus, C. omercooperi and M. schubarti, and a
   lectotype is designated for K. mauritanicus. Distribution maps,
   illustrated keys to the subfamilies, genera and species, and preliminary
   remarks on biogeographic history are also presented.
C1 Drumm, David T.; Department of Coastal Sciences, The University of
   Southern Mississippi, 703 East Beach Dr., Ocean springs, MS 39564, USA,
   USA.
EM david.drumm@eagles.usm.edu
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Diagnosis; Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Key; Evolution; Zoogeography; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean;
   North Atlantic; Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean

DT Article
TI Two new species of Pentacentrus Saussure, 1878 from China (Orthoptera,
   Gryllidae, Pentacentrinae).
AU Liu, Hao-Yu
   Shi, Fu-Ming (shifmi@yahoo.com.cn) 
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 33
PS 3-7
PD December 22 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Pentacentrus Saussure, 1878 are described and
   illustrated, P. multicapillus sp. nov. and P. bituberus sp. nov. Both
   are located in Guangxi, China.
C1 Shi, Fu-Ming; College of Life Sciences, Hebei University, 071002
   Baoding, China, China.
EM shifmi@yahoo.com.cn

   Eurasia; Asia; China

PT J
AN ZOOR14807051962
DT Article
TI A new Platambus (s. str.) Thomson, 1859 species from Guangxi, China
   (Coleoptera, Dytiscidae).
AU Brancucci, Michel (michel.brancucci@unibas.ch) 
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 33
PS 9-13
PD December 22 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Platambus (s.str.) yuxiae sp.nov. is described from the Guangxi
   province, China. The species presents distinctive characters that can
   easily and without ambiguity distinguish it from all other known
   species. The relationships to other species are briefly discussed.
   Habitus and aedeagus are illustrated.
C1 Brancucci, Michel; Natural History Museum, Entomology, Augustinergasse
   2, CH-4001 Basel, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM michel.brancucci@unibas.ch
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Platambus (Platambus) yuxiae [Guangxi Zhuang /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Dytiscidae
OR Platambus (Platambus) yuxiae (Dytiscidae): [Sp nov, Guangxi Zhuang, P.
   10].

PT J
AN ZOOR14807051963
DT Article
TI Taxonomic revision of the genus Archidela Rivalier, 1963 (Coleoptera,
   Cicindelidae).
AU Moravec, Jiri (jirmor@quick.cz) 
   Brzoska, David
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 33
PS 15-37
PD December 22 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A taxonomic revision of the Australian tiger beetle genus Archidela
   Rivalier, 1963 is presented. As a result of the examination of relevant
   type specimens, as well as recently collected material, four species of
   the genus (originally described as Cicindela) are recognized by the
   authors: Archidela nigrina (Macleay, 1864), A. scitula (Sloane, 1909),
   A. rugosicollis (W. Horn, 1913) comb.nov. (based on Cicindela nigrina
   rugosicollis), and A. darwini (Sloane, 1909). The examination has
   confirmed the separate species status of A. scitula and A. rugosicollis,
   Lectotypes of Cicindela nigrina and C. darwini are designated. A short
   history of the genus Archidela, detailed redescriptions of the four
   species, as well as their biology and distributions are presented.
   Illustrations of diagnostic characters and habitus in colour photographs
   and line drawings are also provided.
C1 Moravec, Jiri; P.O.Box 17/A, 679 04 Adamov 1, Czech Republic, Czech
   Republic.
EM jirmor@quick.cz
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Description; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Australasian region
DE Archidela [Australasia /  / Biology; distribution; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Archidela - Rivalier 1963 (Carabidae): [Revision, P. 17; Key to species,
   P. 18]. 
   Archidela darwini - (Sloane 1909) (Carabidae): [Redescription, P. 33]. 
   Archidela nigrina - (Macleay 1864) (Carabidae): [Redescription, P. 19]. 
   Archidela rugosicollis - (Horn 1913) (Carabidae): [Redescription, P. 29;
   Comb nov, Transferred from Cicindela, p. 29]. 
   Archidela scitula - Sloane 1909 (Carabidae): [Redescription, P. 31]. 
   Cicindela darwini - Sloane 1909 (Carabidae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   33]. 
   Cicindela nigrina - Macleay 1864 (Carabidae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   19]. 
   Cicindela nigrina rugosicollis - Horn 1913 (Carabidae): [Referred to,
   Archidela, p. 29]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807051963
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14807051965
DT Article
TI A contribution to the genus Astylus Laporte de Castelnau, 1836, in
   Ecuador, with descriptions of three new species (Coleoptera, Melyridae).
AU Constantin, Robert (robert.constantin@aliceads1.fr) 
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 33
PS 39-61
PD December 22 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Three species of the genus Astylus in Ecuador are here described as new
   to science: A. lojaensis, sp.nov. (prov. Loja), A. longulus, sp. nov.
   (prov. Loja) and A. moreti, sp.nov. (prov. Azuay). The following new
   synonymies are established: Astylus curtus Pic, 1919, A. peruvianus Pic,
   1919 and A. punctatus Pic, 1919 are synonyms of A. bonplandi Erichson,
   1847; Astylus hourgeoisi var. quinquenotatus Pic, 1920, Astylus
   bourgeoisi var. irimaculataus Pic, 1920, Astylus cribrosus Pic, 1919 and
   Astylus riveti Bourgeois, 1911 are synonyms of A. bourgeoise Kirsch,
   1889; Astylus mutatus Pic, 1919 and A. mutatus var. subseparatus Pic,
   1920 are synonyms of A. pallipes Kirsch, 1889. Lectotypes are designated
   for Astylus rubripennis (Latreille, 1811) and A. bonplandi Erichson,
   1847. A key to differentiate the eleven Ecuadorian species of Astylus is
   provided, as are illustrations of the habitus of the new species, and
   details of the genital characters of all the species addressed. New
   faunistic data are also presented as maps of distribution in Ecuador.
C1 Constantin, Robert; 103 impasse de la Roquette, F-50000 Saint-Lo,
   France, France.
EM robert.constantin@aliceads1.fr
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Astylus [Ecuador /  / Key to species] [ /  / Distribution; systematics].
   
   Astylus lojaensis; Astylus longulus; Astylus moreti [Ecuador /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Cleroidea,
   Melyridae
OR Astylus - Laporte de Castelnau 1836 (Melyridae): [Revision, P. 44; Key
   to species, Ecuador, P. 44]. 
   Astylus bonplandi - Erichson 1847 (Melyridae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   45; Syn nov, Astylus curtus Pic 1919, p. 45; Syn nov, Astylus perforatus
   Pic 1919, p. 45; Syn nov, Astylus peruvianus Pic 1919, p. 45; Syn nov,
   Astylus punctatus Pic 1919, p. 45]. 
   Astylus bourgeoisi - Kirsch 1889 (Melyridae): [Syn nov, Astylus
   bourgeoisi var. quinquenotatus Pic 1920, p. 46; Syn nov, Astylus
   bourgeoisi var. trimaculatus Pic 1920, p. 46; Syn nov, Astylus cribosus
   Pic 1919, p. 46; Syn nov, Astylus riveti Bourgeois 1911, p. 46]. 
   Astylus lojaensis (Melyridae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 49]. 
   Astylus longulus (Melyridae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 48]. 
   Astylus moreti (Melyridae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 52]. 
   Astylus pallipes - Kirsch 1889 (Melyridae): [Syn nov, Astylus mutatus
   Pic 1919, p. 53; Syn nov, Astylus mutatus var. subseparatus Pic 1920, p.
   53]. 
   Astylus rubripennis - Latreille 1811 (Melyridae): [Redescription, P.
   56]. 
   Astylus sexpustulatus - Champion 1918 (Melyridae): [Redescription, P.

PT J
AN ZOOR14807051966
DT Article
TI Classification, natural history, and evolution of Epiphloeinae
   (Coleoptera, Cleridae) Part IX. The genus Megaphloeus Opitz, 2010.
AU Opitz, Weston (opitz@kwu.edu) 
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 33
PS 63-132
PD December 22 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This treatise involves intergeneric relationships among Opitzius Barr,
   Epiphloeus Spinola, and oeus Opitz. For the most part, it is a work that
   brings together a number of epiphloeines that were classified under
   Epiphloeus Kuwert; as listed in the Corporaal catalogue published in
   1950. Twenty-six species comprise Megaphloeus Opitz, of which 12 were
   previously described: M. animosus (Wolcott) (type locality: Costa Rica,
   Turrialba), M. lividipes (Chevrolat) (type locality: Venezuela), M.
   marginipes (Chevrolat) locality: Mexico, Cordoba), M. mucoreus (Klug)
   (type locality: Brazil), M. nubilus (Klug) (type locality: Brazil), M.
   parrulus (Schenkling) (type locality: Brazil, Goyas), M. setulosus
   Thomson (type locality: Mexico), M. sexplagiatus (Kuwert) (type
   locality: Peru, Amazonas), M. terzonattes (Gorham) (type locality:
   Brazil, Ega), M. tricolor (Kuwert) (type locality: Brazil, Amazonas), M.
   velutinus (Gorham) (type locality: Brazil, Amazonas), M. variegatus
   (Klug) (type locality: Brazil, Para). The following new species are
   included Megaphloeus Opitz: M. absentis (type locality: Mexico, Puebla,
   4.6 km E. Teziutlan), M. bulatus (type locality: Costa Rica, Puntarenas,
   Est. Aguhas), M. cartus (type locality: Belize, Orange Walk, Rio Bravo
   construction area. LaMilpa), .14. circinus (type locality: Colombia,
   Vaupes, R.N. Mosiro-Itajura, Caparu, Centro Abiental), M. fucoaquilus
   (type locality: Brazil, Rondonia, 62 km SE Ariquemes), M. longius (type
   locality: Honduras, Olancho, P.N. La Muralla), M. megasensibilis (type
   locality: Brazil, Rondonia, 62 km SE Ariquemes). M. pectilis (type
   locality: Guyana, Region 8, lwokrama Forest, I km W Kurupukari, Iwokrama
   Field Station), M. platyglenus (type locality: Ecuador, Orellana, 1km S
   Onkone Gare Camp.), M. rictocaliginus (type locality: Brazil, Rondonia,
   62 km SE Ariquemes), M. tigrinus (type locality: Colombia, Putumayo, PNN
   LaPaya Fea Charapa), M. ustafinis (type locality: Brazil, Mato Grosso,
   Sinop), M. ustus (type locality: Brazil, Nova Teutonia), and M.
   vitellinus (type locality: Brazil, Amazonia). Eleven new synonymies are
   established in this work: Synonymized under Megaphloeus mucoreus (Klug)
   are Enoplium fasciatum Klug, Epiphloeus balteatus Chevrolat, Epiphloeus
   tomentosus Spinola, and Epiphloeus bakeri Wolcott; under M setulosus
   (Thomson), Epiphloeus debilis Kuwert and Epiphloeus obscurus; under M.
   tricolor (Kuwert), Epiphloeus micaceus Chapin; under M. velutinus,
   Epiphloeus tibialis Kuwert, and under Enoplium variegatum Klug,
   Epiphloeus omegas Spinola, Epiphloeus buquetii Spinola, and Phyllobaenus
   manni Wolcott. Nine lectotypes lave been designated; they involve
   Epiphloeus lividipes Chevrolat, Epiphloeus marginipes Chevrolat,
   Enoplium mucorecan Klug, Epiphloeus parvulus Schenkling, Epiphloeus
   setulosus Thomson, Epiphloeus terzonatus Gorham, Epiphloeus tricolor
   Kuwert, Enoplium variegatum Klug, and Epiphloeus velutinus Gorham.
   Megaphloeines are arbophilic insects involved in tritrophic interactions
   along with host plants and bark beetles. Evidence suggests that
   Megaphloeus beetles have a kaironomal response to bark beetle aggregate
   pheromones and host tree terpines. Specimens have been collected in
   flight intercept traps laced with ethanol, or mixtures involving
   sulcatol-ethanol and a-pinine+ethanol in forests laden with Eucalyptus
   grandis W. Hill ex Maid, Araucaria angustifolia (Bertol.) Kuntze, Pints
   taeda Linnaeus, or Pinus caribaea Morelet v. hondurensis. Megaphloeus
   beetles were collected throughout the year in tropical and subtropical
   zones at altitudes ranging from 10 to 1850 m. What distinguishes
   Megaphloeus among other epiphloeines is that the phallic apex is large
   and triangular. Distributional evidence suggests that ancestral
   Megaphloeus originated in South America and perhaps in environs of the
   Andes or lowland Amazonia. Decendants dispersed northwestward to enter
   Middle America after closures of the portals of insular Central America.
   A matrix of 26 character states was analyzed, manually and with
   Winclada. The two analyses yielded two very similar proposals of
   intergeneric and megaphloean interspecies groups phylogenies. It is
   postulated that Megaphloeus Opitz is the sister taxon of a lineage that
   eventually produced members of genera Opitzius Barr and Epiphloeus
   Spinola. In addition to the conventional taxonomic sections, included in
   this treatise is a Spanish translation of the abstract and of a key to
   species groups and species. Included are 104 line drawings, two habitus
   illustrations, eight electron micrographs, 11 distributional maps, two
   phylogenetic trees, a matrix of 26 character states, and a table showing
   the distribution of Megaphloeus Opitz species groups among montane and
   lowland refugia of Middle and South America.
C1 Opitz, Weston; Kansas Wesleyan University, Department of Biology, 100
   East Claflin Avenue, Salina, KS 67401-6196, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI Classification, natural history, and evolution of Epiphloeinae
   (Coleoptera, Cleridae) part x. The genus Madoniella Pic, 1935.
AU Opitz, Weston (opitz@kwu.edu) 
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 33
PS 133-248
PD December 22 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This treatise involves the genus Madoniella Pic described in 1935 to
   accommodate two species. Herein, the genus is expanded to include 74
   species, 65 of which are new. The previously described species with
   their type localities are Madoniella bilineata Chevrolat (Cuba), M.
   corporaali Pic (Lesser Antilles: Guadeloupe: Trois Rivieres), M.
   dislocata (Say) (USA: Georgia: Clark Co., Whitehall Forest), M.
   erythrocephala (Gorham) (Panama: Chiriqui: Volcan de Chiriqui), M. minor
   Pic (Lesser Antilles: Guadeloupe), M. nebulosa (Chevrolat) (Greater
   Antilles: Cuba), M. orientalis Zayas (Greater Antilles: Cuba), M. pici
   Lepesme (Lesser Antilles: Guadeloupe: Trois Rivieres), M. punctata
   (Gorham) (Guatemala, El Quinche: Quinche Mountains). The 65 new species
   included in this work and their type localities are M. abacula (Mexico:
   Oaxaca: 14 km NW Diaz Ordaz), M.adona (Dominican Republic: Mt. Diego de
   Ocampo), M. aktis (Mexico: Chiapas: 11.2 km SE Simojovel), M. anapsis
   (Dominica: 8 km E Dublanc), M. antennatra (Honduras: Yoro: Pico Pijol),
   M. apotoma (Honduras: Comayagua: 11.2 km E Siguatepeque), M. apsis
   (Mexico: Chiapas: El Aguacero), M. avina (Argentina: Salta: El Rey
   National Park), M. hasilaris (Dominican Republic: La Vega: 1 km NW
   Manaboa), M. basilic (Cuba: Loma, Pico del Cato). M. bullalis (Dominican
   Republic: Monte Cristi: 8.6 km N Villa Elisa), M. cardinalis (Costa
   Rica: Heredia: Estacion Biologia La Selva), M. careorita (Costa Rica:
   Heredia; Estacion Biologia La Selva), M. cavina (Dominican Republic:
   Pedernales: 23.5 km N Cabo Rojo), Al cerviculina (Dominican Republic:
   Pedemales: 3.3 km NE Los Arroyos), M. chiricahua (USA: Arizona: Cochise
   Co., Chiricahua Mountains), M. collata (Brazil: Chapala), M. cracentis
   (Brazil: Amazonas: 1 km W Taruma Falls), M. crinis (Mexico: Tlaxcala:
   San Francisco Temetzontla), M. cymatilis (Haiti: Du Nord: Cap Haitien),
   M. dariensis (Panama: Darien: Pire, Estacion Rancho Frio). Al. disjuga
   (Mexico: San Luis Potosi: 40 km W Xilitla), M. displicata (Venezuela:
   Aragua: Ocumare), M. ebena (Dominican Republic: La Romana: Hato Major),
   M. emblema (Costa Rica: Heredia; 11 km SE La Virgen), M. estensiva
   (Puerto Rico: Maricao Forest), M. facis (Guyana: Iwokrama Research
   Forest, 6.4 km N of Kurupukari), M. fonteboa (Brazil: Amazonas:
   Fonteboa), M. gonia (Mexico: Durango: 4.8 km E El Salto), M. guana
   (British Virgin Islands: Guana island), M. howdenorum (Mexico: Chiapas:
   2.6-6 km S La Trinitaria), M. ignis (Guatemala: Zacapa: San Lorenzo), M.
   infula (Dominican Republic: La Vega: Cordillera Central, 4.1 km SW El
   Convento), M. insignis (Brazil: Bahia: San Antonio da Barra), M.
   knullorum (USA: Texas: Jeff Davis Co, Davis Mountains), M. kuehlorum
   (Nicaragua: Matagalpa: 10 km NW Matagalpa), M. latinopsis (Venezuela:
   Aragua: El. Limon), M. leona (Mexico: Nuevo Leon: 14.4 km W Iturbide),
   M. lica (Jamaica: Hardwar Gap), M. linea (Guatemala; San Lorenzo: 2 km S
   San Lorenzo), M. lurida (Dominican Republic: Pedernales: La Abeja), M.
   magdalena (Colombia: Magdalena: Tayrona Pueblito), M. maxicornis
   (Mexico: Veracruz), M. melina (Honduras: Yoro: 8 km N La Habana), M.
   merga (Mexico: Durango: 12.5 W El Salto), M. nana (USA: Texas: Cameron
   Co. Sabal Palm Grove), M. orosiensis (Costa Rica: Guanacaste: Volcan
   Orosi), M. pumilis (Mexico: Chiapas: 54 km S Ocosingo), M. pedalis
   (Cuba: Cayamas), M pellis (Cuba: Holguin: Sierra de Nipe), M.
   peninsularis (Mexico: Baja California: Cabo San Lucas), M. pinicola
   (USA: Arizona: Cochise Co., Chiricahua Mountains), M. plenita (Costa
   Rica: Cartago: Turrialba), M. pumilis (Colombia: Magdalena: Pueblito),
   M. quiniana (Mexico: Quintana Roo, 66 km E Xpujil), M. rectangularis
   (USA: Texas: Hidalgo Co.), M. redacta (Costa Rica; Heredia: Estacion
   Biologia La Selva), M. rubidia (Brazil: Bahia: Salobro), M. storea
   (Jamaica; Hardwar Gap), M. tegetis (Honduras: Copan), M. tegetis (Costa
   Rica: Cartago: Turrialba), M. thomasi (Andros Island: Maidenhair Cop
   pica), M. vogti (USA: Texas: Hidalgo Co.), M. welderi (USA: Texas: San
   Patricio Co., Welder Wildlife Refuge), and M. zonisla (Panama: Colon:
   Fort Shennan). A neotype is selected for Enoplium dislocatum Say.
   Lectotypes are selected for Madoniella corporaali Pic, Epiphloeus
   ersthrocephalus Gorham, Madoniella minor Pic, Madoniella pici Lepesme,
   Epiphloeus punctatus Gorham, and Epiphloeus nebulosum Chevrolat.
   Madoniellans are lignicolous insects with a predatory role in the
   process of wood decomposition; their larvae and adults are voracious
   predators on wood infesting beetles. These beetles are strong flyers,
   highly cryptic on bark, and apparently capable of perceiving volatile
   emissions of bark beetle prey and emission products of hardwoods. They
   congregate in high numbers amidst outbreaks of bark beetles, but after
   depositing eggs founder predatory adults disperse from the initial
   bark-beetle infestation site. That is, once these checkered beetle
   adults have established a predatory population, the initial parents, or
   their progeny, will not deposit eggs during subsequent outbreaks of the
   second generation of bark beetles that reinfest the initial tree hosts.
   Species of Madoniella do not appear to be host specific (regarding prey
   or tree) for they are known to be associated with a variety of wood
   infesting beetles and trees such as pines, oaks, and mahogany. It is
   postulated that the common ancestor of Decorosa and Madoniella evolved
   in South America with extensive over sea dispersals into Middle America
   and the Antilles. It is thought that the Greater Antilles fauna has its
   origin in a Mexo-American founder species that traversed a relatively
   narrow oceanic gap at a time when the southern component of Hispaniola
   approximated the Yucatan peninsula. The madoniellan Lesser Antilles
   components probably are derivatives of northern South American elements.
   The relative abundance of autochthonos islandic species, that
   phylogenetically traverse species-group lines, is indication that
   oversea dispersal has been an important characteristic in madoniellan
   historical and extant biogeography.

PT J
AN ZOOR14807051982
DT Article
TI Description of 69 new longhorn beetles and 6 new genera from Asia mainly
   from Borneo, China, (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).
FT Beischreibung von 69 neuen Bockkaefern and 6 neuen Gattungen aus Asien,
   vorwiegend aus Borneo, China, Laos and Thailand (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae).
AU Holzschuh, Carolus
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 33
PS 249-328
PD December 22 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Six new genera and 69 new species and subspecies are described from
   Borneo (24), Sumatra (5), Mentawai Isl. (1), China (8), Vietnam (2),
   Laos (14), Malaysia (3), and India (2). Strangalia kannegieteri
   Aurivillius, 1925 is transferred to Stenoleptura Gressitt, 1935,
   therefore becomes S. kannegieteri (Aurivillius, 1925), and its Lectotype
   is designated. The replacement name Gerdianus is proposed for Gerdius
   Holzschuh, 2009 (Coleoptera), which is of A junior homonym of Gerdius
   Townes, 1969 (Hymenoptera); Gerdius gracilus Holzschuh, 2009 therefore
   becomes Gerdanus gracilus (Holzschuh, 2009). Obrium annulicorne Pascoe,
   1869 is transferred to Stenhomalus White, 1855, therefore becomes S.
   annulicornis (Pascoe, 1869). Luteicenus Pic, 1922 is raised to generic
   status from a subgenus of Purpuricenus Dejean, 1821, and Latecyrtidus
   Vives et Niisato, 2011 is treated as a synonym of Luteicenus;
   Purpuricenus (Luteicenus) atromaculatus Pic, 1922 becomes atromaculatus
   (Pic, 1922) and Latecyrtidus yamasakoi Vives et Niisato, 2011 is treated
   as its junior synonym.
C1 Holzschuh, Carolus; Spitzeckweg 11, A-9500 Villach, Austria, Austria.

DT Article
TI New and poorly known species of Cryptocephalus Geoffroy, 1762 from the
   Palearctic and Oriental regions (Chrysomelidae, Cryptocephalinae).
AU Medvedev, Lev N. (lev.n.medvedev@mail.ru) 
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 33
PS 329-349
PD December 22 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB 20 new species: C. shapaensis, C. bacboensis, C. dongnaicus (Vietnam),
   C. nahinus (Laos), C. Thailand), C. roseofulvous, C. keralensis, C.
   megalayanus, C. tamilnadensis (India), pseudoincisus, C. schawalleri, C.
   pseudovirens (China), C. olegi (Thailand, Vietnam), g. (Thailand), C.
   laotanus (Laos), C. triangulomimus (Nepal), C. mohamedsaidi, C.
   sarawacensis, C. romantsovi (Malaysia) and one new subspecies: C.
   pallidipennis kalimpongi (India) are described; redescriptions or
   additional data for C. binotatithoraz Pic, 1920, C. sinuatolineatus Pic,
   1920 and C. dimidiatus Suffrian, 1860 are given. C. kuznetzovi L.
   Medvedev, 1992 is reduced to a subspecies of C. eroshkinae L. Medvedev
   et Samoderzhenkov, 1987. C. vouauxi Achard, 1920 is removed from
   nominate subgenus to subgenus Asionus Lopatin, 1988. C. zinovjevi L.
   Medvedev, 1973 from the Russian Far East and is reported for the first
   time for China. C. delkeskampi Gressitt et Kimoto, 1961 is a new synonym
   for C. sinuatolineatus Pic, 1920.
C1 Medvedev, Lev N.; Institute for Problems of Ecology and Evolution,
   Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninsky prospect 33, Moscow 119071,
   Russia, Russia.
EM lev.n.medvedev@mail.ru

PT J
AN ZOOR14807051987
DT Article
TI A contribution to knowledge of Oriental species of Cneorane Baly, 1865
   (Chrysomelidae, Galerucinae).
AU Medvedev, Lev N. (lev.n.medvedev@mail.ru) 
SO Entomologica Basiliensia et Collectionis Frey
VL 33
PS 351-368
PD December 22 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A preliminary key to Oriental Cneorane Baly, 1865 is given. Three
   species (C. bhutana [long dash] Bhutan, C. sprecherae, C. costipennis
   [long dash] both Thailand) are described as new for science. C.
   nigripennis Laboissiere, 1922 is the new synonym of C. cariosipennis
   Fairmaire, 1888. Four species (C. ephippiata Laboissiere, 1930, C.
   abdominalis Jacoby, 1890, C. semipurpurea Jacoby, 1884, C. borneensis
   Jacoby, 1894) are excluded from the genus.

PT J
AN ZOOR14803021186
DT Article
TI Sokatra, a New Side-Necked Turtle (Late Cretaceous, Madagascar) and the
   Diversification of the Main Groups of Pelomedusoides.
AU Gaffney, Eugene S.
   Krause, David W.
SO American Museum Novitates
VL 3728
PS 1-28
PD December 22 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Sokatra antitra, n. gen. et sp., is a new side-necked turtle from the
   Maastrichtian (Upper Cretaceous) Maevarano Formation, Mahajanga Basin,
   northwestern Madagascar. Sokatra antitra is based on a series of
   incomplete skulls: a partial skull that lacks the premaxillae and some
   of the basicranium, a partial skull that has a complete ear region and
   partial basicranium, and other isolated specimens, including dentaries.
   Although this species exhibits some features of the North African and
   Brazilian Euraxemydidae, it does not belong to this family, but instead
   it is the sister taxon of the magnafamily Podocnemidera of Gaffney et
   al. (2006, 2011). Characters of Sokatra uniting it with the magnafamily
   Podocnemidera are: quadrate-basisphenoid contact, ventral covering of
   processus interfenestralis of opisthotic, and at least half of prootic
   covered ventrally. The laterally open foramen jugulare posterius and the
   distinct accessory ridge on the maxilla are characteristic, but not
   unique, features shared with members of the Euraxemydidae. The presence
   of a small wall posterior to the columellae auris and medial to the
   incisura columellae auris and the formation of the foramen posterius
   canalis carotici interni by both the prootic and quadrate are unique to
   Sokatra. In a PAUP analysis using the character matrix from Gaffney et
   al. (2006), Sokatra resolves as: (Pelomedusidae, Araripemys (Sokatra
   (Euraxemydidae (Bothremydidae, Podocnemididae)))). The deep phylogenetic
   roots of Sokatra indicates the presence of its lineage on Madagascar
   prior to the beginning of the Late Cretaceous.
C1 Gaffney, Eugene S.; Division of Paleontology, American Museum of Natural
   History, USA, USA.
SC Zoology
SN 0003-0082; 1937-352X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Sokatra [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Sokatra antitra [Madagascar /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Anapsida, Testudines,
   Pleurodira
OR Pelomedusoides - Cope 1868 (Pleurodira): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 24]. 
   Sokatra (Pleurodira): [Gen nov, Of magnafamily Podocnemidera, Type
   species Sokatra antitra, p. 3, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Sokatra antitra (Pleurodira): [Sp nov, Madagascar, Cretaceous, P. 4;
   Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14802011823
PM 21543354
DT Article
TI Intercontinental dispersal of giant thermophilic ants across the Arctic
   during early Eocene hyperthermals.
AU Archibald, S. Bruce (sba48@sfu.ca) 
   Johnson, Kirk R.
   Mathewes, Rolf W.
   Greenwood, David R.
SO Proceedings of the Royal Society Biological Sciences Series B
VL 278
IS 1725
PS 3679-3686
PD Dec 22 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB Early Eocene land bridges allowed numerous plant and animal species to
   cross between Europe and North America via the Arctic. While many
   species suited to prevailing cool Arctic climates would have been able
   to cross throughout much of this period, others would have found
   dispersal opportunities only during limited intervals when their
   requirements for higher temperatures were met. Here, we present
   Titanomyrma lubei gen. et sp. nov. from Wyoming, USA, a new giant
   (greater than 5 cm long) formiciine ant from the early Eocene (approx.
   49.5 Ma) Green River Formation. We show that the extinct ant subfamily
   Formiciinae is only known from localities with an estimated mean annual
   temperature of about 20[degree]C or greater, consistent with the
   tropical ranges of almost all of the largest living ant species. This
   is, to our knowledge, the first known formiciine of gigantic size in the
   Western Hemisphere and the first reported cross-Arctic dispersal by a
   thermophilic insect group. This implies intercontinental migration
   during one or more brief high-temperature episodes (hyperthermals)
   sometime between the latest Palaeocene establishment of intercontinental
   land connections and the presence of giant formiciines in Europe and
   North America by the early middle Eocene.
C1 Archibald, S. Bruce; Simon Fraser Univ, Dept Biol Sci, Burnaby, BC, V5A
   1S6, Canada, Canada.
EM sba48@sfu.ca
RI Greenwood, David R./C-2758-2008
OI Greenwood, David R./0000-0002-8569-9695; MATHEWES,
   ROLF/0000-0001-7637-199X

PT J
