PM 21525061
DT Article
TI A new Early Permian reptile and its significance in early diapsid
   evolution.
AU Reisz, Robert R.
   Modesto, Sean P. (seanmodesto@yahoo.ca) 
   Scott, Diane M.
SO Proceedings of the Royal Society Biological Sciences Series B
VL 278
IS 1725
PS 3731-3737
PD Dec 22 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 24
AB The initial stages of evolution of Diapsida (the large clade that
   includes not only snakes, lizards, crocodiles and birds, but also
   dinosaurs and numerous other extinct taxa) is clouded by an exceedingly
   poor Palaeozoic fossil record. Previous studies had indicated a 38 Myr
   gap between the first appearance of the oldest diapsid clade
   (Araeoscelidia), ca 304 million years ago (Ma), and that of its sister
   group in the Middle Permian (ca 266 Ma). Two new reptile skulls from the
   Richards Spur locality, Lower Permian of Oklahoma, represent a new
   diapsid reptile: Orovenator mayorum n. gen. et sp. A phylogenetic
   analysis identifies O. mayorum as the oldest and most basal member of
   the araeoscelidian sister group. As Richards Spur has recently been
   dated to 289 Ma, the new diapsid neatly spans the above gap by appearing
   15 Myr after the origin of Diapsida. The presence of O. mayorum at
   Richards Spur, which records a diverse upland fauna, suggests that
   initial stages in the evolution of non-araeoscelidian diapsids may have
   been tied to upland environments. This hypothesis is consonant with the
   overall scant record for non-araeoscelidian diapsids during the Permian
   Period, when thewell-known terrestrial vertebrate communities are
   preserved almost exclusively in lowland deltaic, flood plain and
   lacustrine sedimentary rocks.
C1 Modesto, Sean P.; Cape Breton Univ, Dept Biol, Sydney, NS, B1P 6L2,
   Canada, Canada.
EM seanmodesto@yahoo.ca
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 0962-8452
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Evolution; Land zones;
   Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Araeoscelidia; Diapsida [Evolution /  / Systematics] [Permian / Early
   Permian / stratigraphical distribution]. 
   Orovenator [Permian /  / New genus]. 
   Orovenator mayorum [Oklahoma /  / new species] [Permian /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Euryapsida
OR Diapsida - Osborn 1903 (Reptilia): [Fossil]. 
   Neodiapsida - Benton 1985 (Reptilia): [Emended diagnosis, P. 3733]. 
   Orovenator (Reptilia): [Gen nov, Of clade Neodiapsida, Type species
   Orovenator mayorum, p. 3733, Permian; Fossil]. 
   Orovenator mayorum (Reptilia): [Sp nov, Oklahoma, Permian, P. 3733;
   Fossil]. 
   Araeoscelidia (Euryapsida): [Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14802011828

TI Groundwater, spring and interstitial Ostracoda (Crustacea) from Shiga
   Prefecture, Japan, including descriptions of three new species and one
   new genus.
AU Smith, Robin J. (smith@lbm.go.jp) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3140
PS 15-37
PD 21 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3140.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03140p037.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB During surveys of a variety of groundwater, spring and interstitial
   habitats (e.g. in river bars, domestic wells, springs, and seeps) in
   Shiga Prefecture, Japan, a total of 15 ostracod species were recovered
   and identified. Three species and one genus are described for the first
   time herein, Undulacandona spinula n. gen & n. sp., Cryptocandona
   tsukagoshii n. sp. and Cavernocypris cavernosa n. sp.. Microdarwinula
   zimmeri (Menzel, 1916) is reported for the first time from Japan.
   Dolerocypris ikeyai Smith & Kamiya, 2006, Eucypris pigra (Fischer, 1851)
   and Cryptocandona brehmi (Klie, 1934) are new records for Shiga
   Prefecture.

   525-0001, Japan, Japan.

TI Description of two new species of Pseudochrominae from northern Palawan
   and Mindoro, Philippine Islands (Teleostei: Perciformes:
   Pseudochromidae).
AU Gill, Anthony C. (anthony.c.gill@sydney.edu.au) 
   Williams, Jeffrey T.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3140
PS 49-59
PD 21 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3140.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt03140p059.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Pseudochromis fuligifinis is described from 12 specimens from Verde
   Island, west coast of Mindoro and Apo Reef in the Philippines. It
   closely resembles P. elongatus Lubbock from Indonesia and P. striatus
   Gill, Shao & Chen from the Batanes Islands, Taiwan and the Ryukyu
   Islands, but differs in various meristic and coloration details.
   Manonichthys scintilla is described from five specimens from Coron
   Island and Apo Reef. It differs from congeners in fin shape and live
   coloration details.

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Parastylodactylus Figueira, 1971 (Crustacea:
   Decapoda: Caridea: Stylodactylidae) from off Kollam, southwest coast of
   India.
AU Komai, Tomoyuki (Komai@chiba-muse.or.jp) 
   Shanis, C.P. Rajool
SO Zootaxa
VL 3140
PS 60-68
PD 21 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3140.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03140p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the caridean genus Parastylodactylus Figueira, 1971
   (Stylodactylidae), P. sulcatus, is described and illustrated on the
   basis of three male specimens from the Southern Arabian Sea, off the
   southwest coast of India, at a depth of 350 m. Morphologically, the new
   species appears closest to P. bimaxillaris (Bate, 1888) widely
   distributed in the Indo- West Pacific, but the much longer rostrum, the
   absence of a supraorbital tooth on the carapace, the deep hepatic groove
   on the carapace and the relatively longer and more slender third
   pereopod distinguish the new species from P. bimaxillaris. It is the
   first representative of the genus from Indian waters. An updated key to
   the species of Parastylodactylus is presented.
C1 Komai, Tomoyuki; Natural History Museum and Institute, Chiba, 955-2
   Aoba-cho, Chuo-ku, Chiba, 260-8682, Japan, Japan.
EM Komai@chiba-muse.or.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Ocean; North Indian Ocean

   Parastylodactylus sulcatus [Arabian Sea / India, Kerala / New species].

AB Eight species of Horistonotus Candeze (1860), from states of Alagoas and
   Sergipe, are described and illustrated and a provisional identification
   key for all Brazilian species of this genus is provided. The described
   species were collected in the Caatinga, semi-desert tropical woodland,
   in the Northeastern Region of Brazil. The genus Horistonotus is very
   numerous with more than a hundred species, distributed throughout of
   North, Central and South America.

U2 1
AB A new species, Rhithrogena sartorii Zrelli & Boumaiza, sp. nov. is
   described in subimaginal, egg and nymphal stages from material collected
   in Northern Tunisia. This species shows affinities with members of the
   insularis species group. Features distinguishing the new species from
   other North African species, as well as from Rhithrogena insularis (from
   Corsica) and Rhithrogena nuragica (from Sardinia) are discussed.

DT Article
TI A phylogeny and evolutionary natural history of mesoamerican toads
   (Anura: Bufonidae: Incilius) based on morphology, life history, and
   molecular data.
AU Mendelson, Joseph R., III (jmendelson@zooatlanta.org) 
   Mulcahy, Daniel G.
   Williams, Tyler S.
   Sites, Jack W., Jr
SO Zootaxa
VL 3138
PS 1-34
PD 21 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3138.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt03138p034.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB We combine mitochondrial and nuclear DNA sequence data with
   non-molecular (morphological and natural history) data to conduct
   phylogenetic analyses and generate an evolutionary hypothesis for the
   relationships among nearly every species of Mesoamerican bufonid in the
   genus Incilius. We collected a total of 5,898 aligned base-pairs (bp) of
   sequence data from mitochondrial (mtDNA: 12S[long dash]16S, cyt b,
   ND2[long dash]CO1, including tRNAsTRP[long dash]TYR and the origin of
   light strand replication; total 4,317 bp) and nuclear (CXCR4 and RAG1;
   total 1,581 bp) loci from 52 individual toads representing 37 species.
   For the non-molecular data, we collected 44 characters from 29 species.
   We also include Crepidophryne, a genus that has not previously been
   included in molecular analyses. We present results of parsimony and
   Bayesian analyses for these data separately and combined. Relationships
   based on the non-molecular data were poorly supported and did not
   resolve a monophyletic Incilius (Rhinella marina was nested within). Our
   molecular data provide significant support to most of the relationships.
   Our combined analyses demonstrate that inclusion of a considerably
   smaller dataset (44 vs. 5,898 characters) of non-molecular characters
   can provide significant support where the molecular relationships were
   lacking support. Our combined results indicate that Crepidophryne is
   nested within Incilius; therefore, we place the former in the synonymy
   of the latter taxon. Our study provides the most comprehensive
   evolutionary framework for Mesoamerican bufonids (Incilius), which we
   use as a starting point to invoke discussion on the evolution of their
   unique natural history traits.
C1 Mendelson, Joseph R., III; Department of Herpetology, Zoo Atlanta, 800
   Cherokee Ave SE, Atlanta, GA 30315, USA, USA.
EM jmendelson@zooatlanta.org
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; General morphology; Genetics; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Nearctic region; North America
DE Incilius [General morphology /  / systematics] [Molecular genetics /
   Molecular data / ] [Phylogeny / Phylogeographic analysis / ]
   [Zoogeography /  / ] [Neotropical region / Mesoamerica / ] [Mexico /  /
   ]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Bufonidae
OR Crepidophryne chompipe - Vaughan & Mendelsen 2007 (Bufonidae): [Referred
   to, Incilius, p. 19]. 
   Crepidophryne epiotica - (Cope 1875) (Bufonidae): [Referred to,
   Incilius, p. 19]. 
   Crepidophryne guanacaste - Vaughan & Mendelsen 2007 (Bufonidae):
   [Referred to, Incilius, p. 19]. 
   Incilius - Cope 1863 (Bufonidae): [Syn nov, Crepidophryne Cope 1889, p.
   19]. 
   Incilius chompipe - (Vaughan & Mendelsen 2007) (Bufonidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Crepidophryne, p. 19]. 
   Incilius epioticus - (Cope 1875) (Bufonidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Crepidophryne, p. 19]. 
   Incilius guanacaste - (Vaughan & Mendelsen 2007) (Bufonidae): [Comb nov,

DT Article
TI A new species of Leiopathes (Anthozoa: Antipatharia) from the Great
   Meteor seamount (North Atlantic).
AU Molodtsova, Tina N. (tina@ocean.ru) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3138
PS 51-64
PD 21 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3138.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03138p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Leiopathes montana, a new species previously reported as L. glaberrima
   (Esper), is described from the plateau of the Great Meteor seamount
   (North Atlantic) at depth 300[long dash]335 m. The new species can be
   easily distinguished from all other species of the genus by very thin at
   tips, slightly bended terminal branchlets 0.15[long dash]0.2 mm in
   diameter above the base, rather long in comparison to the size of the
   colony, small compressed triangular spines 0.02[long dash]0.03 mm long
   and 0.22[long dash]0.5 mm apart, and small densely-set polyps (6[long
   dash]9 per centimeter). Eight species assigned to the genus Leiopathes
   represent two distinct groups: (1) sparsely branched forms with longer
   terminal branchlets (L. glaberrima, L. valdiviae, L. acanthophora, L.
   bullosa, L. montana), and (2) forms with sinusoidal stem and branches,
   and very short branchlets forming flabellate fronds (L. expansa, L.
   grimaldii, L. secunda). The largest in size syntype of L. grimaldii
   Roule, 1902 collected off the Azores is proposed here as the lectotype,
   since it is the only full grown and complete specimen and also the only
   specimen illustrated and described in detail by Roule.
C1 Molodtsova, Tina N.; P.P. Shirshov Institute of Oceanology RAS, 36
   Nakhimovsky prospect, Moscow 117997, Russia, Russia.
EM tina@ocean.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Taxonomy; Marine
   zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Leiopathes [North Atlantic /  / Distribution; systematics] [Indian Ocean
   /  / ]. 
   Leiopathes montana [North Atlantic /  / New species]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Ceriantipatharia
OR Leiopathes - Haime 1849 (Ceriantipatharia): [Included taxa, P. 55]. 
   Leiopathes grimaldii - Roule 1902 (Ceriantipatharia): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 60]. 
   Leiopathes montana (Ceriantipatharia): [Sp nov, North Atlantic, P. 55].

DT Article
TI Taxonomic review of freshwater Gammarus (Crustacea: Amphipoda) from
   Iran.
AU Zamanpoore, Mehrdad (mzamanpoore@gmail.com) 
   Grabowski, Michal
   Poeckl, Manfred
   Schiemer, Friedrich
SO Zootaxa
VL 3140
PS 1-14
PD 21 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3140.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03140p014.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The paper summarizes current knowledge upon taxonomy and distribution of
   the freshwater Gammarus Fabricius, 1775 in Iran. Based on the literature
   data, 24 species were recorded so far from the fresh waters in the
   country. Revision of previously published materials including type
   collections, and analysis of new materials, revealed presence of 18
   valid freshwater Gammarus species in Iran (G. anodon, G. bakhteyaricus,
   G. baloutchi, G. crinicaudatus, G. hegmatanensis, G. komareki, G.
   lacustris, G. lobifer, G. loeffleri, G. lordeganensis, G. paricrenatus,
   G. parthicus, G. pretzmanni, G. pseudosyriacus, G. sepidannus, G.
   shirazinus, G. sirvannus and G. zagrosensis). Among the remaining six
   species, three (G. arduus, G. laticoxalis, G. syriacus) were reported as
   a result of misidentification and further three (G. miae, G. plumipes,
   G. projectus) appeared to be junior synonyms of other already described
   species. Distribution ranges of most of the species are restricted
   usually to only few localities in the mountainous terrain, so they may
   be treated as Iranian endemics. The only exceptions are: G. lacustris
   (widely distributed in Holarctic, with only few populations in Iran), G.
   komareki (widely distributed in the Balkan Peninsula and Asia Minor, in
   Iran recorded from the entire Alborz region) and G. pseudosyriacus
   (widely distributed in Asia Minor, in Iran found in the entire Zagros
   region). A brief remark on taxonomy of each species is presented, with
   emphasis on misidentifications, synonymies and similar species,
   supplemented by distribution data, and ecological details if available.
   An identification key for the freshwater Gammarus of Iran is provided.
C1 Zamanpoore, Mehrdad; Department of Limnology, Institute of Ecology,
   University of Vienna, Austria, Austria.
EM mzamanpoore@gmail.com
RI Grabowski, Michal/K-1016-2012; Zamanpoore, Mehrdad/C-1895-2017
OI Grabowski, Michal/0000-0002-4551-3454; Zamanpoore,
   Mehrdad/0000-0002-3042-7262
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Ecology; Habitat;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Gammarus [Ecology /  / Systematics] [Freshwater habitat /  /
   distribution] [Iran /  / Key to species] [ /  / ]. 
   Gammarus arduus; Gammarus laticoxalis; Gammarus syriacus [Iran /  /
   Erroneous record]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI Taxonomy of European Damaeidae (Acari: Oribatida) VI. The oribatid mite
   genus Parabelbella: Redescription of P. elisabhetae and synonymy of
   Akrodamaeus.
AU Miko, Ladislav (ladislavmiko@seznam.cz) 
   Ermilov, Sergey G.
   Smelyansky, Ilya E.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3140
PS 38-48
PD 21 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3140.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03140p048.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The mite genus Parabelbella Bulanova-Zachvatkina, 1972, one of the
   poorest known genera of Damaeidae, is redefined on the basis of
   redescription of P. elisabhetae Bulanova-Zachvatkina, 1967, collected by
   the authors in Russia and following study of the type material of
   Bulanova-Zachvatkina. Akrodamaeus Norton, 1979 is considered as a junior
   synonym of Parabelbella based on the new diagnosis. Altogether 7 known
   species belong to Parabelbella, with known distribution in Russia,
   Central Asia and America. Development of the concept of the genus is
   discussed, concluding that the generic name is available only since the
   year 1972, when P. crenatosetosa was established as it's type. It was
   found that the type species was described by Bulanova-Zachvatkina in
   1967 and not in 1957 as earlier presented. Recently proposed synonymies
   of Heterodamaeus Mihelcic., 1964, Mirobelba Perez-Inigo et Pena, 1994,
   Tectodamaeus Aoki, 1984 and Nododamaeus Hammer, 1977 with Parabelbella
   are considered unacceptable without additional information and synonymy
   of Akrodamaeus with Metabelbella Bulanova- Zachvatkina, 1957 is
   rejected. The key of European species of Parabelbella is given.
C1 Miko, Ladislav; European Commission, Directorate General for Health and
   Consumers, Rue Breydel 4, 1040 Bruxelles, Belgium, Belgium.
EM ladislavmiko@seznam.cz
RI Miko, Ladislav/R-8149-2019

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

TI Australian goblin spiders of the genus Opopaea Simon, part 1. The
   species of the IBISCA-Queensland Project at Lamington National Park
   (Araneae: Oonopidae).
AU Baehr, Barbara C. (barbara.baehr@qm.qld.gov.au) 
SO Memoirs of the Queensland Museum
VL 55
IS 2
PS 413-437
PD 20 December 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The IBISCA-Queensland Project, an intensive survey of invertebrates
   along an altitudinal gradient within subtropical rainforest at Lamington
   NP in Queensland, Australia, revealed eight new species of the goblin
   spider genus Opopaea Simon, 1891 including: O. antoniae sp. nov., 0.
   jonesae sp. nov., O. leica sp. nov., O. olivernashi sp. nov., 0.
   rogerkitchingi sp. nov., O. sown sp. nov., 0. speighti sp. nov. and 0.
   yukii sp. nov., each described from both sexes. A key is provided for
   these Australian Opopaea species and their altitudinal distributions are
   discussed.

DT Article
TI Orsolobidae (Araneae) of the IBSCA-Queensland Project at Lamington
   National Park, Australia.
AU Baehr, Barbara C. (barabra.baehr@qm.qld.gov.au) 
   Raven, Robert J.
   Hebron, Wendy
SO Memoirs of the Queensland Museum
VL 55
IS 2
PS 439-449
PD 20 December 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Five species of the endemic Australian spider family Orsolobidae are
   recorded from the IBISCA-Queensland Project, a survey of invertebrates
   along an altitudinal gradient within continuous rainforest at Lamington
   National Park, Queensland, Australia. They comprise two species of
   Hickmanolobus and three species of Tasmanoonops, including the newly
   described Hickmanolobus nimorakiotakisi sp. nov. and Tasmanoonops
   rogerkitchingi sp. nov. Also recorded are Tasmanoonops parvus
   Forster&Platnick, of which the male is described for the first time,
   Tasmanoonops complexus Forster&Platnick and Hickmanolobus ibisca Baehr
   and Smith. Within Lamington National Park all five species have been
   collected only above around 750 m a.s.l. and consequently the
   Orsolobidae are recommended for inclusion in programs to monitor the
   impacts of climate change.

   4101, Australia, Australia.

   described, Male, p. 443]. 
   Hickmanolobus rogerkitchingi (Araneae): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 444]. 
   Orsolobidae (Araneae).

DT Article
TI Internal parasites obtained from two alien turtles, Trachemys scripta
   (Emydidae) and Chelydra serpentine (Chelydridae), in Japan.
AU Ishida, Aya
   Iwao, Hajime
   Hinoue, Masami
   Abe, Shintaro
   Kobayashis, Raita
   Asakawa, Mitsuhiko (askam@rakuno.ac.jp) 
SO Bulletin of the Biogeographical Society of Japan
VL 66
PS 1-6
PD Dec 20 2011
PY 2011
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 13
AB The present survey was conducted on internal parasites of 2 alien turtle
   species, namely Trachemys scripta (18 individuals) (host abbreviation:
   Ts) and Chelydra serpentina (3 individuals) (Cs) in Japan. Two nematode
   species including Serpinema microcephalus (Ts) and Falcaustra sp. cf.
   falcata (Ts, Cs)), a trematode of Telorchis geoclemmydis (Ts, Cs)) and a
   protozoan genus including several species of Eimeria (Ts) were obtained
   from the present samples. They are new host records in Japan.

DT Article
TI First occurrence of the Hydromedusa Octophialucium sp (Hydrozoa,
   Leptomedusae) in Japan and its life cycle.
AU Akiyama, Hisashi (sps-1@poem.ocn.ne.jp) 
   Yamasaki, Yuusuke
   Tsujita, Akiko
   Horinouchi, Shiori
   Kubota, Shin
SO Bulletin of the Biogeographical Society of Japan
VL 66
PS 135-139
PD Dec 20 2011
PY 2011
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Ten or more medusae of Octophialucium sp. (Hydrozoa, Leptomedsae) were
   collected at the sea surface in Sasebo, Nagasaki Prefecture, japan, as
   the first record from Japan. The morphology of four large mature medusae
   are described and photographed. They were reared in aquarium, and their
   polyps, medusa bud, newly liberated medusa and mature medusa were also
   described and photographed. The young medusae were reared for 3 months
   to observe the temporal morphological change in aquarium. The life cycle
   of this species is completed in aquarium for the first time.
C1 Akiyama, Hisashi; Saikai Natl Pk Kujukushima Aquarium, 1055 Kashimae,
   Sasebo, Nagasaki, 8580922, Japan, Japan.

   [North Pacific / Japan, Kyushu / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14806042899
DT Article
TI Species identification of the mud crab (Crustacea: Portunidae, Scylla
   sp.) of Yap Island, Micronesia.
AU Kawada, Akihiro
   Yokota, Masashi (yokota@kaiyodai.ac.jp) 
   Struessmann, Carlos A.
   Usami, Yoh
   Watanabe, Seiichi
SO Bulletin of the Biogeographical Society of Japan
VL 66
PS 195-202
PD Dec 20 2011
PY 2011
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 1
AB The aim of the present study was to identify the species of mud crab
   (Scylla sp.) found in Yap Island, the Federated States of Micronesia by
   means of morphological and genetic analyzes. Based on the morphological
   examination, all mud crabs from Yap Island were tentatively classified
   as Scylla serrata. The genetic analysis compared a partial sequence (219
   bp) of the mitochondrial DNA cytochrome oxidase subunit I (COI) in
   Scylla spp. samples from Yap Island and 10 other mangrove areas in the
   West Pacific Region, e.g. Fiji, Vanuatu, Papua New Guinea, Makassar and
   Manado (Indonesia), Surat Thani (Thailand), Okinawa, Kagoshima, Kochi
   and Hamanako (Japan). Samples from other locations included specimens of
   S. paramamosain, S. olivacea, and S. tranquebarica for comparison. The
   genetic analysis by mitochondrial DNA network of four species haplotypes
   confirmed that all specimens from Yap were of S. serrata. It also
   indicated little genetic variation between specimens collected in
   various locations within the island or between those from Yap and the S.
   serrata specimens from other West Pacific areas.
C1 Yokota, Masashi; Tokyo Univ Marine Sci & Technol, Minato Ku, 4-5-7
   Konan, Tokyo, 1088477, Japan, Japan.
EM yokota@kaiyodai.ac.jp
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Genetics
   &Heredity
SN 0067-8716
BD General morphology; Biochemistry; Genetics; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Scylla serrata [General morphology /  / species identification] [Nucleic
   acids / mtDNA COI sequence / ] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [North Pacific
   / Federated States of Micronesia, Yap Island / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura
OR Scylla serrata (Brachyura). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14806042899
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14806044242
DT Article
TI Chemosynthetic trophic support for the benthic community at an
   intertidal cold seep site at Mocha Island off central Chile.
AU Sellanes, Javier (sellanes@ucn.cl) 
   Zapata-Hernandez, German
   Pantoja, Silvio
   Jessen, Gerdhard L.
SO Estuarine Coastal and Shelf Science
VL 95
IS 4
PS 431-439
PD December 20 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 34
AB We analyzed C and N stable isotope ratios of benthic fauna and their
   potential food sources at an intertidal methane seep site and a control
   site without emanation at Mocha Island (central Chile). The objective
   was to trace the origin of the main food sources used by the local
   heterotrophic fauna, based on the hypothesis that chemosynthetic
   production could be partially fueling the local food web at the seep
   site. Food sources sampled at both sites included macroalgae,
   particulate organic matter and bacteria-like filaments found growing
   over the red algae Gelidium lingulatum within the areas of active
   methane release. At the control site, located 11 km away from the gas
   emanation, fauna exhibited moderate [delta]13C values ranging from
   -16.2[per mill] (in a nereid polychaete) to -14.8[per mill] (in a
   cirolanid isopod), which were consistent with those of the potential
   photosynthetic food sources sampled at this site (-20.2 to -16.5[per
   mill]). [delta]13C values of the photosynthetic food sources at the seep
   site similarly ranged between -25.4 and -17.9[per mill]. However, a
   portion of the animals at this site were consistently more 13C-depleted,
   with [delta]13C values close to that of the seeping methane (-43.8[per
   mill]) and the bacteria-like filaments (-39.2 [plus or minus]2.5[per
   mill]) also collected at this site. Specific examples were the Marphysa
   sp. polychaetes ([delta]13C = -44.7 [plus or minus]0.6[per mill]), the
   Schistomeringos sp. dorvilleid polychaetes ([delta]13C = -42.9[per
   mill]), and the tanaid crustacean Zeuxo marmoratus ([delta]13C = -37.3
   [plus or minus]0.2[per mill]). The significantly higher [delta]13C
   values of the herbivorous gastropod Tegula atra at the seep site (-29.3
   [plus or minus]3.1[per mill]) than at the control site (-12.6 [plus or
   minus]0.3[per mill]) also indicated differences among sites of the
   preferred carbon sources of this species. Mixing model estimates
   indicate that at the seep site bacteria-like filaments could be
   contributing up to [approximately]60% of the assimilated diet of
   selected invertebrates. Furthermore, several indicators of trophic
   structure, based in isotopic niche metrics, indicate a considerably
   higher variety of basal resources used at the seep site and a consequent
   enhanced trophic diversity, compared with the non-seep site.
C1 Sellanes, Javier; Departamento de Biologia Marina, Facultad de Ciencias
   del Mar, Universidad Catolica del Norte, Coquimbo, Chile, Chile.
EM sellanes@ucn.cl
RI Sellanes, Javier/I-5722-2012; Sellanes, Javier/P-4699-2019; Jessen,
   Gerdhard L./AAG-1605-2020
OI Sellanes, Javier/0000-0002-6942-0762; Sellanes,
   Javier/0000-0002-6942-0762; Jessen, Gerdhard L./0000-0002-2602-6052;
   Zapata-Hernandez, German/0000-0003-3245-9118
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 0272-7714
BD Ecology; Ecological energetics; Trophic structure; Habitat; Marine
   zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Invertebrata [Energy flow / Chemoautotrophic energy source supplement /
   benthon] [Food webs /  / ] [Community structure /  / ] [Marine habitat /
   Intertidal methane seep / ] [South Pacific / Chile, Mocha Island / ]. 
TN Invertebrates
ST Animalia
OR Invertebrata (Animalia). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14806044242
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14804029634
DT Article
TI On species related to Elachista pollutella Duponchel (Lepidoptera,
   Elachistidae), with descriptions of four new Palaearctic species.
AU Kaila, Lauri (lauri.kaila@helsinki.fi) 
SO Entomologica Fennica
VL 22
IS 3
PS 129-139
PD 20 December 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The taxonomy of the relatives of Elachista (Aphelosetia) pollutella
   Duponchel, 1843 is clarified. The following species are described as
   new: Elachista jubarella sp. n. from Russian Caucasus, Elachista rutjani
   sp. n. from Russia: South Ural and Tuva, and Ukraine, Elachista enochra
   sp. n. from Turkmenistan, and E. cretula sp. n. from Kazakhstan and
   Turkmenistan. E. pollutella, previously only known from Central and
   Southern Europe, is recorded for the first time from Asian part of
   Russia in Altai Mts. and Mongolia. The identity of Elachista ilicrina
   Falkovitsh, 1986 is discussed.
C1 Kaila, Lauri; Finnish Museum of Natural History, Zoological Museum,
   FI-00014 University of Helsinki, Finland, Finland.

AN ZOOR14804029638
DT Article
TI Torymus ventralis (Fonscolombe) and Torymus maculatus sp. n. from
   Finland, and Torymus maculosus sp. n. from Corfu, Greece (Hymenoptera:
   Chalcidoidea: Torymidae).
AU Vikberg, Veli (vikberg@aina.net) 
SO Entomologica Fennica
VL 22
IS 3
PS 149-156
PD 20 December 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new species of Torynurs with maculated forewings are described: T.
   macarlatus sp. n. from southern Finland and T. maculosus sp. n. from
   Corfu, Greece. Both species are related to Torymus ventralis
   (Fonscolombe). Findings of T. ventralis in Finland are presented. The
   species is known as a parasitoid of Planetella (Diptera: Cecidomyiidae),
   although no Torymus was reared from subterranean galls of Planetella sp.
   on Car ex lasiocarpa Ehrh. (Cyperaceae) in Finland. The only parasitoids
   to emerge from these galls were Eurytoma truncata (Boheman) and Eupelmus
   vesicularis (Retzius).
C1 Vikberg, Veli; Liinalammintie 11 as 6, FI-14200 Turenki, Finland,
   Finland.
EM vikberg@aina.net

   diseases and disorders; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe

   Torymus maculosus [Greece /  / New species]. 
   Torymus ventralis [General morphology / Female morphology / Systematics;
   possible dipteran host associations] [Dipteran hosts / Planetella /
   Possible gall associations] [Denmark / Schlick / biology; distribution]
   [Finland / Aland Islands & Varsinais-Suomi / ] [France / Dordogne / ].

ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14802016331
DT Article
TI Review of the subgenus Ammosphex Wilcke, 1942 of the genus Arachnospila
   Kincaid, 1900 (Hymenoptera: Pompilidae) of the Russian Far East and East
   Siberia.
AU Loktionov, Valery M.
   Lelej, Arkady S. (lelej@biosoil.ru) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3137
PS 1-30
PD 20 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3137.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03137p030.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A total of nineteen species are reviewed. Five new species: Arachnospila
   (Ammosphex) belokobylskii Loktionov and Lelej, sp. nov. (Primorskiy
   Terr.), A. (A.) orientausa Loktionov and Lelej, sp. nov. (Primorskiy
   Terr.), A. (A.) rasnitsyni Loktionov and Lelej, sp. nov. (Buryatia), A.
   (A.) tobiasi Loktionov and Lelej, sp. nov. (Buryatia), and A. (A.)
   zonsteini Loktionov and Lelej, sp. nov. (Buryatia) are described and
   illustrated. Hitherto unknown females of A. (A.) eoabnormis Lelej, 1995,
   A. (A.) kurentzovi Lelej, 1995, A. (A.) kurzenkoi Lelej, 1995, A. (A.)
   mongolopinata Wolf, 1981, A. (A.) wolfi Lelej, 1995, and A. (A.)
   yasumatsui Wolf and Moczar, 1972 are described. Three species:
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) dschingis Wolf and Moczar, 1972, A. (A.)
   kaszabi Wolf and Moczar, 1972, and A. (A.) yasumatsui Wolf and Moczar,
   1972 are newly recorded from Russia. A key to species for both sexes is
   given.The synonymy of Psammochares subflavus Haupt, 1929 under
   Arachnospila clericalis (F. Morawitz, 1889) is confirmed.
C1 Lelej, Arkady S.; Institute of Biology and Soil Science, Far Eastern
   Branch of Russian Academy of Sciences, Vladivostok-22, 690022, Russia,
   Russia.
EM lelej@biosoil.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Arachnospila (Ammosphex) [Russia / Far East & Siberia / Distribution;
   natural history; systematics]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) belokobylskii; Arachnospila (Ammosphex)
   orientausa; Arachnospila (Ammosphex) rasnitsyni; Arachnospila
   (Ammosphex) tobiasi; Arachnospila (Ammosphex) zonsteini [Russia /  / New
   species]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) dschingis; Arachnospila (Ammosphex) kaszabi;
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) yasumatsui [Russia /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Pompiloidea, Pompilidae
OR Arachnospila (Ammosphex) - Wilcke 1942 (Pompilidae): [Key to species,
   Males, p. 27, females, p. 28]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) belokobylskii (Pompilidae): [Sp nov, Russia, P.
   8]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) dschingis (Pompilidae): [New record]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) eoabnormis - Lelej 1995 (Pompilidae): [First
   time described, Female, p. 10]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) kaszabi (Pompilidae): [New record]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) kurentzovi - Lelej 1995 (Pompilidae): [First
   time described, Female, p. 11]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) mongolopinata - Wolf 1981 (Pompilidae): [First
   time described, Female, p. 14]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) orientausa (Pompilidae): [Sp nov, Russia, P.
   15]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) rasnitsyni (Pompilidae): [Sp nov, Russia, P.
   17]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) tobiasi (Pompilidae): [Sp nov, Russia, P. 18]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) wolfi - Lelej 1995 (Pompilidae): [First time
   described, Female, p. 25]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) yasumatsui - Wolf & Moczar 1972 (Pompilidae):
   [First time described, Female, p. 25; New record]. 
   Arachnospila (Ammosphex) zonsteini (Pompilidae): [Sp nov, Russia, P.
   26]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14802016331
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14802016336
DT Article
TI Chewing lice of the genus Myrsidea (Phthiraptera: Menoponidae) from New
   World warblers (Passeriformes: Parulidae) from Costa Rica, with
   descriptions of four new species.
AU Kounek, Filip
   Syrchra, Oldrich (sychrao@vfu.cz) 
   Capek, Miroslav
   Laterak, Ivan
SO Zootaxa
VL 3137
PS 56-63
PD 20 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3137.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt03137p063.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Four new species of chewing lice of the genus Myrsidea parasitic on
   members of the avian family Parulidae are described. They and their type
   hosts are: Myrsidea basileuteri ex Basileuterus rufifrons, M. myiobori
   ex Myioborus miniatus, M. paleno ex Parkesia motacilla and M. zeledoni
   ex Phaeothlypis fulvicauda. Records of undescribed Myrsidea representing
   new louse-host associations for Basileuterus tristriatus and Parula
   pitiayumi are also discussed.
C1 Syrchra, Oldrich; Department of Biology and Wildlife Diseases, Faculty
   of Veterinary Hygiene and Ecology, University of Veterinary and
   Pharmaceutical Sciences, Palackeho 1[long dash]3, 612 42 Brno, Czech
   Republic, Czech Republic.
EM sychrao@vfu.cz
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   Central America

AN ZOOR14802016332
DT Article
TI A new avocado pest in Central America (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae) with a
   key to Lepidoptera larvae threatening avocados in California.
AU Gilligan, Todd M. (tgilliga@gmail.com) 
   Brown, John W.
   Hoddle, Mark S.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3137
PS 31-45
PD 20 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3137.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt03137p045.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Cryptaspasma perseana Gilligan and Brown, new species, is described and
   illustrated from Mexico and Guatemala. This species is a potential pest
   of the fruit of cultivated avocado, Persea americana (Lauraceae). Images
   of adults, male secondary structures, male and female genitalia, eggs,
   larvae, and pupae are provided. Details of the life history are
   reviewed. We provide characters to differentiate this pest from the most
   common avocado fruit pest in the region, Stenoma catenifer (Walsingham)
   (Elachistidae), and a key to identify Lepidoptera larvae threatening
   avocado in California. In addition, we provide a complete list of
   tortricids documented from different avocado varieties worldwide.
C1 Gilligan, Todd M.; Colorado State University, Department of
   Bioagricultural Sciences and Pest Management, Fort Collins, CO 80523,
   USA, USA.
EM tgilliga@gmail.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Nutrition; Diet;
   Associations; Land zones; Nearctic region; Neotropical region; North
   America; USA; Central America
DE Cryptaspasma (Cryptaspasma) perseana [Associations / Persea americana
   (Plant) / New associate species] [Mexico /  / New species] [Guatemala / 
   / plant associate]. 
   Lepidoptera [Associations / Persea americana (Plant) / Key to associated
   species] [California /  / Key to species; associated with Persea
   americana (Plant)]. 
   Tortricidae [Food plants / Persea americana / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans

   (Tortricidae): [Sp nov, Guatemala, Associated with Persea americana
   (Plant), p. 32].

PT J
AN ZOOR14802016334
DT Article
TI New species and records of the genus Dolophilodes Ulmer (Trichoptera:
   Philopotamidae) from India.
AU Saini, Malkiat Singh (mpandher.iari@gmail.com) 
   Pandher, Manpreet Singh
SO Zootaxa
VL 3137
PS 46-55
PD 20 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3137.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt03137p055.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Dolophilodes Ulmer (Trichoptera: Philopotamidae) is reviewed
   from India, with the description of 3 new species: D. malickyi sp. nov.
   and D. punjpullaensis sp. nov. from Punjpulla (Himachal Pradesh) and D.
   morsei sp. nov. from Lumla (Arunachal Pradesh). Dolophilodes ornatula
   Kimmins is reported for the first time from India. This species, D.
   tibetana Kimmins and D. indica Martynov are redescribed with additional
   collection records. A key to males of the known Indian species of this
   genus is provided.
C1 Saini, Malkiat Singh; Department of Zoology and Environmental Sciences,
   Punjabi University, Patiala, 147002, India, India.
EM mpandher.iari@gmail.com
RI Singh, Manpreet/AAF-6019-2020
OI Singh, Manpreet/0000-0002-8045-7267

DT Article
TI A revision of Geostiba of the West Palaearctic region. XXI. Eight new
   species from Turkey and the Caucasus, a new synonymy, and additional
   records (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Aleocharinae).
AU Assing, V. (vassing.hann@t-online.de) 
SO Linzer Biologische Beitraege
VL 43
IS 2
PS 1135-1158
PD 19 Dezember 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eight species of Geostiba THOMSON from Turkey and the West Caucasus are
   described and illustrated: Geostiba (Tropogastrosipalia) perfodens
   nov.sp. (Turkey: Isparta), G. (T.) fodens nov.sp. (Turkey: Isparta), G.
   (T.) pungens nov.sp. (Turkey: Isparta), G. (T.) aequa nov.sp. (Turkey:
   Nigde, Adana), G. (T.) burdurica nov.sp. (Turkey: Burdur), G. (T.)
   akiana nov.sp. (Turkey: Antalya), G. (Sibiota) uniplicata nov.sp.
   (W-Caucasus), and G. (S.) convergens nov.sp. (W-Caucasus). One
   subgeneric name is synonymised: Sibiota CASEY 1906 = Typhlusida CASEY
   1906, nov.syn. Additional records from Turkey and the Caucasus region
   are reported for six species. Supplements to a recently published key to
   the Geostiba species of the East Mediterranean, including the Caucasus
   region and Iran, are provided. At present, 181 species in four subgenera
   are known from the region.

TI A revision of Palaearctic Sunius XIV. Three new species from Turkey and
   additional records (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Paederinae).
AU Assing, V. (vassing.hann@t-online.de) 
SO Linzer Biologische Beitraege
VL 43
IS 2
PS 1159-1168
PD 19 Dezember 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three species of the Sunius seminiger species group from Turkey are
   described and illustrated: Sunius sultanicus nov.sp. (Isparta/Konya:
   Sultan Daglan), S. aequus nov.sp. (Isparta: Kuyucak Dagi), and S.
   ulcerosus nov.sp. (Isparta: Dedegol Daglari). Supplements to a recent
   key to the Sunius species of the Palaearctic region are provided.
   Additional records of three species from Turkey and Spain are reported.
   In the Palaearctic region, the genus now comprises 116 species and two
   subspecies. The Turkish Sunius fauna is more diverse than that of any
   other country and at present includes 27 species.
C1 Assing, V.; Gabelsbergerstr 2, D-30163 Hannover, Germany, Germany.

DT Article
TI On some East Palaearctic Tetartopeus species (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae:
   Paederinae).
AU Assing, V. (vassing.hann@t-online.de) 
SO Linzer Biologische Beitraege
VL 43
IS 2
PS 1179-1197
PD 19 Dezember 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A revision of several East Palaearctic species of the paederine genus
   Tetartopeus CZWALINA 1888 revealed three synonymies: Tetartopeus
   kamtschaticus (BERNHAUER 1927) = Lathrobium gracile POPPIUS 1909,
   nov.syn., = L. poppiusi KOCH 1939, nov.syn.; Tetartopeus niger (LECONTE
   1863) = Lathrobium cognatum SHARP 1889, nov.syn. Lectotypes are
   designated for Lathrobium kamtschaticum BERNAUER 1927, L. cognatum SHARP
   1889, L. fragile SHARP 1889, and L. pallipes SHARP 1889. The external
   and sexual characters of six species are illustrated. A catalogue of the
   33 valid species currently known from the Palaearctic region is
   provided. Four of them are of doubtful identity, either because their
   descriptions are based on females or because their male sexual
   characters have not been examined. Additional records, among them
   several new country records, are presented for eight species.
C1 Assing, V.; Gabelsbergerstr 2, D-30163 Hannover, Germany, Germany.
EM vassing.hann@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 0253-116X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Synonymy; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones

   ] [ / East / Distribution; faunal list; new record; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae
OR Lathrobium cognatum - Sharp 1889 (Staphylinidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 1183]. 
   Lathrobium fragile - Sharp 1889 (Staphylinidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 1185]. 
   Lathrobium kamtschaticum - Bernhauer 1927 (Staphylinidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 1181]. 
   Lathrobium pallipes - Sharp 1889 (Staphylinidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 1187]. 
   Tetartopeus - Czwalina 1888 (Staphylinidae): [New record]. 
   Tetartopeus kamtschaticus - (Bernhauer 1927) (Staphylinidae): [Syn nov,
   Lathrobium poppiusi Koch 1939, p. 1181; Syn nov, Lathrobium punctatum
   var. gracile Poppius 1909, p. 1181]. 
   Tetartopeus niger - LeConte 1863 (Staphylinidae): [Syn nov, Lathrobium
   cognatum Sharp 1889, p. 1183].

PT J
AN ZOOR14803017629
DT Article
TI Contribution to the knowledge of Gyrophaena MANNERHEIM 1830 (Coleoptera:
   Staphylinidae: Aleocharinae: Gyrophaenina) of the Baikal region.
AU Enushchenko, I.V. (deschampsia@yandex.ru) 
   Shavrin, A.V.
SO Linzer Biologische Beitraege
VL 43
IS 2
PS 1199-1217
PD 19 Dezember 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Species of the genus Gyrophaena MANNERHEIM 1830 of the Baikal Region are
   reviewed. Twenty-one species are recorded, eighteen of which are
   confirmed by study of our material. Gyrophaena (Gyrophaena) aedugena
   ENUSHCHENKO sp. nov. from Irkutsk Area is described and illustrated. New
   synonymy is established: Gyrophaena (G.) joyi WENDELER 1924 = G. joyi
   asiatica WUSTHOFF 1937 syn. nov. The following species are newly
   recorded for Siberia: G. (G.) obsoleta GANGLBAUER 1895, G. (G.)
   pseudonana A. STRAND 1939, G. (G.) rugipennis MULSANT & REY 1861, G.
   (G.) transversalis A. STRAND 1939, G. (G.) williamsi A. STRAND 1935.
   Gyrophaena (G.) poweri CROTCH 1867 is newly recorded from Siberia and
   the Far East. Additional new records are as follows: G. (Phaenogyra)
   strictula ERTCHSON 1839 new for East Siberia, G. (Leptarthrophaena)
   affinis MANNERHEIM 1830, G. (G.) congrua ERICHSON 1837, G. (G.) gentilis
   ERICHSON 1839, G. (G.) manca ERICHSON 1839 and G. (G.) pulchella HEER
   1839 new for the Chita Area, G. (G.) joyi WENDELER new for Irkutsk and
   Chita Areas, G. (G.) orientalis A. STRAND 1938 new for Buryatia Republic
   and the Irkutsk and Chita Areas. Illustrations of genital structures are
   provided for G. joyi, G. manca, G. orientalis, and G. transversalis. The
   bionomics of sixteen species are presented.
C1 Enushchenko, I.V.; The V.B. Sochava Institute of Geography SB RAS,
   Ulan-Batorskaya str 1, Irkutsk 664033, Russia, Russia.
EM deschampsia@yandex.ru

SN 0253-116X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia

   systematics]. 
   Gyrophaena (Gyrophaena) aedugena [Russia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae
OR Gyrophaena - Mannerheim 1831 (Staphylinidae): [New record]. 
   Gyrophaena (Gyrophaena) aedugena - Enushchenko 2011 (Staphylinidae): [Sp

TI First record of Aneurinae from New Caledonia (Hemiptera, Heteroptera,
   Aradidae).
AU Heiss, E. (aradus@aon.at) 
SO Linzer Biologische Beitraege
VL 43
IS 2
PS 1331-1338
PD 19 Dezember 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The flat bug subfamily Aneurinae was not yet recorded from New
   Caledonia. In the present paper a new genus Caledoneurus nov.gen. with
   the species lariviereae nov.sp. and Aneurillodes cascadensis nov.sp. are
   described and illustrated. Their relationships to other Oriental-South
   Pacific Aneurinae are discussed.

   Innsbruck, Austria, Austria.

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Gabrius STEPHENS 1829 from Madagascar and
   adjoining Islands (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Philonthina).
AU Hromadka, L. (hromadkal@seznam.cz) 
SO Linzer Biologische Beitraege
VL 43
IS 2
PS 1377-1397
PD 19 Dezember 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Madagascarian and adjoining Islands species of the genus Gabrius
   STEPHENS 1829 (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae) are revised taxonomically.
   Fifteen species are recognized, including 3 new species: Gabrius ardeola
   nov.sp. (Madagascar), Gabrius cvanolanius nov.sp. (Madagascar), Gabrius
   taphozous nov.sp. (Madagascar). Twelve species are redescribed: G.
   delamarei JARRIGE 1970 (Madagascar), G..fauveli (COQUEREL 1866)
   (Reunion), G. frmbriolatus ERICHSON 1840 (Ethiopia, Kenya, Madagascar,
   Mascarene Islands, Seychelles), G. gomyi LECOQ 1990 (Reunion), G.
   ingratus FAUVEE, 1905 (Madagascar), G. lemur JARRIGE 1978 (Madagascar),
   G. macer LECOQ 1990 (Reunion), G. oceanicus TOTTENHAM 1956 (Seychelles),
   G. phelsuma HROMADKA 2007 (Madagascar), G. quadriceps JARRIGE 1978
   (Madagascar), G. rabigoides JARRIGE 1957 (Reunion), G. tsaratananus
   JARRIGE 1970 (Madagascar). All species are (re) described and
   morphological details of some species and aedeagi of all species are
   figured. An identification key to all species is provided.
C1 Hromadka, L.; Anny Letenske 7, CZ-120 00 Praha 2, Czech Republic, Czech
   Republic.
EM hromadkal@seznam.cz

   Tinodes), Hydropsychidae (Cheumatopsyche, Hydropsyche), Ecnomidae
   (Ecnomus), Brachycentridae (Micrasema) and Lepidostomatidae
   (Lepidostoma). Variation in Paduniella koehleri is figured.

DT Article
TI Contribution to the Ichneumoninae (Hymenoptera, Ichneumonidae) of
   Southeastern Asia: 1. Tribes Clypeodromini, Listrodromini, Goedartini,
   Compsophorini, and Platylabini.
AU Riedel, M. (mamaflo.Riedel@t-online.de) 
SO Linzer Biologische Beitraege
VL 43
IS 2
PS 1549-1572
PD 19 Dezember 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this publication, three collections of Oriental Ichneumoninae
   (Hymenoptera, Ichneumonidae) mainly from Laos, Vietnam and Taiwan have
   been studied. Distributional records of 40 species and subspecies
   belonging to the tribes Clypeodromini, Listrodromini, Goedartini,
   Compsophorini, and Platylabini are mentioned, one genus and 15 species
   and subspecies are described as new. New genus is: Paraplatylabus
   nov.gen. New species and subspecies are: Clypeodromus laoticus nov.sp.,
   Clypeodromus rarus nov.sp., Anisobas kankoensis nov.ssp. laoticus,
   Listrodromus flavomaculatus nov.sp., Listrodromus propodealis nov.sp.,
   Listrodromus propodealis nov.ssp. sabahensis, Habrojoppa vietnamensis
   nov.sp., Maraces flavobalteata nov.ssp. vietnwnensis, Maraces
   rufothoracica nov.sp., Apaeleticus tonkinesis nov.sp., Asthenolabus
   vietnamensis nov.sp., Platylabus flagellator nov.sp., Platylabus
   rufromesonotator nov.sp., Paraplatylabus vietnamensis nov.sp., and
   Pristicerops rufithorax nov.sp. The hitherto unknown [female] is
   described for Listrodromus javae HEINRICH. For Charitojoppa gracilis
   HEINRICH, Plandahus septemcingulatus HEINRICH, Pristicerops principal is
   HEINRICH and Notoplatylabus birmanicus HEINRICH the unknown males are
   described.

TI [Information on the Bledius (Hesperophilus) atricapillus species group
   (GERMAR) (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae: Oxytelinae).]
FT Zur Kenntnis der Verwandtschaft von Bledius (Hesperophilus) atricapillus
   (GERMAR) (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae: Oxytelinae).
AU Schuelke, M. (mschuelke.berlin@t-online.de) 
SO Linzer Biologische Beitraege
VL 43
IS 2
PS 1595-1608
PD 19 Dezember 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB On the identity of Sepedophilus immaculatus STEPHENS. - Sepedophilus
   aestivus (REV 1882), previously a synonym of S. immaculatus is
   revalidated and distinguished from the latter by the male sexual
   characters. Illustrations of its primary and secondary sexual characters
   are provided. The species is distributed in Western Europe and North
   Africa. Sepedophilus cinctus (MOTSCHULSKY 1858) is removed from the
   synonymy of S. immaculatus and regarded as species dubia.
C1 Schuelke, M.; Blankenfelder Strasse 99, D-13127 Berlin, Germany,
   Germany.
EM mschuelke.berlin@t-online.de

SN 0253-116X

   Key; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

   (Hesperophilus) nanus [Palaearctic region /  / Distribution; new record;

   /  / ] [Germany /  / ] [Italy /  / ].

   [Syn nov, Bledius praetermissus Williams 1929, p. 1599; Nomen protectum,

DT Article
TI New species and records of Nandeva Wiedenbrug, Reiss et Fittkau
   (Chironomidae: Chironominae).
AU Andersen, Trond (trond.andersen@zmb.uib.no) 
   Saether, Ole A.
   Contreras-Ramos, Atilano
SO Zootaxa
VL 3136
PS 45-60
PD 19 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3136.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt03136p060.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Nandeva digitifer sp. n. from Chile is described and figured as male and
   female and N. verruculata sp. n. from Brazil as male. The female of N.
   latiloba Saether et Roque is also described and figured and new
   Neotropical records of N. latiloba, N. strixinorum Saether et Roque and
   N. tropica Wiedenbrug, Reiss et Fittkau are given. The female of N.
   fittkaui Cranston is re-examined. New generic diagnosis and description
   are given for the imagines. Some character states from previous
   parsimony analyses are corrected and new analyses performed indicating
   Nandeva as part of Tanytarsini or as part of the sister group to
   Tanytarsini.

DT Article
TI Samariscus neocaledonia, a new righteye flounder (Teleostei:
   Pleuronectiformes: Samaridae) from New Caledonia.
AU Kawai, Toshio (kawai@museum.hokudai.ac.jp) 
   Amaoka, Kunio
   Seret, Bernard
SO Zootaxa
VL 3135
PS 63-68
PD 19 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3135.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03135p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new righteye flounder, Samariscus neocaledonia sp. nov., is described
   on the basis of two specimens collected in deep waters (244-278 m)
   around New Caledonia. The new species is easily distinguished from its
   18 congeners in having a combination of 78-81 dorsal fin rays, 62-65
   anal fin rays, five pectoral fin rays, ca. 55-62 lateral line scales,
   and 10 abdominal and 31-32 caudal vertebrae.
C1 Kawai, Toshio; Fisheries Science Center, Hokkaido University Museum,
   3-1-1 Minato-cho, Hakodate, Hokkaido 041-8611, Japan, Japan.
EM kawai@museum.hokudai.ac.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Samariscus neocaledonia [South Pacific / New Caledonia / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Pleuronectiformes, Pleuronectidae
OR Samariscus neocaledonia (Pleuronectidae): [Sp nov, New Caledonia
   (marine), P. 64].

PT J
AN ZOOR14802015662
DT Article
TI Species relationships in the Neotropical genus Phareicranaus Roewer 1913
   (Opiliones: Cranaidae): two new species and new data from Penial
   morphology.
AU Pinto-da-Rocha, Ricardo (ricrocha@usp.br) 
   Bonaldo, Alexandre B.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3135
PS 1-34
PD 19 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3135.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03135p034.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A reanalysis of the species relationships in the genus Phareicranaus
   Roewer, 1913, here considered the senior synonym of Acanthocranaus
   Roewer, 1913, Santinezia Roewer, 1923 and Comboyus Roewer, 1943, is
   carried out, using information unavailable in a previous analysis (of
   Santinezia). Subfamilies Cranainae and Prostygninae may be not
   monophyletic, since the generic relationships among cranaines are still
   obscure; it seems that Phareicranaus is closely related to Ventrivomer
   Roewer, 1913 and Ventrisudis Roewer, 1963, based on presence of a
   ventral apophysis on male coxa IV and cylindrical pedipalpal femur. The
   analysis performed with equal weighting generated 64 equally parsimonius
   trees (275 steps, ci= .24; ri= .60), and the strict consensus tree
   differs substantially from previous analyses. Based on results of the
   equally weigthed cladistic analysis, Phareicranaus is supported by the
   following unambiguous synapomorphies: penis base of the glans ringed;
   pedipalpal femur with a stout dorsoapical spine; strong ventral
   tubercles on pedipalpal femur and; area II invading area I (the two
   halves do not touch each other). Two new species are described,
   Phareicranaus divisor (type-locality: Brazil, Acre, Parque Nacional da
   Serra do Divisor) and P. patauateua (type-locality: Brazil, Para, Ourem,
   Patauateua, fazenda Gaviao). Male genitalia are described for the
   following cranaids: Chiriboga albituber Roewer, 1959; Metacranaus
   tricalcaris Roewer, 1913; Phareicranaus calcariger (Roewer, 1913), comb.
   n.; P. albimedialis (Goodnight & Goodnight, 1943); P. festae Roewer,
   1925; P. parallelus Roewer, 1925; P. angelicus (Roewer, 1963) comb. n.;
   and P. ortizi (Roewer, 1952) and Ventrisudis mira Roewer, 1963. The
   following new combinations are proposed: from Acanthocranaus,
   Phareicranaus calcariger (Roewer, 1913); from Santinezia, Phareicranaus
   albilineatus (Roewer, 1932); P. angelicus (Roewer, 1963); P.
   arthrocentricus (Mello-Leitao, 1943), P. biordi (Gonzalez-Sponga, 1991);
   P. calcarfemoralis (Roewer, 1917); P. calcaritibialis (Roewer, 1915); P.
   capayitaensis (Gonzalez-Sponga, 2003); P. contrerasi (Gonzalez- Sponga,
   2003); P. circumlineatus (Gonzalez-Sponga, 1989); P. curvipes (Roewer,
   1916); P. duranti (Gonzalez-Sponga, 1989); P. fronteriza
   (Gonzalez-Sponga, 2003); P. furva (Pinto-da-Rocha & Kury, 2003); P.
   giganteus (Roewer, 1913); P. glaber (Gonzalez-Sponga, 2003); P. gracilis
   (Pinto-da-Rocha & Kury, 2003); P. guaricoensis (Gonzalez-Sponga, 2003);
   P. heliae (Avram, 1983); P. hermosa (Pinto-da-Rocha & Kury, 2003); P.
   lamitisus (Gonzalez-Sponga, 2003); P. leonensis (Gonzalez-Sponga, 2003);
   P. lucifer (Pinto-da-Rocha & Kury, 2003); P. manauara (Pinto-da-Rocha,
   1994); P. noctiscansor (Townsend & Milne 2010); P. onorei
   (Pinto-da-Rocha & Kury, 2003); P. ortizi (Roewer, 1952); P. parvus
   (Gonzalez- Sponga, 2003); P. sanarensis (Gonzalez-Sponga, 2003); P.
   simonbolivari (Avram, 1987); P. singularis (H. Soares, 1970); P.
   soledadensis (Gonzalez-Sponga, 2003); P. spinulatus (Goodnight &
   Goodnight, 1943); and P. subparamera (Gonzalez- Sponga, 2003).
   Santinezia sanarensis humocaroensis Gonzalez-Sponga, 2003, transferred
   to Phareicranaus, is elevated to species level, proposing the new
   combination and new status: Phareicranaus humocaroensis
   (Gonzalez-Sponga, 2003). Three new names are proposed: Phareicranaus
   roeweri to replace Nieblia festae Roewer, 1925, preoccupied by
   Phareicranaus festae Roewer, 1925; Phareicranaus goodnightorum to
   replace Santinezia magna Goodnight & Goodnight 1942, preoccupied by
   Phareicranaus magnus (Roewer, 1932); and Phareicranaus kuryi to replace
   Comboyus albilineatus Roewer, 1943, preoccupied by Santinezia
   albilineata Roewer, 1932, which is presently a junior synonym of Inezia
   curvipes Roewer, 1916 (now Phareicranaus curvipes). Phareicranaus
   cingulatus Roewer, 1932 and Santinezia serratotibialis Roewer, 1932 are
   newly synonymized with Goniosoma calcariferum Simon, 1879 (the type
   species of Phareicranaus). Additionally, Phareicranaus giganteus Roewer,
   1932 is newly synonymized with Holocranaus longipes Roewer 1913, and the
   monotypic genus Meridia Roewer 1913 (type species M. palpalis Roewer
   1913) is transferred from Manaosbiidae to Cranaidae, Cranainae.
C1 Pinto-da-Rocha, Ricardo; Depto de Zoologia, Instituto de Biociencias,
   Universidade de Sao Paulo, Rua do Matao, travessa 14, 321, 05508-900,
   Sao Paulo SP, Brazil, Brazil.
EM ricrocha@usp.br
RI Bonaldo, Alexandre Bragio/C-6622-2011; Pinto-da-Rocha,
   Ricardo/J-6774-2012
OI Bonaldo, Alexandre Bragio/0000-0002-8216-5110; Pinto-da-Rocha,
   Ricardo/0000-0002-3959-2205
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Available name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   General morphology; Reproduction; Reproductive system; Evolution; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; South America

DT Article
TI Mexistrophia, a new genus of Cerionidae from Mexico (Gastropoda:
   Pulmonata: Urocoptoidea).
AU Thompson, Fred G. (fgt@flmnh.ufl.edu) 
SO Nautilus
VL 125
IS 4
PS 182-192
PD Dec 16 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Mexistrophia new genus and three new species of the landsnail family
   Cerionidae, Mexistrophia reticulate new species, M. obsolete new
   species, M. inexpectate new species, are described from northeastern
   Mexico. The genus is characterized by the absence of lamella or other
   barriers within the shell. The genus is diagnosed by soft anatomical
   features as well as shell characteristics. The known distribution of
   Mexistrophia is confined to higher elevations at 2000-2600 meters in the
   Sierra Madre Oriental in the states of Nuevo Leon, Queretaro and
   Hidalgo, where it inhabits cool temperate conifer forests that are
   subject to seasonal frosts and occasional freezes. Its distribution is
   disjunct geographically and ecologically from that of Cerion, which is
   confined to the tropical Caribbean region at very low elevations.
C1 Thompson, Fred G.; Univ Florida, Florida Museum Nat Hist, Gainesville,
   FL, 32611, USA, USA.
EM fgt@flmnh.ufl.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0028-1344

   America

   [Mexico /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs

   Orthalicoidea

PT J
AN ZOOR14803024563
DT Article
TI New Cretaceous turbiniform vetigastropods (Gastropoda) from the Pacific
   slope of North America.
AU Squires, Richard L. (richard.squires@csun.edu) 
SO Nautilus
VL 125
IS 4
PS 193-206
PD Dec 16 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Seven new species of warm-temperate, shallow-marine turbiniform
   vetigastropods are described from Cretaceous strata in the region
   extending from Vancouver Island, British Columbia, to northern Baja
   California, Mexico. The chilodontine Agathadanta haegerti new species
   (latest Santonian) is the first confirmed species of this extant genus
   in the Western Hemisphere. The calliotropine Cidarina grahami new
   species (middle Campanian) is the earliest record of this extant genus.
   The colloniines Afrollonia elderensis new species (late Albian) and
   Antillocallonia has. new species (Turonian) are the earliest records of
   these extinct genera in Western Hemisphere. The teguline Tegula daileyi
   new species (late Campanian) is one of the few known Campanian species
   of this extant genus. The margaritines Pupillaria encina new species and
   Pupillaria lomana new species (both of which are late Campanian to
   possibly early Maastrichtian in age) are the earliest records of this
   extant genus. During the course of this study, it was discovered that
   the nododelphinulid Trochacanthns wallalense (White, 1885) (late
   Campanian to early late Maastrichtian) is the senior synonym of T
   pacificus Squires and Saul, 2001. White's species is the only known
   occurrence of this extinct genus in the Western Hemisphere.
C1 Squires, Richard L.; Calif State Univ Northridge, Dept Geol Sci,
   Northridge, CA, 91330, USA, USA.
EM richard.squires@csun.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0028-1344
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America; Canada; USA; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Afrollonia; Antillocollonia; Cidarina; Pupillaria; Tegula [Land zones /
   Western Hemisphere / new geological records] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Afrollonia elderensis; Antillocollonia bos; Pupillaria encina;
   Pupillaria lomana; Tegula daileyi [California /  / new species]
   [Cretaceous /  / ].

   species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Vetigastropoda [North America / Pacific Slope region / Systematics].

   Amberleyoidea, Trochoidea

   Trochacanthus wallalense - (White 1885) (Amberleyoidea): [Syn nov,
   Trochacanthus pacificus Squires & Saul 2001, p. 193; Fossil]. 
   Afrollonia (Trochoidea): [Fossil]. 
   Afrollonia elderensis (Trochoidea): [Sp nov, California, Cretaceous, P.

TI Systematic revision of the American taxa belonging to the genera
   Alloblackburneus Bordat, 2009, and Blackburneus Schmidt, 1913, with
   description of seven new species (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Aphodiinae).
AU Dellacasa, Marco (dellacasa@museo.unipi.it) 
   Dellacasa, Giovanni
   Gordon, Robert D.
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 0204
PS 1-52
PD 16 December 2011
PY 2011
UR http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0204Dellacasaetal.
   pdf
AW http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0204Dellacasaetal.
   pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The American species belonging to the genera Alloblackburneus Bordat and
   Blackburneus Schmidt (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Aphodiinae) are
   redescribed and figured. Seven new species are described:
   Alloblackburneus guadalajarae, A. ibanezbernali; Blackburneus
   amazonicus, B. sanfilippoi, B. surinamensis, B. teposcolulaensis, B.
   thomasi. The neotype of Scarabaeus rubeolus Palisot de Beauvois, 1809 is
   designated. The lectotype of Blackburneus argentinensis (Schmidt, 1909)
   and of Blackburneus laxepunctatus (Schmidt, 1910) are designated. The
   following new combinations are proposed: Alloblackburneus aegrotus
   (Horn, 1870); Alloblackburneus cavidomus (Brown, 1927); Alloblackburneus
   cynomysi (Brown, 1927); Alloblackburneus fordi (Gor- don, 1974);
   Alloblackburneus geomysi (Cartwright, 1939); Alloblackburneus lentus
   (Horn, 1870); Alloblackburneus rubeolus (Palisot de Beauvois, 1805);
   Alloblackburneus saylori (Hinton, 1934); Alloblackburneus tenuistriatus
   (Horn, 1887); Alloblackburneus troglodytes (Hubbard, 1894).

PT J
AN ZOOR14802015728
DT Article
TI Vespidae (Insecta: Hymenoptera) of Puerto Rico, West Indies.
AU Carpenter, James M. (carpenter@amnh.org) 
   Genaro, Julio A.
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 0202
PS 1-35
PD 16 December 2011
PY 2011
UR http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0202CarpenterGenar
   o.pdf
AW http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0202CarpenterGenar
   o.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The vespid fauna of Greater Puerto Rico is reviewed (Hymenoptera:
   Vespidae). Three new species are described, Ancistrocerus isla
   Carpenter, Euodynerus jeitita Carpenter and Genaro, and Omicron aridum
   Carpenter and Genaro. Polistes crinitus americanus (Fabricius, 1775) and
   P. crinitus multicolor (Olivier, 1792) are both reduced to synonyms of
   nominotypical P. crinitus (Felton, 1765), revised status; Zeta
   abdominale hispaniolae (Bequaert and Salt, 1931) and Zeta abdominale
   ornatum (de Saussure, 1855) are both reduced to synonyms of
   nominotypical Zeta abdominale (Drury, 1770), revised status; and Zethus
   ruinodus monensis Bohart and Stange, 1965, and Zethus ruinodus
   virginicus Bohart and Stange, 1965, are both reduced to synonyms of
   nominotypical Zethus ruinodus (Latreille, 1806), revised status.
   Parancistrocerus obliquus (Cresson, 1865) is newly recorded from Puerto
   Rico. The presence of Pachodynerus guadulpensis (de Saussure, 1853) in
   Puerto Rico is confirmed. An analysis of the composition of the Puerto
   Rican vespid fauna is presented.
C1 Carpenter, James M.; Division of Invertebrate Zoology, American Museum
   of Natural History, New York, NY 10024, USA, USA.
EM carpenter@amnh.org
SC Zoology
SN 0749-6737; 1942-1354

   zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies

   / ].

   Vespoidea, Eumenidae, Vespidae

   Ancistrocerus isla - Carpenter 2011 (Eumenidae): [Sp nov, Puerto Rico,
   P. 6]. 
   Euodynerus jeitita (Eumenidae): [Sp nov, Dominican Republic, P. 7]. 
   Omicron aridum (Eumenidae): [Sp nov, Puerto Rico, P. 9]. 
   Parancistrocerus obliquus (Eumenidae): [New record].

DT Article
TI Gymnothorax melanosomatus, a new moray eel (Teleostei: Anguilliformes:
   Muraenidae) from southeastern Taiwan.
AU Loh, Kar-Hoe
   Shao, Kwang-Tsao
   Chen, Hong-Ming (hmchen@mail.ntou.edu.tw) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3134
PS 43-52
PD 16 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3134.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt03134p052.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Gymnothorax melanosomatus new species, is described here on the basis of
   eight specimens collected from eastern coastal Taiwan at a depth 50[long
   dash]180 m. This new moray eel is distinguished from a closely similar
   species, G. prolatus, by a combination of the following characters: a
   uniformly black body when fresh (vs. brown), a relatively long preanal
   length 58.5 % of TL (vs. 48.9), shorter snout length 17.8 % of HL (vs.
   20.0), interobital width 12.2 % of HL (vs. 14.3); more preanal vertebrae
   105[long dash]109 (vs. 74[long dash]86) and total vertebrae 201[long
   dash]211 (vs. 174[long dash]190). The male and female are not different
   in body color and pattern, but the numbers of median intermaxillary
   teeth are different between the sexes, 0 in male and 2[long dash]3 in
   female.
C1 Chen, Hong-Ming; Department of Aquaculture, National Taiwan Ocean
   University, Keelung, 202, Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM hmchen@mail.ntou.edu.tw
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Marine
   zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Gymnothorax melanosomatus [North Pacific / Taiwan / New species].

ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,

   44].

   [Diagnostic characters, P. 48].

DT Article
TI Eviota rubriceps, a new goby from the Southwestern Pacific Ocean, with
   comments on E. mikiae and E. raja (Teleostei: Gobiidae).
AU Greenfield, David W. (greenfie@hawaii.edu) 
   Jewett, Susan L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3134
PS 53-62
PD 16 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3134.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03134p062.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of goby, Eviota rubriceps, most similar to E. nigrispina,
   is described from Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, and the Philippine
   Islands. Both species have the lower two thirds of the body dark in
   preserved specimens, belong to the cephalic sensory-pore pattern group 2
   of Lachner and Karnella (1980), have an 8/7 dorsal/anal formula, and
   unbranched pectoral-fin rays. Eviota rubriceps differs from E.
   nigrispina in live and preserved coloration and in caudal-peduncle
   depth. The descriptions of E. mikiae and E. raja are expanded based on
   additional materials.
C1 Greenfield, David W.; 944 Egan Ave., Pacific Grove, CA 93950, USA, USA.
EM greenfie@hawaii.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Ocean
DE Eviota rubriceps [North Pacific / Philippines / New species] [South
   Pacific / Indonesia / ] [ / Papua New Guinea / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Gobiidae

   Eviota raja - Allen 2001 (Gobiidae): [Redescription, P. 61]. 
   Eviota rubriceps (Gobiidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia (marine), P. 54].

AN ZOOR14802015543
DT Article
TI A new species of Proceratophrys Miranda-Ribeiro (Amphibia: Anura:
   Cycloramphidae) from the Chapada Diamantina, State of Bahia,
   northeastern Brazil.
AU Felgueiras Napoli, Marcelo (napoli@ufba.br) 
   Goncalves Cruz, Carlos Alberto
   de Abreu, Rafael Oliveira
   del-Grande, Maria Lucia
SO Zootaxa
VL 3133
PS 37-49
PD 16 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3133.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03133p049.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe a new species of Proceratophrys, allied to P. schirchi, from
   the northern sector of the Espinhaco mountain range, within a semiarid
   region in central State of Bahia known as Chapada Diamantina. The new
   species inhabits seasonal semi-deciduous forests (usually known as dry
   forests) that cover the mountainous relief of the Serra de Jacobina, a
   regional designation of the Espinhaco mountain range in northeastern
   Brazil. Proceratophrys minuta sp. nov. most resembles P. schirchi by
   combination of small palpebral appendages, general external morphology,
   and by its restriction to Atlantic Forest remnants. It is diagnosed from
   all congeners by the combination of small body size (snout[long
   dash]vent length, males 20.4[long dash]25.2 mm, females 28.3[long
   dash]31.9 mm), absence of rostral appendage, short palpebral appendages
   with the central prominent, dorsum adorned with sinuous longitudinal
   ridges outlining a spear-shaped ornamentation like a hastate-shaped leaf
   (with flaring pointed lobes at eyes and spear point at urostile), and
   other six morphological characteristics. We also describe the tadpole of
   P. minuta sp. nov., and compare its color and external morphology with
   other tadpoles of Proceratophrys described in the literature.
C1 Felgueiras Napoli, Marcelo; Museu de Zoologia, Departamento de Zoologia,
   Instituto de Biologia, Universidade Federal da Bahia, Campus
   Universitario, Rua Barao de Jeremoabo, Ondina, 40170-115 Salvador,
   Bahia, Brazil, Brazil.
EM napoli@ufba.br
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Proceratophrys minuta [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Leptodactylidae
OR Proceratophrys minuta (Leptodactylidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 39]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14802015543
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14802015547
DT Article
TI Amphicutis stygobita, a new genus and new species of brittle star
   (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea: Ophiurida: Amphilepididae) found in Bernier
   Cave, an anchialine cave on San Salvador Island, Bahamas.
AU Pomory, Christopher M. (cpomory@uwf.edu) 
   Carpenter, Jerry H.
   Winter, John H.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3133
PS 50-68
PD 16 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3133.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03133p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Amphicutis stygobita is a new genus and new species of ophiuroid found
   in Bernier Cave, an anchialine cave on San Salvador Island, Bahamas. The
   species is small (disk diameter 3[long dash]4 mm) with short arms
   (2[long dash]2.5X disk diameter). Dorsal disk features include
   imbricated scales, and oval radial shields separated by a column of
   scales. Ventral disk features include imbricated scales, genital scales
   flat and thin, no bursal sacs, second tentacle pore of oral frame
   outside mouth slit, oral shields small ovals similar in appearance to
   disk scales, two to three oral papillae per jaw side with the proximal
   papillae usually in the infradental position, and ventral tooth at the
   apex of each jaw broadly rounded. The arms are the most distinctive
   feature. Dorsal arm plates are small diamond-oval shaped and separated
   from one another by a gap equal to the arm plate length. Ventral arm
   plates are small figure-8 shaped and separated from one another by a gap
   equal to the arm plate length. Lateral arm plates meet medially on
   dorsal and ventral sides and make up most of an arm segment. Each
   lateral arm plate bears two arm spines. Disk and arms are often formed
   by soft tissue outlining plates and scales, but lacking significant
   calcification. A raised skin persists after calcification, from which
   the genus name derives. The species is named for its aquatic
   cave-dwelling habit, apparently endemic to a single cave, and may be
   unique among ophiuroids in being restricted to a cave environment.
C1 Pomory, Christopher M.; Department of Biology, University of West
   Florida, Pensacola, Florida 32514, USA, USA.
EM cpomory@uwf.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North
   Atlantic
DE Amphicutis stygobita [Caribbean Sea / Bahamas / New species]. 
TN Echinoderms; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Echinodermata, Stelleroidea, Ophiuroidea
OR Amphicutis (Ophiuroidea): [Gen nov, Of family Amphilepididae, Type
   species Amphicutis stygobita, p. 53]. 
   Amphicutis stygobita (Ophiuroidea): [Sp nov, Bahamas (marine), P. 54]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14802015547
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14802015540
DT Article
TI New genus for a unique species of Indo-West Pacific bryozoan.
AU Tilbrook, Kevin J. (kevin.tilbrook@qm.qld.gov.au) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3134
PS 63-67
PD 16 Dec 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/3134.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt03134p067.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Larval type, larval morphology, ancestrular morphology and colony
   astogeny have great systematic value in the cheilostomate bryozoans, but
   for most species these characters are undocumented. Whilst most
   cheilostomate bryozoan species produce lecithotrophic coronate larvae; a
   minority of species produce planktotrophic cyphonautes larvae, all
   belonging to genera within the superfamily Membraniporoidea. Biflustra
   laboriosa Tilbrook, 2006 nominally belongs to a membraniporid genus
   whose species are otherwise characterised by having a twinned
   ancestrula. The production of a single ancestrula from a cyphonautes
   larva and overall zooidal morphology excludes B. laboriosa from the
   Membraniporidae and its zooidal characters are alien to any other
   membraniporoidean genus. Accordingly, Tarsocryptus n. gen. is erected to
   accommodate it, resulting in the new combination Tarsocryptus laboriosa
   n. comb. Its reassignment here to the membraniporoidean Electridae is
   tentative.
C1 Tilbrook, Kevin J.; Museum of Tropical Queensland, 70[long dash]102
   Flinders Street, Townsville, Queensland, 4810, Australia, Australia.
EM kevin.tilbrook@qm.qld.gov.au
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination
TN Bryozoans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Bryozoa
OR Biflustra laboriosa - Tibrook 2006 (Bryozoa): [Designated type species
   for new genus, Tarsocryptus, p. 64]. 
   Tarsocryptus (Bryozoa): [Gen nov, Of family Electridae?, Type species
   Biflustra laboriosa Tibrook 2006, p. 64]. 
   Tarsocryptus laboriosa - (Tibrook 2006) (Bryozoa): [Description, P. 66;
   Comb nov, Transferred from Biflustra, p. 64]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14802015540
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14807051863
DT Article
TI Digital-Weevil-Determination for Curculionoidea of West Palaearctic.
   Transalpina: Polydrusus (Entiminae: Polydrusini).
FT Digital-Weevil-Determination der westpalaearktischen Curculionoidea.
   Transalpina: Polydrusus (Entiminae: Polydrusini).
GP CURCULIO Team
SO Snudebiller
VL 12
PS 11-38
PD 15 December 2011
PY 2011
LA English; German
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the framework of the 'Digital Weevil Determination' project a digital
   and interactive determination work for the genus Polydrusus (Entiminae:
   Polydrusini) is presented for the first time as a pictorial key in
   English and German language. The check-list includes 45 (sub-)species
   from the northern part of West Palaearctic Region ("Transalpina", the
   zoogeographical area north of the Pyrenees, the Alps and the Balkan
   Mountains; the eastern delimitation is orientated approximately along
   the eastern borderlines of the EU members). We did not receive the types
   or any other specimens of 4 taxa and could not include these in our
   study. All information in the key is firstly given in a pictorial format
   and is also - more additionally - 'translated' into text. By this, we
   follow a basic principle of modern entomological and taxonomical work:
   To see by light-optical microscope exactly that, what the digital
   picture is keeping ready on the screen. The following synonyms are
   given: Polydrusus (Piezocnemus) chaerodrysius Gredler 1866 =
   carinthiacus (K.&J. Daniel 1898) syn. nov. = cejkai Roubal 1928 syn nov.
   This work includes distribution maps and information on the biology for
   some species.
EM P.Stueben@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 1439-4650
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones
DE Polydrusus [Checklists /  / Systematics] [Palaearctic region / West /
   Key to species & subgenera] [ /  / Biology; distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Curculionoidea,
   Curculionidae
OR Polydrusus - Germar 1817 (Curculionidae): [Key to subgenera, Palaearctic
   region, West, English, p. 12, German, p. 26; Key to species, Palaearctic
   region, West, English, p. 12, German, p. 26]. 
   Polydrusus (Piezocnemus) chaerodrysius - Gredler 1866 (Curculionidae):
   [Syn nov, Polydrusus carinthiacus Daniel & Daniel 1898, p. 17; Syn nov,
   Polydrusus cejkai Roubal 1928, p. 17]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807051863
DA 2020-09-17
